{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shawn_Camp_(singer)","to":"Shawn Camp (singer)"}],"pages":{"11851769":{"pageid":11851769,"ns":0,"title":"Shawn Camp (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = Shawncamp-fls.jpg\n| caption           = Performing at Suwannee Springtime Reunion, March 22, 2018\n| name              = Shawn Camp\n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = Darrell DeShawn Camp<ref>{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/writer.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&querytype=WriterID&keyid=520279&keyname=CAMP%20DARRELL%20DE%20SHAWN&CAE=128966143&Affiliation=BMI|title=Listing for Darrell DeShawn Camp|work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|access-date=January 19, 2010}}</ref>\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1966|8|29}}\n| origin            = [[Perryville, Arkansas]], US\n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar, fiddle\n| genre             = [[country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[americana (music)|Americana]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active      = 1991\u2013present\n| label             = [[Reprise Records|Reprise]], Skeeterbit, [[Oh Boy Records|Oh Boy]]\n| associated_acts   = [[Tim Mensy]]<br />[[Josh Turner]]<br />[[The Earls of Leicester]]\n| partner           = Lisa Stewart (2021-present)\n| website           = {{url|shawncamp.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Darrell DeShawn Camp''' (born August 29, 1966) is an American musician who performs [[country music|country]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] music. Originally signed to [[Reprise Records]] in 1993 as a recording artist, Camp charted two minor singles on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts that year. Since then he has found success as a songwriter, having co-written hit singles for many country music artists, including [[Willie Nelson]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[Josh Turner]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], and [[Blake Shelton]], although he continues to record his own material as well. The 2023 Grammy Awards presented the legendary Willie Nelson's \"A Beautiful Time\" with \"Country Album of The Year\". The title cut, along with album cut, \"We're Not Happy ('Til You're Not Happy)\", were both penned by Camp.\n\n==Biography==\nCamp was raised in [[Perryville, Arkansas]] by a musical family.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/shawn-camp-mn0000015822/biography|title=Shawn Camp &#124; Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=January 22, 2020}}</ref> In 1987, he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and worked in the backing bands of  acts including The Grand Prairie Boys, [[Osborne Brothers]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Suzy Bogguss]], and [[Trisha Yearwood]].<ref name=\"camp\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.shawncamp.com/about.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070529181547/http://www.shawncamp.com/about.html|url-status=dead|title=Shawn Camp: About|archive-date=May 29, 2007}}</ref> In 1991, he was signed to [[Reprise Records]], with two minor Top 40 singles charting in 1993.<ref name=\"camp\"/> The first of these, \"Fallin' Never Felt So Good\", was previously recorded by [[Dude Mowrey]].\n\nCamp recorded a second album for Reprise, but never released it due to creative differences. He then began writing for other artists. Camp's first Number One as a songwriter came in early 1998, when [[Garth Brooks]] reached the top of the ''Billboard'' country charts with \"[[Two Pi\u00f1a Coladas]]\", a song co-written by Camp.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Later in the same year, [[Brooks & Dunn]] reached Number One with \"[[How Long Gone]]\", another Camp co-write.<ref name=\"camp\"/><ref name=\"pdf\">{{cite web |url=http://ohboy.com/media/shawncamppublicity.pdf |title=Archived copy |website=ohboy.com |access-date=13 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040919173438/http://ohboy.com/media/shawncamppublicity.pdf |archive-date=19 September 2004 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nCamp released ''Lucky Silver Dollar'' in 2001.<ref name=\"camp\"/> In 2006, he was nominated as Songwriter of the Year by the Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music; also, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' ranked him No.10 on their 2006 list of Hot Country Songwriters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cowboyjackclement.com/shawn_camp/ |title=Shawn Camp and Jack Clement |website=www.cowboyjackclement.com |access-date=13 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061108012231/http://www.cowboyjackclement.com/shawn_camp/ |archive-date=8 November 2006 |url-status=dead}}</ref> In the same year, two songs co-written by Camp entered the country charts: \"[[Nobody But Me (Blake Shelton song)|Nobody But Me]]\" by [[Blake Shelton]], and \"[[Would You Go with Me]]\" by [[Josh Turner]], which peaked at No.4 and No.1, respectively, on the ''Billboard'' U.S. [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Camp also co-wrote Turner's 2007 single \"[[Firecracker (song)|Firecracker]]\", [[George Strait]]'s 2008 single \"[[River of Love]]\", and [[Billy Currington]]'s 2011 single \"[[Love Done Gone]]\".\n\nSince early 2007, Camp had been collaborating with country legend [[Loretta Lynn]] writing songs such as \"I'm Dyin' for Someone to Live For\" and \"I'm More Alone When I'm With You\" together. Camp has featured some of the photographs taken at the Cash Cabin Studios in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]] which many believe means he is going to be duetting on some of Lynn's upcoming albums. The pair usually wrote together at Lynn's home in [[Hurricane Mills, Tennessee]] (known as The Loretta Lynn Dude Ranch.)\n\nIn September 2010, Reprise Records issued the previously-unreleased 1994 album, retitled ''1994''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2010/09/03/shawn-camps-shelved-1994-album-to-be-released/|title=Shawn Camp's shelved 1994 album to be released|last=Cooper|first=Peter|date=September 3, 2010|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=September 27, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, Camp won Album of the Year at the American Music Awards for his co production with [[Tamara Saviano]] of ''This One's for Him: A Tribute to Guy Clark''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://americanamusic.org/recipient-archive |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 6, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018055116/http://americanamusic.org/recipient-archive |archive-date=October 18, 2012 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Camp became the lead vocalist for [[The Earls of Leicester]] and he has been a session musician.\n\nIn January 2014, Camp won a Grammy Award for his production of [[Guy Clark]]'s album ''[[My Favorite Picture of You]]''.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/movie-news/grammy-awards-2014-the-complete-winners-list-186621/|title=Grammy Awards 2014: The Complete Winners List|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 27, 2014|access-date=January 22, 2020}}</ref> This was his second Grammy nomination for Best Folk Album of the Year, in December, 2012, he and co-producer Tamara Saviano, were nominated for ''This One's for Him: A Tribute to Guy Clark''.\n\nThe 2023 Grammy Awards presented the legendary Willie Nelson's \"A Beautiful Time\" with \"Country Album of The Year\". The title cut, along with album cut, \"We're Not Happy 'Til You're Not Happy\", were both penned by Camp.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Osborne_Brothers","to":"Osborne Brothers"}],"pages":{"9111487":{"pageid":9111487,"ns":0,"title":"Osborne Brothers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American bluegrass band}}\n{{For|the 2010s Maryland-based country music group|Brothers Osborne}}\n{{Distinguish|the Osmond Brothers}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name           = Osborne Brothers\n|image          = \n|caption        = \n|background     = group_or_band\n|origin         = [[Hyden, Kentucky]], U.S.\n|genre          = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]\n|years_active   = 1953\u20132005\n|label          = [[MGM Records|MGM]], [[Decca Records|Decca]], [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[CMH Records|CMH]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Pinecastle Records]]\n|associated_acts= [[Rocky Top X-Press]], [[The Strangers (American band)|The Strangers]]\n|website        = \n|past_members   = {{plainlist|\n* [[Bobby Osborne]]\n* [[Sonny Osborne]]\n}}\n}}\n\nThe '''Osborne Brothers''', [[Sonny Osborne|Sonny]] (October 29, 1937 \u2013 October 24, 2021) and [[Bobby Osborne|Bobby]] (December 7, 1931 \u2013 June 27, 2023), were an influential and popular [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] act during the 1960s and 1970s and until Sonny retired in 2005.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=300}}</ref> They are probably best known for their No.&nbsp;33 1967 country hit song, \"[[Rocky Top]]\", written by [[Felice and Boudleaux Bryant]] and named after a [[Tennessee]] location.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.topoquest.com/map.php?lat=35.56389&lon=-83.71389&datum=nad27&zoom=4|title=Rocky Top, NC - N35.56389\u00b0 W83.71389\u00b0|website=Topoquest.com|access-date=August 8, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nThe Osbornes were born in [[Roark, Kentucky]], on Jack's Creek, but they moved to [[Hyden, Kentucky|Hyden]], after their house burned down. They then moved near [[Dayton, Ohio]], where they grew up and performed as entertainers in southwestern Ohio.<ref name=t237>Tribe 2006, p.&nbsp;237.</ref> In 1952, during the [[Korean War]], Bobby was drafted and served in the [[United States Marine Corps]]. Sonny went to work with the \"Father of Bluegrass Music\" [[Bill Monroe]]. Following Bobby's discharge, the Osbornes teamed up with [[Jimmy Martin]], performing at radio stations WROL in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]] and [[WJR]] in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]].<ref name=t238>Tribe 2006, p.&nbsp;238.</ref><ref name=o2>Osborne 1964, p.&nbsp;2.</ref> At their only session together, on November 16, 1954, the Osbornes and Martin recorded six songs for RCA Victor.<ref>Booklet, Bear Family Records BCD 15705</ref> In late 1955, the Osbornes left Martin and moved to [[Wheeling, West Virginia]], where they performed on [[WWVA Jamboree]] until Christmas, together with Charlie Bailey.<ref name=r155>Rosenberg 2005, p.&nbsp;155.</ref> They returned to Dayton in early 1956 playing the local clubs with guitarist Enos Johnson. When Johnson left, the Osbornes added guitarist [[Red Allen (bluegrass)|Red Allen]] and fiddler Art Stamper to form a new group.\n\nThe Osborne Brothers and Red Allen (under the pseudonym Stanley Alpine) recorded for Gateway Records in February or March 1956 cutting eight instrumentals. In the spring of 1956, Tommy Sutton, a local disc jockey, helped the Osborne Brothers get a recording contract with [[MGM Records]].<ref name=g67>Goldsmith 2004, p.&nbsp;67.</ref> The new group, with the Osbornes on banjo and mandolin, Allen on guitar, Ernie Newton on bass, Tommy Jackson and Art Stamper on fiddles, made their MGM recording debut on July 1, 1956.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">Booklet, Bear Family Records BCD 15598</ref> Their first released 45 RPM single for MGM containing \"Ruby Are You Mad\" became a huge success and led to the Osbornes being signed on as regular members of the WWVA Jamboree in October 1956.<ref name=r155/><ref name=g68>Goldsmith 2004, p.&nbsp;68.</ref> The \"Jamboree version\" of the group comprised Ricky Russell on dobro, Johnny Dacus on fiddle and Ray Anderson on bass. \"Ruby Are You Mad\" marks the first time twin banjos were used on a bluegrass recording.<ref name=g68/> On October 17, 1957, at their third session for MGM, the Osbornes, always experimenting with their sound, added a dobro and drums, also for the first time on a bluegrass recording. In April 1958, Red Allen, who was the last musician to receive billing next to the Osborne Brothers, left the group.<ref name=g69>Goldsmith 2004, p.&nbsp;69.</ref>\n\nUpon their breaking into the bluegrass scene, the Osborne Brothers quickly became known for their virtuoso instrumentation and tight, melodic vocal harmonies. They first made the country chart in 1958 with \"Once More\", performing as a trio with [[Red Allen (bluegrass)|Red Allen]]. The song featured a novel inverted stacked harmony. Bobby sang the lead line highest, with Sonny singing baritone, and the third singer (Red Allen) singing tenor as the lowest part. This made Bobby's distinctive voice the lead, and the third voice was somewhat interchangeable. As a result, they could hire others guitarist and singers without changing the overall sound. The \"high lead\" vocal trio became their signature, and they used to great effect in the country market with songs like \"Blame Me\", \"Sweethearts Again\", and a remake of the Carter Family's \"Fair and Tender Ladies\".\n\nDuring the 1960s, the Osbornes caused minor controversy among Bluegrass music purists by incorporating electronic and percussion instruments in their live acts and studio work. In 1960 they became the first bluegrass group to play on a college campus, performing at Antioch College.<ref name=wd243>Wolff, Duane 2000, p.&nbsp;243.</ref> In 1963 they signed with [[Decca Records]].<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> On August 8, 1964, the Osborne Brothers were inducted as members of the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.opry.com/MeetTheOpry/Members.aspx?id=116|title=Grand Ole Opry: Members|website=Opry.com|access-date=August 8, 2021|archive-date=September 11, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911013352/http://www.opry.com/MeetTheOpry/Members.aspx?id=116|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nThe Osborne Brothers recorded their hit \u201cRocky Top\u201d in November 1967. Released on December 25, 1967, it sold 85,000 copies in only two weeks,<ref name=\"l30\">Ledgin (2004), p. 30</ref> and was named an official Tennessee [[List of U.S. state songs|state song]] in 1982.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tn.gov/main/article/state-songs |title=State Songs |publisher=Tennessee State Government |access-date=2017-12-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626114840/http://www.tn.gov/main/article/state-songs |archive-date=2015-06-26 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 1973 the Osborne Brothers became the first bluegrass group to perform at the White House.<ref name=l30/>\n\nIn 1994, The Osborne Brothers were inducted into the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]]'s Hall of Honor.\n\n==Hits==\nTheir song \"Ruby Are You Mad\" came in 1956 after signing with MGM Records (1956) and began a string of hits through 1986. Among them were \"Once More\" (1958), \"Up This Hill & Down\" (1965), \"Making Plans\" (1965), \"Rocky Top\" (1967), \"Tennessee Hound Dog\" (1969), and \"Midnight Flyer\" (1972). The Osborne Brothers' final chart appearance came in late 1986 with a new version of \"Rocky Top\".\n\n==Later years and deaths==\nBobby continued to perform with his band Rocky Top X-press, which includes two of his three sons. They performed May 31, 2013, at the rededication marking new ownership of The Gatlinburg Inn, where Boudleaux and Felice Bryant wrote \"Rocky Top,\" and the couple's sons, Dane and Del Bryant, were on hand. Bobby died in 2023.\n\nSonny retired in 2005 and died in 2021.\n\n==Notable band members==\n*Johnathan Smith, Organ/Keys\n*[[Red Allen (bluegrass)|Red Allen]], guitar\n*[[Benny Birchfield]], guitar/banjo\n*Paul Brewster, guitar\n*[[Jimmy D. Brock]], bass\n*[[Grady Martin]], guitar\n*[[Shawn Camp (musician)|Shawn Camp]], fiddle\n*[[Jimmy Campbell (bluegrass)|Jimmy Campbell]], fiddle\n*[[Shad Cobb]], fiddle\n*[[Donnie Collins]], guitar\n*[[David Crow (musician)|David Crow]], fiddle\n*[[Derek Deakins]], fiddle\n*[[Dennis Digby]], bass\n*[[Glen Duncan (bluegrass)|Glen Duncan]], fiddle\n*[[Boyce Edwards]], fiddle\n*Bill Edwards, guitar\n*[[The Grascals|Terry Eldredge]], bass/guitar\n*[[Harley Gabbard]], guitar\n*[[Tim Graves]], dobro\n*[[Tommy Jackson (musician)|Tommy Jackson]], fiddle\n*[[Ray Kirkland]], bass\n*[[Jimmy Martin]], guitar\n*[[The Grascals|Jimmy Mattingly]], fiddle\n*[[Daryl Mosley]], bass\n*[[Bobby Osborne, II]], guitar/bass\n*[[Robby Osborne]], guitar/bass/drums\n*[[Wynn Osborne]], banjo\n*[[Ronnie Reno]], guitar/bass\n*[[Dale Sledd]], guitar\n*[[The Grascals|Terry Smith]], bass\n*[[Buddy Spicher]], fiddle\n*[[Blaine Sprouse]], fiddle\n*[[Steve Thomas (bluegrass)|Steve Thomas]], fiddle\n*[[Gene Wooten]], dobro\n*[[Dana Cupp]], Guitar, Banjo\n*Tim Evans, bass\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Foggy_Mountain_Boys","to":"Foggy Mountain Boys"}],"pages":{"71731810":{"pageid":71731810,"ns":0,"title":"Foggy Mountain Boys","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[Flatt and Scruggs]]\n\n{{Redirect category shell|\n{{R from move}}\n{{R from subtopic}}\n{{R printworthy}}\n}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Harley_Allen","to":"Harley Allen"}],"pages":{"12827022":{"pageid":12827022,"ns":0,"title":"Harley Allen","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use American English|date=December 2022}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Harley Allen\n| image               =\n| caption             =\n| image_size          =\n| background          = non_performing_personnel\n| birth_name          = Harley Lee Allen\n| birth_date                = {{Birth date|1956|01|23}}\n|birth_place =[[Dayton, Ohio]], United States\n| death_date                = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|2011|03|30|1956|01|23}}\n|death_place =[[Brentwood, Tennessee]], United States\n| origin              =\n| instrument          = Guitar, [[mandolin]]\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = [[1970s in music|1970s]]&ndash;[[1990s in music|1990s]]\n| label               = [[Folkways Records|Folkways]], [[PolyGram Records|PolyGram]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]\n| Publishing Company  =\n| website                 =\n}}\n'''Harley Lee Allen''' (January 23, 1956{{spaced ndash}}March 30, 2011) was an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[Country music|country]] singer and songwriter.\n\n==Early life==\nAllen was born in [[Dayton, Ohio]], the son of [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] performer [[Red Allen (bluegrass)|Red Allen]].\n\n==Discography==\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Another River''\n| \n* Release date: November 5, 1996\n* Label: [[PolyGram Records]]\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! Album\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1996\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Old Love Dreamin'\"\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Another River''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Waving Girl\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Boy She Did\"\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love Ain't Supposed to Hurt\"\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 1996\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Boy She Did\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/harley-allen/385145/boy-she-did.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305101311/http://www.cmt.com/videos/harley-allen/385145/boy-she-did.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 5, 2016|title=CMT : Videos : Harley Allen : Boy She Did|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|access-date=January 16, 2012}}</ref>\n| Lynn Spinnato\n|}\n\n==Career==\nAllen appeared on several 1970s albums with his brothers as the '''Allen Brothers''': ''Allengrass'' (Lemco Records), ''Sweet Rumors'' (Rounder Records), ''Clara's Boys'' (Rounder Records), ''Are You Feeling It Too'' (Folkways Records), ''Red Allen Favorites'' (King Bluegrass Records). He recorded three [[solo album]]s, ''Across The Blueridge Mountains'' ([[Folkways Records|Folkways]], 1983), ''Another River'' ([[PolyGram Records|PolyGram]], 1996) and ''Live At The Bluebird'' (2001).\n\nHe was most known for providing background vocals on the song \"[[Man of Constant Sorrow|I Am a Man of Constant Sorrow]]\" from the [[O Brother, Where Art Thou? (soundtrack)|''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' soundtrack]].  He won two [[Grammy Award]]s for that recording in 2002, in the [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]] and [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] categories.\n\nAllen performed on two bluegrass tribute albums for the British rock band [[the Moody Blues]]: ''[[Moody Bluegrass]]: A Nashville Tribute to the Moody Blues'' (2004), and ''[[Moody Bluegrass]] TWO... Much Love'' (2011).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4247134 |title=Moody Bluegrass: Rocking Through the Hills |publisher=NPR |date=December 30, 2004 |access-date=August 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/moody-bluegrass-two%E2%80%A6much-love/ |title=Moody Bluegrass Two\u2026Much Love |publisher=bluegrasstoday.com |date=June 7, 2011 |access-date=August 25, 2015}}</ref> The latter album was released after Allen's death.\n\n==Personal life==\nAllen is survived by his three brothers, Ronnie, Greg and Mark Allen; his sister, Delores Allen; his wife, Debbie Nims; their two daughters, Katelyn and Maggie; and son, Aaron.<ref>[http://www.theboot.com/2011/03/31/harley-allen-dead/ Hit Songwriter Harley Allen Dies at 55]</ref>\n\n==Death==\nAllen died of lung cancer on March 30, 2011, at his home in [[Brentwood, Tennessee]].<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.cmt.com/news/75agz0/hit-country-songwriter-harley-allen-dead-at-55|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221128192319/https://www.cmt.com/news/75agz0/hit-country-songwriter-harley-allen-dead-at-55|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 28, 2022|title=Hit Country Songwriter Harley Allen Dead at 55|date=March 30, 2011|work=CMT|access-date=September 8, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Songs written==\nThe singles/songs written or co-written by Allen have been, among others, performed by:\n* [[Gary Allan]] (\"Bourbon Borderline\", \"The Devil's Candy\", \"I Just Got Back From Hell\", Learning To Live With Me\", \"[[Tough Little Boys]]\")\n* [[Dierks Bentley]] (\"My Last Name\")\n* [[Garth Brooks]] (\"Rollin'\")\n* [[Tracy Byrd]] (\"Cowgirl\")\n* [[John Conlee]] (\"Pass It On\", \"She's Mine\")\n* [[Billy Currington]] (\"[[Like My Dog]]\")\n* [[The Del McCoury Band]] (\"Keep Her While She's There\", \"Never Grow Up Boy\")\n* [[Joe Diffie]] (\"Something I Do For Me\")\n* [[Ty England]] (\"New Faces in the Field\")\n* [[Alan Jackson]] (\"Another Good Reason\", \"[[Between the Devil and Me]]\", \"Everything I Love\", \"I Slipped And Fell in Love\", \"I Still Love You\", \"Life Or Love\", \"Meat And Potato Man\", \"The Angels Cried\", \"Who I Am\")\n* [[George Jones]] (\"The Man He Was\")\n* [[Sammy Kershaw]] (\"For Years\")\n* [[Hal Ketchum]] (\"No Easy Road\")\n* [[Alison Krauss|Alison Krauss & Union Station]] (\"It Doesn't Matter\")\n* [[Jake Mathews]] (\"That's Why They Call It Cheatin'\")\n* [[Kathy Mattea]] (\"Live It\")\n* [[John Michael Montgomery]] (\"Cool\", \"December 1943\", \"I Wanna Be There\", \"[[The Little Girl]]\")\n* [[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]] (\"Paradise\")\n* [[Joe Nichols]] (\"[[I'll Wait for You (Joe Nichols song)|I'll Wait for You]]\", \"If Nobody Believed in You\")\n* [[Linda Ronstadt]] (\"High Sierra\")\n* Shannon Walker (\"That's Why God Made Me\", \"Mommy All The Time\", \"His Father's Son\", \"Before I Let You Go\", \"Walk Out of the Rain\")\n* [[Blake Shelton]] (\"[[The Baby (song)|The Baby]]\", \"The Bartender\", \"When Somebody Knows You That Well\")\n* [[Daryle Singletary]] (\"That's Why God Made Me\")\n* [[Ricky Skaggs]] (\"A Simple Life\", \"Spread A Little Love Around\")\n* [[Darden Smith]] (\"Seven Wonders\")\n* [[Josh Turner]] (\"I Had One One Time\")\n* [[Rhonda Vincent]] (\"In Your Loneliness\", \"When Love Arrives\")\n* [[Don Williams]] (\"Gulf Shore Line\")\n* [[Mark Wills]] (\"Still Waiting\")\n* [[Darryl Worley]] (\"[[Awful, Beautiful Life]]\", \"Spread A Little Love Around\")\n* [[Lonesome River Band]] (\"[[Stray Dogs & Alley Cats]]\")\n* [[Ronnie Bowman]] (\"[[Merry Christmas,Ho Ho Ho]]\")\n* [[Melonie Cannon]] (\"[[Nobody Hops A Train Anymore]]\")\n* The Allen Brothers (\"Wildwood Flower Blues\")\n* Britt Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"High_Valley","to":"High Valley"}],"pages":{"13367990":{"pageid":13367990,"ns":0,"title":"High Valley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country band}}\n{{for|the American Viticultural Area|High Valley AVA}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = High Valley\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| caption         = High Valley in 2022\n| alias           =\n| origin          = [[La Crete]], [[Alberta]], Canada\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]}}\n| years_active    = 1997\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Open Road Recordings|Open Road]]|[[Centricity Music|Centricity (US)]]|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]|[[Warner Music Nashville|Warner Nashville]]|Blue Chair|Cage Free}}\n| website         = {{official website|http://highvalleymusic.com/}}\n| current_members = Brad Rempel<br />Dave Myers<br />Raymond Klassen<br />Clint Milburn<br />Andrew Hemmerling\n| past_members    = Bryan Rempel<br />Curtis Rempel\n}}\n'''High Valley''' is a Canadian [[Country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] band originally from Blumenort, Alberta, a small community near the hamlet of [[La Crete]]. The group is composed of Brad Rempel (lead vocals) and his supporting band, Dave Myers (bass guitar), Raymond Klassen (Dobro), Clint Milburn (guitar), and Andrew Hemmerling (drums).<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2021/11/high-valley-reemerges-with-new-music-due-out-nov-12/ | title=High Valley Reemerges with New Music Due Out Nov. 12 | date=4 November 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countryschatter.com/2016/09/high-valley-know-how-to-turn-a-show-into-a-party/ | title=High Valley know how to turn a show into a party | date=13 September 2016 }}</ref> Brad Rempel's brother Bryan Rempel was a member until March 2014,<ref>{{cite news|last=Tinson|first=Kayla|title=Bryan Rempel leaving High Valley|url=http://topcountry.ca/bryan-rempel-leaving-high-valley/|access-date=March 12, 2014|newspaper=Top Country|date=March 10, 2014}}</ref> while younger brother Curtis Rempel was a member until June 2021.<ref>{{cite web|first=Katie|last=Colley|title=Curtis Rempel Announces Exit From Country Duo High Valley To Focus On New Business|url=https://etcanada.com/news/790741/curtis-rempel-announces-exit-from-country-duo-high-valley-to-focus-on-new-business/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210611154717/https://etcanada.com/news/790741/curtis-rempel-announces-exit-from-country-duo-high-valley-to-focus-on-new-business/|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 11, 2021|work=[[Entertainment Tonight Canada|ET Canada]]|date=June 11, 2021}}</ref> All three brothers grew up in a [[Mennonite]] community and graduated from La Crete Public School.<ref name=\"cmt\">[http://www.cmt.ca/Artist/HighValley High Valley] at [[CMT (Canada)|CMT]]</ref>\n\nAfter a number of chart successes in Canada between 2010 and 2015, High Valley were signed to [[Atlantic Records]] Nashville in October 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nicholson|first1=Jessica|title=High Valley Inks Deal With Atlantic Records/Warner Music Nashville|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2015/10/high-valley-inks-deal-with-atlantic-recordswarner-music-nashville/|access-date=October 9, 2015|work=[[MusicRow]]|date=October 8, 2015}}</ref> They achieved some success with the singles \"[[Make You Mine (High Valley song)|Make You Mine]]\" and \"[[She's with Me]]\" at [[United States]] country radio. They have three No.&nbsp;1 hits on the ''Billboard'' [[Canada Country]] chart with \"[[I Be U Be]]\", \"[[Grew Up On That]]\", and \"[[River's Still Running]]\".\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! ''[[MySpace]]''. January 21, 2007. Retrieved November 26, 2007.</ref> percussion\n| genre            = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 1989\u2013present\n| label            = [[Nonesuch Records]]<br>[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill Records]]\n| associated_acts  = [[Nickel Creek]], [[Sean Watkins]], [[Chris Thile]], [[Mutual Admiration Society (collaboration)|Mutual Admiration Society]], [[Works Progress Administration (musical group)|Works Progress Administration]], [[The Decemberists]], [[Dan Wilson (musician)|Dan Wilson]], [[I'm With Her (band)|I'm With Her]], [[Aoife O'Donovan]], [[Sarah Jarosz]], [[The Killers]], [[Jackson Browne]]\n| website          = [http://sarawatkins.com/ sarawatkins.com]\n| current_members  = \n| past_members     = \n}}\n\n'''Sara Ullrika Watkins''' (born June 8, 1981) is an American singer-songwriter and [[fiddle]]r. Watkins debuted in 1989 as the fiddler of [[Nickel Creek]], the [[progressive bluegrass]] group  she formed with her brother [[Sean Watkins|Sean]] and [[mandolin]]ist [[Chris Thile]]. In addition to singing and fiddling, Watkins also plays the [[ukulele]] and the guitar, and also played percussion while touring with [[the Decemberists]].  In 2012, she and her brother played with [[Jackson Browne]] during his \"I'll Do Anything\" acoustic tour.\n\nWith Nickel Creek, Watkins released five studio albums, one [[compilation album]], and seven [[single (music)|singles]]. During the band's seven-year hiatus, she released three solo albums: ''[[Sara Watkins (album)|Sara Watkins]]'' and ''[[Sun Midnight Sun]]'' on [[Nonesuch Records]] and ''[[Young in All the Wrong Ways]]'' on [[New West Records]].<ref name=\"nonesuch\">[http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-signs-sara-watkins-2008-11-25 \"Nonesuch Signs Sara Watkins\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200821224601/https://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-signs-sara-watkins-2008-11-25 |date=August 21, 2020 }}. [[Nonesuch Records]]. November 25, 2008. Retrieved November 29, 2008.</ref>\n\n==Biography==\n\n===1989\u20132007, 2014\u2013present: Nickel Creek===\n{{main|Nickel Creek}}\n\n===2007\u2013present: Solo career===\nIn late 2005, Watkins stated in a [[PopMatters]] interview when discussing her first solo-written recorded song, \"Anthony\", that she \"definitely [makes] the effort [to write more], but it's something that doesn't come too easy for me. Nor does it come really easy for the guys, I think they've just been doing it for a very long time.\"<ref name=\"popmatters\">Tranter, Nikki. [https://www.popmatters.com/music/interviews/nickel-creek-051118.shtml \"Understanding and Ability\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525042539/http://www.popmatters.com/music/interviews/nickel-creek-051118.shtml |date=May 25, 2011 }}. ''[[PopMatters]]''. November 18, 2005. Retrieved March 27, 2008.</ref>\n\n[[File:SaraWatkinsACL.jpg|thumb|left|Watkins performing at [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]] in 2009]]\nWatkins signed as a solo artist with [[Nonesuch Records]] in fall 2008<ref name=\"nonesuch\"/> and released her self-titled debut solo album on April 7, 2009. Watkins started recording the album in February 2008, and it was jointly recorded in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and Los Angeles.<ref name=\"endoftheroad\"/> ''Sara Watkins'' was produced by bassist [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] of [[Led Zeppelin]] fame, who first performed with Watkins on a [[Mutual Admiration Society (album)|Mutual Admiration Society]] tour in 2004.<ref name=\"endoftheroad\">Dickens, Tad. [http://www.roanoke.com/webmin/podcasts/end-of-the-road-for-nickel-creek/article_489db2a0-342d-573e-acd2-2d01dfa1db84.html \"End of the road for Nickel Creek?\"]. ''[[The Roanoke Times]]''. November 2, 2007. Retrieved March 1, 2008.</ref>\n\nWatkins toured the United States as an opening act in 2008.<ref name=\"endoftheroad\"/> She performed short tours as an opening act for singer-songwriter [[Tift Merritt]] along the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] in March and April<ref name=\"tiftmerritt\">[http://trianglemusic.blogspot.com/2008/01/nickel-creek-members-tours-stop-in-nc.html \"Nickel Creek members' tours stop in NC\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708071101/http://trianglemusic.blogspot.com/2008/01/nickel-creek-members-tours-stop-in-nc.html |date=July 8, 2011 }}. ''Triangle Music''. January 24, 2008. Retrieved March 1, 2008.</ref> and with [[Robert Earl Keen]] around [[New England]] in September,<ref name=\"northampton\"/> as well as doing a 17-date tour with [[Donavon Frankenreiter]] in October. On April 14, 2009, she appeared on ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'', with Jones on bass, [[Questlove]] of [[The Roots]] on drums, and her brother [[Sean Watkins]] on guitar. On August 28, 2011, she made her debut with ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]],'' at the [[Minnesota State Fair]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Hubbard |first=Rob |url=http://www.twincities.com/ci_15989751?nclick_check=1 |title='Prairie Home Companion' hits its stride at Fair |date=September 3, 2010 |publisher=TwinCities.com |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=August 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819083610/http://www.twincities.com/ci_15989751?nclick_check=1 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/2010/10/23/ |title=A Prairie Home Companion for October 23, 2010 &#124; American Public Media |publisher=Origin-prairiehome.publicradio.org |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=August 19, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084937/http://origin-prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/2010/10/23/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2012, she toured with [[Jackson Browne]] as the opening act for his acoustic winter tour.\n\nIn September 2011, Watkins indicated via Twitter that she would begin work on a second album in the fall of 2011. In May 2012, Watkins released her second solo album, ''[[Sun Midnight Sun]]'', again on [[Nonesuch Records]].<ref name=\"NonesuchRelease\">{{cite web|title=Sun Midnight Sun|date=March 14, 2012|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/albums/sun-midnight-sun|publisher=Nonesuch Records|access-date=June 5, 2013|archive-date=September 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927105600/http://www.nonesuch.com/albums/sun-midnight-sun|url-status=live}}</ref> Produced by former [[Simon Dawes]] guitarist [[Blake Mills]], it features guest appearances from [[Fiona Apple]] and Jackson Browne.<ref name=\"NonesuchRelease\" />\n\nIn 2016, Watkins won \"Instrumentalist of the Year\" at the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]].\n\n===Other projects===\n[[File:2014APHCstreetdanceSaraWatkins.jpg|thumb|right|Watkins performing at the season opening of ''A Prairie Home Companion'', 2014]]\nIn 2002, Watkins starred in an advertisement for cell phone provider [[Cingular Wireless]] alongside her former fiddle teacher Dennis Caplinger, as well as other prominent bluegrass artists.<ref name=\"cingular\">[http://www.wrightforyou.com/bgetc.html \"A Most Cingular Sensation\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010031149/http://www.wrightforyou.com/bgetc.html |date=October 10, 2007 }}. ''Wright For You''. June 2002. Retrieved June 21, 2008.</ref><ref name=\"johnmoore\">[http://www.wvfest.com/performers/showperformer.html?artid=430 \"Brad Davis, Tim May & John Moore\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090412171014/http://www.wvfest.com/performers/showperformer.html?artid=430 |date=April 12, 2009 }}.</ref> Between 2000 and 2004, Watkins and the other members of [[Nickel Creek]] ([[Chris Thile]] and [[Sean Watkins]]), [[Glen Phillips (singer)|Glen Phillips]], [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]], and [[Pete Thomas (drummer)|Pete Thomas]] collaborated on an EP, ''[[Mutual Admiration Society Solo Sampler]]''; an album, [[Mutual Admiration Society (album)|''Mutual Admiration Society'']] (recorded in 2000); and a brief tour.\n\nThe 2007 documentary film ''[[Arctic Tale]]'' featured a song by Watkins and musician [[Grant-Lee Phillips]], titled \"Song of the North (Beneath the Sun)\". Watkins lent her vocal talents to the film alongside other performers such as [[Aimee Mann]] and [[Brian Wilson]].<ref>[http://music.msn.com/album/?album=52045085&menu=credits{{Dead link|date=November 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} \"Arctic Tale [Original Soundtrack&#93;: Credits\"]. ''[[MSN]]''. Retrieved April 22, 2008.</ref>\n\nIn January 2008, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' reported a new [[Supergroup (music)|supergroup]] octet tentatively named [[The Scrolls]], later named Works Progress Administration (W.P.A.). The octet is composed of Watkins, her brother [[Sean Watkins]] (guitar), [[Glen Phillips (singer)|Glen Phillips]] (guitar, vocals), [[Benmont Tench]] (piano), Luke Bulla (fiddle), [[Greg Leisz]] (various), [[Pete Thomas (drummer)|Pete Thomas]] (drums), and [[Davey Faragher]] (bass). The group released their album ''WPA'' in September 2009.\n\nWatkins is featured on [[Needtobreathe]]'s 2009 CD ''[[The Outsiders (Needtobreathe album)|The Outsiders]]'' on the track \"Stones Under Rushing Water\".\n\nIn late January and early February 2010, Watkins undertook a short tour with [[Jerry Douglas]] and [[Aly Bain]] in Scotland and England under the \"[[Transatlantic Sessions]]\" banner, culminating in a performance in the [[Royal Festival Hall]] in London on February 6, 2010. In June 2010, Watkins appeared on the [[The Nerdist Podcast|Nerdist]] podcast as a musical guest, performing her best-known solo song, \"Long Hot Summer Days\" (a [[John Hartford]] cover). Later that summer, she participated in the Summer Love Tour with [[Garrison Keillor]] in venues across the United States.<ref>{{cite web |last=Finke |first=Nikki |url=https://www.deadline.com/2010/04/garrison-keillors-a-prairie-home-companion-skeds-summer-love-25-city-tour/ |title=Garrison Keillor's Prairie Home Companion Skeds \"Summer Love\" 25-City Tour |publisher=Deadline.com |date=April 14, 2010 |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=July 26, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726190050/http://www.deadline.com/2010/04/garrison-keillors-a-prairie-home-companion-skeds-summer-love-25-city-tour/ |url-status=live }}</ref> She guest hosted Keillor's show, ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'', on January 15, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prairiehome.publicradio.org/features/hodgepodge/2011/01/guest_host/index.shtml |title=January 15: Nickel Creek alum Sara Watkins; clawhammer banjo player Abigail Washburn; singer-songwriter Tom Brosseau |publisher=Prairiehome.publicradio.org |date=January 31, 2011 |access-date=May 6, 2015}}</ref> Watkins contributed fiddle, guitar, percussion, and vocals on [[The Decemberists]]' 2011 tour.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.decemberists.com/news/the-decemberists-news-1-4-10/ |title=News 1.4.10 |publisher=Thedecemberists.com |access-date=May 6, 2015 |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231905/http://www.decemberists.com/news/the-decemberists-news-1-4-10/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Also in 2011, she (and her brother Sean) began to perform as a musician and singer in the humor/retro-radio podcast \"[[Thrilling Adventure Hour]]\".\n\nWatkins played violin and sang on \"A Face To Call Home\" on [[John Mayer]]'s 2012 album ''[[Born and Raised (John Mayer album)|Born and Raised]]''. During 2012 and 2013, she toured with Jackson Browne, both as an opening act and accompanying him during the performance.\n\nWatkins and her brother Sean play regularly at the [[Largo (nightclub)|Largo]] nightclub in Los Angeles as \"[[Watkins Family Hour]]\". Keyboardist [[Benmont Tench]] (of [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]]) and bassist [[Sebastian Steinberg]] (formerly of Soul Coughing) are regular participants, and other guest musicians from the Largo family generally show up as well, including [[Jon Brion]], Fiona Apple, Don Heffington, [[Greg Leisz]], and former Nickel Creek bandmate [[Chris Thile]] when he is in town. The irregular collaborations led to a 2015 album and tour under the same name.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McCue|first1=Lori|title=Sean and Sara Watkins are taking their Watkins Family Hour on the road, and bringing famous friends|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/express/wp/2015/09/03/sean-and-sara-watkins-are-taking-their-watkins-family-hour-on-the-road-and-bringing-famous-friends/|access-date=July 14, 2016|newspaper=Washington Post|date=September 3, 2015|archive-date=August 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822083302/https://www.washingtonpost.com/express/wp/2015/09/03/sean-and-sara-watkins-are-taking-their-watkins-family-hour-on-the-road-and-bringing-famous-friends/|url-status=live}}</ref> Also in 2015, Watkins toured extensively with [[Sarah Jarosz]] and [[Aoife O'Donovan]] (of [[Crooked Still]] fame). The trio, who now play under the name [[I'm with Her (band)|I'm With Her]], hosted the radio show ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' on October 10, 2015. Watkins also performed vocals for \"June & Johnny\" on [[Jon Foreman]]'s 2015 EP ''[[The Wonderlands: Darkness]]''.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=SaraWatkins|author=Sara Watkins|number=634774137374941186|date=August 21, 2015|title=I sang with @jonforeman on his song June and Johnny \u2013 out today on @Spotify!! Link below. Thanks Jon! Check it out!}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/im-with-her-band-interview-bluegrass-music-aoife-odonovan-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz|title=I'm With Her: 'We're about camaraderie, not Hillary'|first=Emma|last=John|date=February 18, 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref>\n\nIn 2020, she played fiddle on [[Phoebe Bridgers]]'s record ''[[Punisher (Phoebe Bridgers album)|Punisher]]'', on track 10 \"Graceland Too\".\n\nIn 2021, she played fiddle on [[The Killers]]'s record ''[[Pressure Machine]]'' (Tracks: ''West Fields'', ''Cody'', ''Pressure Machine'') and violin on ''In Another Life''.\n\n===Personal life===\nOn August 16, 2008, Watkins married Todd Cooper in her parents' backyard in [[Vista, California|Vista]], California.<ref name=\"northampton\">[http://sarawatkins.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=72&Itemid=1 \"Sept \u2013 Northampton, MA\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716005146/http://sarawatkins.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=72&Itemid=1 |date=July 16, 2011 }}. Sarawatkins.com. September 2008. Retrieved September 16, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://glenphillips.net/blog/?p=70 \"Summer Is Almost Over...\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090412072047/http://glenphillips.net/blog/?p=70 |date=April 12, 2009 }}. Glenphillips.com. August 24, 2008. Retrieved August 30, 2008.</ref> On June 15, 2017, she announced via Twitter that she and her husband were expecting a child in September.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=SaraWatkins|author=Sara Watkins|number=875344896118468609|date=June 15, 2017|title=Well, it's about time to fess up and tell you all that in September, my husband and I are\u2026}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Solo career===\n\n====Studio albums====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! 1958)}}\n{{for|his eponymous album|Marty Stuart (album)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2024}} {{Use American English|date=May 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| background       = solo_singer\n| image book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|page=351|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://repertoire.bmi.com/Catalog.aspx?detail=writerid&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&keyid=332890&subid=0 | title=Search results for 'Stuart, John Marty' | publisher=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] | access-date=August 11, 2020}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1958|09|30}}\n| birth_place      = [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]], U.S.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/marty-stuart-mn0000378041/biography | title=Marty Stuart biography | publisher=[[AllMusic]] | access-date=August 11, 2020 | author=Steve Huey}}</ref>\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]}}\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|[[mandolin]]}}\n| years_active     = 1968\u2013present\n| label            = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[Universal South Records|Universal South]], Superlatone, [[Ridge Runner Records|Ridge Runner]]\n| spouse = {{plainlist|\n* {{marriage|[[Cindy Cash]]|1983|1988|end=div}}\n* {{marriage|[[Connie Smith]]|1997}}\n}}\n| current_member_of = The Fabulous Superlatives\n| past_member_of   = The Rock & Roll Cowboy Band\n| website          = {{URL|martystuart.net/}}\n}}\n\n'''John Marty Stuart''' (born September 30, 1958) is an American [[country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music]] singer, songwriter, and musician. Active since 1968, Stuart initially toured with [[Lester Flatt]], and then in [[Johnny Cash]]'s road band before beginning work as a solo artist in the early 1980s. He is known for his combination of [[rockabilly]], [[country rock]], and [[bluegrass music]] influences, his frequent collaborations and cover songs, and his distinctive stage dress.\n\nHis greatest commercial success came in the first half of the 1990s on [[MCA Records]] Nashville. Stuart has recorded over 20 studio albums, and has charted over 30 times on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. His highest chart entry is \"[[The Whiskey Ain't Workin']]\", a duet with [[Travis Tritt]]. \n\nStuart has won five [[Grammy Award]]s out of 16 nominations.  He is also a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] and [[Country Music Hall of Fame]].\n\n==Early life==\n{{external media | width = 210px | float = right | audio1 = [https://freshairarchive.org/segments/marty-stuart-keeper-country-musics-cowboy-couture-0 Marty Stuart: Keeper Of Country Music's Cowboy Couture], interviewed by [[Terry Gross]] on ''[[Fresh Air]]'', 51:08, October 1, 2014.<ref name=\"Fresh Air\">{{cite web | title =Marty Stuart: Keeper Of Country Music's Cowboy Couture | work = [[Fresh Air]] | publisher =[[WHYY-FM|WHYY]] ([[NPR]]) | date = October 1, 2014 | url =https://freshairarchive.org/segments/marty-stuart-keeper-country-musics-cowboy-couture-0 | access-date =September 15, 2019 }}</ref> }}\nJohn Marty Stuart was born in [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]], on September 30, 1958.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> \n\nStuart learned to play [[guitar]] and [[mandolin]] as a child, and by age 12, he had joined a gospel band called The Sullivans. While a member of this band, Stuart met mandolinist [[Roland White]], a member of [[Lester Flatt]]'s backing band; White invited Stuart to perform with Flatt at a concert in Delaware in 1972, which led to him becoming a regular member of that band. He continued to tour in this capacity until Flatt retired in 1978, and recorded an independent album called ''With a Little Help from My Friends'' that same year. After this, Stuart performed with [[Vassar Clements]] and [[Doc Watson]] before joining [[Johnny Cash]]'s band in 1980.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> \n\nIn 1982, he released a second album called ''Busy Bee Cafe'' on [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill Records]]. The album was composed of a [[jam session]] that included a number of country and bluegrass performers such as Cash, Watson, and [[Earl Scruggs]]. In 1985, Stuart accompanied Johnny Cash to Memphis and played on the ''Class of '55'' album that also featured [[Carl Perkins]], [[Roy Orbison]], and [[Jerry Lee Lewis]]. At the end of the session, Perkins presented Stuart with his guitar.<ref>Dickerson, James L., ''Goin' Back to Memphis: A Century of Blues, Rock 'n' Roll and Glorious Soul'', Schirmer Books, 1996, pg. 12</ref> Later that year, Stuart left Cash's band and landed a recording contract with [[Columbia Records]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Recording career==\nStuart released his [[Marty Stuart (album)|self-titled debut album]] on Columbia in 1985. The album accounted for Stuart's first chart entry on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts with his first single release, \"[[Arlene (song)|Arlene]]\".<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Three other singles charted from the album in 1986: \"Honky Tonker\" and \"All Because of You\", both written by [[Steve Forbert]], and Stuart's own \"Do You Really Want My Lovin'\". However, these songs were less successful on the charts.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> The success of \"Arlene\" helped Marty to receive a nomination by the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] for [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year|Top New Male Vocalist]], losing to [[Randy Travis]]. [[AllMusic]] writer Jim Worbois gave the album a mixed review, stating that it was \"Not a great album, but made somewhat more interesting by some of the people appearing on the record and the inclusion of two Steve Forbert songs.\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/marty-stuart-mw0000083078 | title=''Marty Stuart'' review | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=August 12, 2020 | author=Jim Worbois}}</ref> He recorded a second album for Columbia titled ''[[Let There Be Country]]'', which charted two singles in 1988: the [[Merle Haggard]] composition \"Mirrors Don't Lie\" and \"Matches\".<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Due to the underperformance of the singles, Columbia chose not to release the album, and Stuart exited the label to return to Mississippi.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n===1989-91: Beginning of MCA Records tenure===\nAfter briefly rejoining the Sullivans, he returned to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and signed with [[MCA Records]] in 1989.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> That label issued the album ''[[Hillbilly Rock]]'' that year. Co-produced by [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] and session guitarist [[Richard Bennett (guitarist)|Richard Bennett]], the album charted four singles on Hot Country Songs. First was a cover of Cash's \"[[Cry! Cry! Cry!]]\", followed by \"Don't Leave Her Lonely Too Long\", which Stuart wrote with [[Kostas (songwriter)|Kostas]]. While these were unsuccessful on the charts, the album's [[Hillbilly Rock (song)|title track]] (written by [[Paul Kennerley]]) became Stuart's first top-ten country hit in 1990.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> The album's final release was \"[[Western Girls (Marty Stuart song)|Western Girls]]\", which Stuart also co-wrote.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> ''Hillbilly Rock'' was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) in 1997 for shipments of 500,000 copies.<ref name=\"riaa\">{{cite web | url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=marty+stuart#search_section | title=Search results for Marty Stuart | publisher=Recording Industry Association of America | access-date=August 14, 2020}}</ref>\n\nHis second MCA album, ''[[Tempted (Marty Stuart album)|Tempted]]'', followed in 1991. The album charted four singles on Hot Country Songs between 1991 and 1992: \"[[Little Things (Marty Stuart song)|Little Things]]\", \"[[Till I Found You]]\", \"[[Tempted (Marty Stuart song)|Tempted]]\", and \"[[Burn Me Down (Marty Stuart song)|Burn Me Down]]\", of which all except \"Till I Found You\" reached the top ten.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Bennett and Brown stayed on as producers, with the former also contributing alongside Stuart on both guitar and mandolin. Kennerley and Kostas contributed as both songwriters and backing vocalists; also performing backing vocals on some tracks were Billy Thomas and [[Ray Herndon]], who were also recording on MCA in [[McBride & the Ride]] at the time.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Tempted |others=Marty Stuart |year=1991 |type=CD inssert |publisher=MCA Records |id=MCAD-10106}}</ref> Jana Pendragon of AllMusic gave the album four-and-a-half stars out of five, comparing it to [[Dwight Yoakam]]'s ''[[Hillbilly Deluxe (Dwight Yoakam album)|Hillbilly Deluxe]]'' in style and saying, \"Stuart kicks country-pop in its well-defined hindquarters[\u2026]But Stuart is just as deadly when he slows things down and does a ballad.\"<ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r123530|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Tempted'' review|last=Pendragon|first=Jana|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=August 12, 2020}}</ref>\n\nAlso in 1991, Stuart co-wrote a song with [[Travis Tritt]] called \"[[The Whiskey Ain't Workin']]\". Recorded on the latter's 1991 album ''[[It's All About to Change]]'', this song was released in between \"Tempted\" and \"Burn Me Down\". It would go on to become Stuart's highest chart entry, reaching number two on Hot Country Songs in early 1992.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> It also won Stuart his first [[Grammy Award]], for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]] that year.<ref name=\"grammy\">{{cite web | url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/marty-stuart/6414 | title=Search results for Marty Stuart | publisher=Grammy.com | access-date=August 11, 2020}}</ref> This song's success also led to the two touring in 1992 as the No Hats Tour, a reference to the fact that unlike most contemporary country musicians, neither Tritt nor Stuart sported a [[cowboy hat]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1991/11/29/no-hats-tour/ | title=The No Hats Tour -- Travis Tritt and Marty Stuart refuse to wear cowboy headgear | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=November 29, 1991 | access-date=August 14, 2020 | author=Ron Givens}}</ref>\n\n===1992-95: End of MCA tenure===\n[[File:Travis Tritt concert 1-18-2014.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Stuart is a frequent collaborator of [[Travis Tritt]], pictured here in 2014.]]\nHis next MCA album, ''[[This One's Gonna Hurt You]]'', came out in 1992. The lead single \"[[This One's Gonna Hurt You (For a Long, Long Time)]]\", also a duet with Tritt, was a top-ten hit in 1992, but the followup singles \"Now That's Country\", \"High on a Mountain Top\", and \"Hey Baby\" were less successful.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Kennerley and Cash were once again among the contributing vocalists, while [[Ashley Cleveland]] and [[Pam Tillis]] both sang backing vocals on \"High on a Mountain Top\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/this-ones-gonna-hurt-you-mw0000081284 | title=''This One's Gonna Hurt You'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=August 12, 2020 | author=Thom Jurek}}</ref> Johnny Cash provided duet vocals on \"Doin' My Time\", while the track \"Me and Hank and Jumpin' Jack Flash\" [[sampling (music)|sampled]] voice recordings of Lester Flatt, [[Hank Williams]], and [[Ernest Tubb]].<ref name=\"ew hurt\"/> [[Alanna Nash]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' rated the album \"A\", finding the \"stylistic mix\" superior to preceding albums, noting influences of [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Southern rock]], [[rockabilly]], and [[blues]] in his delivery and song choices.<ref name=\"ew hurt\">{{cite web | url=https://ew.com/article/1992/07/24/this-ones-gonna-hurt-you/ | title=''This One's Gonna Hurt You'' | publisher=Entertainment Weekly | date=July 24, 1992 | access-date=August 14, 2020 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref> Also in 1992, Columbia issued ''Let There Be Country''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> ''This One's Gonna Hurt You'' was certified gold by the RIAA in 1993.<ref name=\"riaa\"/> Stuart won his second Grammy Award in 1993, in the category of [[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance|Best Country Instrumental Performance]], as one of several featured artists on [[Asleep at the Wheel]]'s cover of \"[[Red Wing (song)|Red Wing]]\" on their 1993 album ''[[Tribute to the Music of Bob Wills and the Texas Playboys]]''.<ref name=\"grammy\"/>\n\n''[[Love and Luck (album)|Love and Luck]]'' was his next album, released in 1994.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Only one single, \"Kiss Me, I'm Gone\", made top 40 from the project.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Stuart co-produced the album with Brown, while also contributing on guitar, mandolin, and songwriting. The album's opening title track featured [[Vince Gill]], [[Ricky Skaggs]], and [[Harry Stinson (musician)|Harry Stinson]] on backing vocals.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Love and Luck |others=Marty Stuart |year=1994 |type=CD booklet |publisher=MCA Records |id=10880}}</ref> Also included were two covers: [[Billy Joe Shaver]]'s \"If I Give My Soul\" and [[The Flying Burrito Brothers]]' \"Wheels\", as well as the mandolin instrumental \"Marty Stuart Visits the Moon\". Daniel Gioffre of AllMusic highlighted these three tracks in particular as being among the strongest on the album.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/love-and-luck-mw0000111190 | title=''Love and Luck'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=August 14, 2020}}</ref> Nash rated the album \"B\", stating that \"As a singer, Marty Stuart has all the zip of unbuttered toast, and as a writer, too many of his songs float aimlessly...Yet Stuart has genuine love for the early country greats and injects his own work with such impassioned strains of old hillbilly styles, that he charms in spite of his limitations.\"<ref name=\"ew love\">{{cite web | url=https://ew.com/article/1994/03/18/love-and-luck/ | title=''Love and Luck'' review | publisher=Entertainment Weekly | date=March 18, 1994 | access-date=August 14, 2020 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref>\n\nFollowing this album, MCA issued a compilation called ''[[The Marty Party Hit Pack]]'' in 1995, which contained singles from his previous MCA albums, as well as \"The Whiskey Ain't Workin'\", the previously-unreleased \"The Likes of Me\" and \"If I Ain't Got You\", and two cover songs previously found on multi-artist tribute albums released in 1994. These were a rendition of [[Elvis Presley]]'s \"[[Don't Be Cruel]]\", featuring [[The Jordanaires]] and previously found on ''It's Now or Never: The Tribute to Elvis'', and [[The Band]]'s \"[[The Weight]]\", featuring [[The Staple Singers]] and previously found on ''[[Rhythm, Country and Blues]]''. Both of these cover songs were produced by [[Don Was]], while [[Don Cook]] handled production on the two new songs.<ref name=\"party\">{{Cite AV media notes |title=The Marty Party Hit Pack |others=Marty Stuart |year=1995 |type=CD booklet |publisher=MCA Nashville |id=MCAD-11204}}</ref> \"The Likes of Me\" was previously cut by [[Conway Twitty]] on his 1993 album ''[[Final Touches]]'', on which Cook was also a producer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/final-touches-mw0000101221|title=''Final Touches''|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=27 January 2016}}</ref> Both of these new songs issued as singles in 1995, but neither entered the country music top 40.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Jay Orr of ''New Country'' magazine criticized \"The Likes of Me\" and the two cover songs, but otherwise found the album a \"neat summation\" of Stuart's music.<ref name=orr>{{cite journal|last=Orr|first=Jay|date=April 1995|title=Album reviews: ''The Marty Party Hit Pack''|journal=New Country|volume=2|issue=5|pages=66|issn=1074-536X}}</ref> ''The Marty Party Hit Pack'' became Stuart's fourth and final gold album in 1998.<ref name=\"riaa\"/>\n\nStuart released ''[[Honky Tonkin's What I Do Best]]'' in 1996, which produced two more minor chart entries in [[Honky Tonkin's What I Do Best (song)|the title track]] (another duet with Tritt) and \"You Can't Stop Love\" that year.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> The title track also won Stuart a Vocal Event of the Year award from the [[Country Music Association]].<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Nash rated the album \"A\u2212\", finding an influence of [[The Beatles]] in \"Thanks to You\" and of [[Delta blues]] in \"The Mississippi Mudcat and Sister Sheryl Crow\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://ew.com/article/1996/07/12/honky-tonkins-what-i-do-best/ | title=''Honky Tonkin's What I Do Best'' | publisher=Entertainment Weekly | date=July 12, 1996 | access-date=August 14, 2020 | author=Alanna Nash}}</ref>\n\n==Career since the late 1990s==\nStuart released another album in 1999 called ''[[The Pilgrim (Marty Stuart album)|The Pilgrim]]''. It charted only one single that year with \"Red, Red Wine and Cheatin' Songs\".<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> A [[concept album]] based around a [[love triangle]], the album featured vocal contributions from Pam Tillis, [[George Jones]], and [[Emmylou Harris]], as well as a poem recited by Johnny Cash. An uncredited review of the album in AllMusic was largely favorable, stating that \"no one's idea of a commercial country album, one has to admire the sheer ambition of the project, as well as the guts it took MCA Records to release what amounts to a unique and deeply personal artistic vision.\"<ref name=\"allmusic pilgrim\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-pilgrim-mw0000239885 | title=''The Pilgrim'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=August 14, 2020}}</ref> After this album proved to be commercially unsuccessful, Stuart left MCA in 2000.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nHis next album was 2003's ''[[Country Music (Marty Stuart album)|Country Music]]'', released on [[Columbia Records]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> For this album, Stuart assembled a new backing band called Marty Stuart and His Fabulous Superlatives, consisting of Harry Stinson on drums, [[Kenny Vaughan]] on guitar, and Brian Glenn on bass guitar.<ref name=\"freep super\">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/361942751/ | title=Reviews | work=[[Detroit Free Press]] | date=July 6, 2003 | access-date=August 14, 2020}}</ref> Included on the albums were covers of [[Porter Wagoner]]'s \"[[A Satisfied Mind]]\", [[Carl Butler and Pearl]]'s \"Sundown in Nashville\",<ref name=\"freep super\"/> and Johnny Cash's \"Walls of a Prison\", as well as the [[Merle Haggard]] duet \"Farmer's Blues\".<ref name=\"jurek\"/> Two singles from the album both charted: \"If There Ain't, There Ought'a Be\" and \"Too Much Month (At the End of the Money)\".<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> Thom Jurek of AllMusic wrote that the album \"is relentless in both its attack and in the pleasure it provides to the listener. There are hot licks everywhere, with great songs, vocals, and a tapestry of moods, textures, and shades that serve to leave one impression: Stuart's radical experimentation of the last ten years has resulted in his finest moment thus far.\"<ref name=\"jurek\">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/country-music-mw0000036484 | title=''Country Music'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=August 14, 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, Stuart launched a custom record label, Superlatone Records, to issue overlooked Southern [[Gospel music|Gospel]] and Roots music recordings. Stuart released three critically acclaimed collections on Superlatone, ''Souls' Chapel'', ''Badlands'', and ''Live at the Ryman''. In October 2005, Stuart released a concept album, ''Badlands: Ballads of the Lakota'', which pays tribute to the [[Sioux]] culture in what is now [[South Dakota]].  In 2007, Stuart produced [[Porter Wagoner]]'s final album on the predominantly punk label [[Epitaph Records]].\n\n==The Fabulous Superlatives==\n[[File:Cousin_Kenny.jpg|thumb|right|The Fabulous Superlatives in 2022: from left to right Stuart, Vaughan, Stinson, Scruggs]]\nThe Fabulous Superlatives, Marty Stuart's band since 2002, includes him on guitar and mandolin, [[Kenny Vaughan]] on guitar, and [[Harry Stinson (musician)|Harry Stinson]] on drums, and from 2002 until 2008, Brian Glenn on bass. From 2008 until 2015, Paul Martin was on bass.  In 2015, [[Chris Scruggs]] replaced Paul Martin on bass, and also played [[steel guitar]].  Every member also sings.<ref name=KV-lexington-2012>{{cite news|last1=Tunis|first1=Walter|title=Country guitarist Kenny Vaughan steps out on his own |url=http://www.kentucky.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article44365353.html|work=Lexington Herald Reader|date=21 June 2012|access-date=27 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=fan-website>{{cite web|title=Marty Stuart Fan Page: The Band|url=http://www.martystuart.com/band-crew.htm |access-date=17 December 2017|publisher=Mattioli, Sherry}}</ref><ref name=HS-nodep-2005>{{cite web|url=http://nodepression.com/article/marty-stuart-party-may-come-end-road-goes-forever|title=Marty Stuart - The party may come to an end, but the road goes on forever|work=No Depression|access-date=October 13, 2017|author=Jon Weisberger|date=August 31, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930164100/http://nodepression.com/article/marty-stuart-party-may-come-end-road-goes-forever|archive-date=September 30, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Musical style==\nIn a 1992 article for ''Entertainment Weekly'', Kate Meyers wrote that Stuart \"considers himself more a stylist than a singer, meaning he gets by with a mix of approaches...rather than relying on a fantastic voice of his own\", citing Johnny Cash, [[Bill Monroe]], and [[Muddy Waters]] as his main musical influences.<ref name=\"meyers\">{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1992/09/18/road-marty-stuart/ | title=On the road with Marty Stuart | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=September 18, 1992 | access-date=August 14, 2020 | author=Kate Meyers}}</ref> Stuart's musical image in the 1990s was also defined by his distinct clothing and hairstyle. Meyers described him as having a \"striking black mane, speckled with well-earned gray...[o]ften tied in a black or pink [[bandana]] headband\", faded jeans from [[Levi Strauss & Co.]], a black T-shirt, [[cowboy boots]], a [[concho belt]], and a [[rhinestone]]-studded suit jacket designed by [[Nudie Cohn]] (sometimes termed the \"Nudie suit\").<ref name=\"meyers\"/>\n\n==Equipment and memorabilia==\nStuart is known for his extensive collection of country music memorabilia. Some of his collection was exhibited at the [[Tennessee State Museum]] in 2007 as \"Sparkle & Twang: Marty Stuart's American Musical Odyssey.\" The  exhibit later appeared at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, Ohio, and at the Arkansas Statehouse Museum.  In early 2018, Stuart co-curated, along with the [[Grammy Museum]], an exhibit at the [[Woody Guthrie Center]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], entitled \"Marty Stuart's Way Out West: A Country Music Odyssey\". The exhibit highlighted the West Coast impact on country music, featuring items by artists including Johnny Cash, [[Merle Haggard]], [[Buck Owens]], and Stuart himself. Many of the items in the exhibit came from the private collection of Stuart, including the last portrait of Cash (taken by Stuart four days before Cash died).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/scene/music/marty-stuart-launches-way-out-west-exhibit-at-woody-guthrie/article_3f6a0138-8fb6-59f8-ab44-0eb4365f4183.html|title=Marty Stuart launches 'Way Out West' exhibit at Woody Guthrie Center|first=Jimmie Tramel Tulsa|last=World|date=24 January 2018 }}</ref>\n\n[[Image:WIKI MARTY STUART 2.jpg|thumb|right|Marty Stuart, January 1993, with [[Clarence White]]'s [[B-Bender]] guitar]]\n\nYvonne and Mavis Staples of [[the Staple Singers]] gave one of their father \"Pops\" Staples' guitars to Marty Stuart after Pop's death.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4822820 |title=Marty Stuart Rediscovers Gospel in 'Souls' Chapel'|website=NPR.org |access-date=2013-05-23}}</ref> Mavis Staples explained, \"My father was Marty's godfather. My sisters and I took him in as our brother. He's the only one that I've heard who -- when he's playing guitar, he sounds like Pop. He can play just like him.\"<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Dauphin|first1=Chuck|title=Mavis Staples Talks Las Vegas Shooting & Reasserting Herself As a Voice for Change|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7997590/mavis-staples-las-vegas-civil-rights-interview|access-date=12 October 2017|magazine=Billboard|date=12 October 2017|ref=Staples in Billboard}}</ref>\n\nStuart's guitars also include 'Clarence', the familiar two-tone [[Fender Telecaster]], once owned by [[Clarence White]]. This instrument<ref>{{cite web|last1=Russell|first1=Rusty|title=\"Clarence\" The Granddaddy of Bender Guitars |url=http://www.martystuart.com/zArt-VintageGuitar4-04.htm|website=Marty Stuart Fan Page |access-date=31 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kuhn|first1=Thomas Eric|title=Telecaster - \"Going electric\"|url=http://www.burritobrother.com/gear.htm|website=The Country Boys |access-date=31 January 2016}}</ref> is the original [[B-Bender]] guitar, built and designed by White and [[Gene Parsons]] around 1967, to allow the guitarist to manually raise the guitar's 'B' string one whole step to play in a style similar to a [[pedal steel guitar]]. Stuart bought this unique guitar in 1980 from White's widow,<ref>{{cite web|last1=di Perna|first1=Alan|title=How Marty Stuart Is Keeping Country Music's Rich Tradition Alive|url=http://www.guitaraficionado.com/how-marty-stuart-is-keeping-country-musics-rich-tradition-alive.html|website=Guitar Aficionado|publisher=NewBay Media, LLC|access-date=31 January 2016}}</ref> and continued to play it in concert, as of 2019.\n\n==''The Marty Stuart Show''==\nStuart is host of ''The Marty Stuart Show'', which features traditional country music in the vein of ''[[The Porter Wagoner Show]]'', ''[[Flatt & Scruggs]]'', the ''[[Wilburn Brothers]] Show'', and ''[[Hee Haw]]''. ''The Marty Stuart Show'' began airing at 8:00&nbsp;pm on November 1, 2008, on cable's [[RFD-TV]].  Although no new episodes have been produced as of 2022, the network continues to air old episodes of the show under the name ''The Best of the Marty Stuart Show''.<ref name=\"O\u2019Dell2017\">{{cite web |author1=Cary O\u2019Dell |title=Now Playing at the Packard Campus Theater (May 4-6, 2017) {{!}} Now See Hear! |url=https://blogs.loc.gov/now-see-hear/2017/05/now-playing-at-the-packard-campus-theater-may-4-6-2017/https://blogs.loc.gov/now-see-hear/2017/05/now-playing-at-the-packard-campus-theater-may-4-6-2017/ |website=blogs.loc.gov |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200204025101/https://blogs.loc.gov/now-see-hear/2017/05/now-playing-at-the-packard-campus-theater-may-4-6-2017/ |archive-date=February 4, 2020 |date=1 May 2017 |access-date=March 14, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nEach episode features music by Stuart and his band the Fabulous Superlatives. Stuart hosts and produces the 30-minute episodes, with [[WSM (AM)|WSM]] disc jockey and Grand Ole Opry announcer [[Eddie Stubbs]] serving as the show's emcee.\n\n==Country Music Foundation==\nStuart is a member of the board of the [[Country Music Foundation]] and is a past president. Stuart has also been a [[List of Grand Ole Opry Members|member]] of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] since 1992.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> On August 12, 2020, Stuart was selected to be inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/08/12/hank-williams-jr-marty-stuart-dean-dillon-country-music-hall-fame/3352839001/|title=Hank Williams Jr., Marty Stuart, Dean Dillon to enter the Country Music Hall of Fame|first=Matthew Leimkuehler and Dave|last=Paulson|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=May 7, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nStuart's first wife was Johnny Cash's daughter [[Cindy Cash|Cindy]], to whom he was married from 1983 to 1988.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> \n\nSince July 8, 1997, Stuart has been married to country artist [[Connie Smith]], whom he had admired since his childhood.<ref name=\"WOCMSCS\">{{cite news |last1=Campbell |first1=Courtney |title=Marty Stuart and Connie Smith: A Love Story Years in the Making |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/marty-stuart-connie-smith-love-story/ |access-date=11 October 2019 |publisher=Wide Open Country}}</ref> Stuart described encountering Smith many years earlier, after attending her concert: \"I met Connie when I was 12 years old. She came to the [[Indian reservation]] in my hometown of [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]], to work at a fair. She hasn't changed a bit. She looked great then and she looks great now.\"<ref>{{cite web|title=Spirits Of Marty Stuart And Connie Smith Finally Unite (first appeared in a printing of ''Country Weekly'' in 1997) |url=http://www.martystuart.com/zart-cw-8-12-97.htm|publisher=Marty Stuart.com|access-date=August 16, 2010}}</ref> Stuart said he told his mother then that he was going to marry Connie Smith. Smith explains how they have sustained their marriage : \"Make the Lord the center ... and commit.\"<ref>{{cite web |last=Gallagher|first=Pat|title=Connie Smith and Marty Stuart Offer Marriage Tips|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/07/08/connie-smith-marty-stuart |publisher=The Boot|website=TheBoot.com|date=July 8, 2010|access-date=August 16, 2010}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Marty Stuart discography}}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!Year\n!width=\"250\"|Association\n!width=\"350\"|Category\n!width=\"350\"|Nominated work\n!width=\"65\"|Result\n|-\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=1|1985\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=1|[[Academy of Country Music]]\n| align=\"center\"| Top New Male Vocalist\n| align=\"center\"| Marty Stuart\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=1|1990\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=1|[[Country Music Association]]\n| align=\"center\"| Video of the Year\n| align=\"center\"| \"[[Hillbilly Rock (song)|Hillbilly Rock]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=1|1991\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=2| Academy of Country Music\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=2| Top Vocal Duet\n| align=\"center\" rowspan=2| Marty Stuart and
