This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Billy_Strings","to":"Billy Strings"}],"pages":{"56208163":{"pageid":56208163,"ns":0,"title":"Billy Strings","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American bluegrass musician (born 1992)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Billy Strings\n| image             = Billy Strings Taken By Christopher Morley.jpg\n| alt               = \n| caption           = Strings in 2023\n| alias             = \n| birth_name        = William Lee Apostol\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1992|10|03}}\n| birth_place       = [[Lansing, Michigan]], U.S.\n| occupation         = {{flatlist|\n*Singer\n*songwriter\n*musician\n}}\n| spouse            = Ally Apostol (m. 2023)\n| origin            = \n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]|[[progressive bluegrass]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[roots rock]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[jam band]]|[[psychedelic music|psychedelia]]}}\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|banjo}}\n| years_active      = 2013\u2013present\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]|[[Reprise Records|Reprise]]}}\n| website           = https://www.billystrings.com\n| associated_acts   = {{flatlist|\n*[[Don Julin]]\n*[[Billy Failing]]\n*[[Royal Masat]]\n*[[Jarrod Walker]]\n*[[John Mailander]]\n*[[Brad Tucker]]\n*[[Drew Mautlich]]\n*[[Molly Tuttle]]\n*[[Sierra Ferrell]]\n*[[Brendino Schlongergan]]\n*[[Lindsay Lou]]\n*[[Green Shirt Guy]]\n*[[Billy and the Kids]]\n*[[B\u00e9la Fleck]]\n*[[Jonah Calvo]]\n| website         = {{oweb|http://www.billystrings.com}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Billy Strings''' (born '''William Lee Apostol''', October 3, 1992) is an American guitarist and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] musician.<ref name=\"rolling stone\">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-august-2017-w496530/billy-strings-w496534|title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: August 2017|magazine=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=August 8, 2017|access-date=January 31, 2018}}</ref> His album [[Home (Billy Strings album)|''Home'']] won the [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]] in 2021.\n\n==Early life==\nBilly Strings was born William Lee Apostol on October 3, 1992, in [[Lansing, Michigan]]. His father died of a heroin overdose when he was two and his mother remarried Terry Barber, an accomplished amateur bluegrass musician whom Strings regards as his father. The family later moved to [[Morehead, Kentucky]], and then to [[Muir, Michigan]]. While he was still a preteen, his parents became addicted to methamphetamine. He left the family home at the age of 13 and went through a period of hard drug usage. His family eventually achieved sobriety; Billy stopped using hard drugs and drinking alcohol, becoming [[California sober|\"California sober\"]] and consuming only cannabis and similar \"light drugs\" (ie psychedelics).<ref name=\"RollingStoneJune2022\">{{cite news |last1=Hudak |first1=Joseph |title=Drugs, Bluegrass, and Bass Fishing: How Billy Strings Outran His Past and Infiltrated the Mainstream |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/billy-strings-bluegrass-fishing-concert-1369241/ |access-date=25 August 2022 |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=June 22, 2022}}</ref><ref name=\"northernexpress.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.northernexpress.com/news/feature/article-5963-the-amazing-billy-strings/|title=The Amazing Billy Strings|publisher=Northern Express}}</ref> \n\nBarber was a heavy influence on his stepson, introducing him to traditional bluegrass artists at a young age,<ref name=\"rolling stone\"/> including [[Doc Watson]], [[Del McCoury]], [[David Grisman]],<ref name=\"Live for Live Music billy-strings\">{{cite web|url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/features/billy-strings-garcia-grisman/|title=Watch Billy Strings Crush Garcia & Grisman's \"Dreadful Wind & Rain\"|website=liveforlivemusic.com|date=March 23, 2018}}</ref> [[Bill Monroe]], [[John Hartford]], [[Ralph Stanley]], [[Earl Scruggs]] and [[Larry Sparks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midwesterngentleman.com/music/keep-stringin-the-billy-strings-interview/|title=Midwestern Gentleman - Keep Stringin': The Billy Strings Interview|date=December 8, 2019 |publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wglt.org/post/billy-strings-just-beginning-already-wild-ride#stream/0|title=Billy Strings: Just Beginning An Already Wild Ride|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=November 7, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519173408/http://http/|archive-date=May 19, 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> Strings is also a [[Rock music|rock]] and [[Heavy metal music|metal]] fan, influenced by [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Johnny Winter]], [[Widespread Panic]], [[Phish]], the [[Grateful Dead]], [[Def Leppard]], [[Between the Buried and Me]] and [[Black Sabbath]], and played in hard rock and indie rock bands in his teens.<ref name=\"northernexpress.com\"/><ref name=\"The Bluegrass Situation\">{{cite web|url=https://thebluegrasssituation.com/read/jumping-into-the-deep-end-a-conversation-with-billy-strings|title=JUMPING INTO THE DEEP END: A CONVERSATION WITH BILLY STRINGS|date=October 18, 2017 |publisher=The Bluegrass Situation}}</ref>\n\nApostol got his stage name, Billy Strings, from his aunt, who saw his ability on multiple traditional bluegrass instruments.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://greenvillejournal.com/2017/05/04/billy-strings-fascinatingly-unpredictable-performer/ |title=Billy Strings Is A Fascinatingly Unpredictable Performer|date=May 4, 2017 |publisher=Greenville Journal}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n\n=== Beginnings and ''Turmoil'' & ''Tinfoil'' (2012-2019) ===\n[[File:111219 RelixPressDayNYC BillyStrings JFaatzMedia-2910.jpg|left|thumb|300x300px|Billy Strings in 2019]]\nIn 2012, Don Julin, a mandolin player from [[Traverse City, Michigan]], and author of ''Mandolin for Dummies'', asked Strings to join him on a paying gig. The partnership lasted for the next four years. \n\n''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' named Strings one of the Top Ten New Country Artists to Know in 2017.<ref name=\"rolling stone\" /> On February 12, 2018, ''Rolling Stone'' published an article titled \"Bluegrass Prodigy Billy Strings Plots 2018 Spring Tour\", saying: \"Billy Strings doesn't have any trouble living up to his name. [He is] one of the latest breakneck guitar pickers to emerge in the bluegrass world.\"<ref name=\"Rolling Stone 2\">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/bluegrass-prodigy-billy-strings-plots-2018-spring-tour-w516633/|title=Bluegrass Prodigy Billy Strings Plots 2018 Spring Tour|magazine=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=February 12, 2018 }}</ref> The [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] awarded him with the Momentum Instrumentalist of the Year award in 2016.<ref name=\"crossovertouring.com\">{{cite web |url=http://crossovertouring.com/billy-strings/|title=Crossover Touring|website=crossovertouring.com}}</ref> ''Bluegrass Situation'' named him a scene tastemaker in 2016.<ref name=\"crossovertouring.com\"/> Lisa Snedeker of ''[[HuffPost]]'' proclaimed ''Turmoil & Tinfoil'' as one of the best albums of 2017, writing: \"In September it charted at No. 3 on the Billboard Bluegrass charts. 'Nuff said.\"<ref name=\"huffingtonpost.com\">{{cite web |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/year-in-review-favorite-musical-picks-for-2017_us_5a49b486e4b0d86c803c7835/|title=Year in Review: Favorite musical picks for 2017|date=January 2018 |publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref> In March 2018, ''Rolling Stone'' released Strings' debut music video for his song \"Dealing Despair\" from his album ''Turmoil & Tinfoil''.<ref name=\"rollingstone\">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/billy-strings-dealing-despair-see-intense-new-video-w517819/|title=See Bluegrass Shredder Billy Strings Call Out Violent Culture in 'Dealing Despair' Video |date=March 13, 2018 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]}}</ref> He planned to play over 200 shows in 2018.<ref name=\"Daily Progress\">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyprogress.com/steeped-in-versatility-billy-strings-keeps-returning-to-his-bluegrass/article_5abb6646-4e32-11e8-a8d8-1fa4895a60c8.html/|title=Steeped in versatility, Billy Strings Keeps Returning to His Bluegrass Roots|date=May 2, 2018 |publisher=Daily Progress}}</ref>\n\nHe has been invited to play on stage with artists including [[Phish]], [[Dierks Bentley]],<ref name=\"WMOT Roots Radio\">{{cite web|url=http://wmot.org/post/wmot-fundraiser-evening-dierks-bentley#stream/0|title=WMOT Fundraiser: An Evening with Dierks Bentley|website=wmot.org|date=March 6, 2018 }}</ref> [[Del McCoury]], [[Bill Kreutzmann]], [[Bob Weir]], [[David Grisman]], [[Larry Keel]], [[Sam Bush]],<ref name=\"Jambands.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.jambands.com/news/2018/01/21/greensky-bluegrass-collaborate-with-sam-bush-and-billy-strings-in-nashville|title=Greensky Bluegrass Collaborate with Sam Bush and Billy Strings in Nashville|website=Jambands.com|date=January 21, 2018 }}</ref> [[The Marcus King Band]],<ref name=\"JamBase\">{{cite web|url=https://www.jambase.com/article/marcus-king-billy-strings-team-kings-strings-set-rooster-walk|title=Marcus King & Billy Strings To Team For 'King & Strings' Set At Rooster Walk|publisher=Jambase.com}}</ref> [[Greensky Bluegrass]], [[The Infamous Stringdusters]],<ref name=\"Live for Live Music aiken-bluegrass\">{{cite web |url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/features/aiken-bluegrass-festival-2017/|title=The Infamous Stringdusters, Fruition, & More To Bring The Pickin' To Aiken Bluegrass Festival |website=liveforlivemusic.com|date=April 13, 2017 }}</ref> [[The String Cheese Incident]], [[Leftover Salmon]], [[Widespread Panic]], [[Tool (band)|Tool]], and more. He has performed at festivals including Frankfort Bluegrass Festival (Frankfort, IL), Hookahville, Blue Ox, Pickathon, [[Merlefest]], DelFest, [[High Sierra Music Festival]], [[Lollapalooza]], [[Grey Fox Bluegrass Festival]], [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]], John Hartford Memorial Festival,<ref>{{cite web|title = John Hartford Memorial Festival - Previous Lineup History| url = https://hartfordfest.com/previous-lineup-history| website = hartfordfest.com| access-date = June 2, 2018 }}</ref> Aiken Bluegrass Festival, [[Appaloosa Music Festival]], [[Wheatland Music Festival]], Red Wing Roots Music Festival, Bristol Rhythm & Roots, Rooster Walk, French Broad River Festival, Makers Trail Festival, Under the Big Sky Festival and the All Good Presents 4848 Festival. At Grey Fox, he served as their very first artist in residence in 2017 and 2018.<ref name=\"Delfest\">{{cite web|url=https://www.Delfest.com/lineup/|title=Lineup|website=delfest.com|date=November 15, 2021 }}</ref><ref name=\"Grey Fox Bluegrass Festival\">{{cite web|url=https://greyfoxbluegrass.com/festival/2018-lineup/|title=2018 Lineup|website=greyfoxbluegrass.com}}</ref> Strings has appeared on famous [[PBS]] musical TV programs ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' and ''[[Bluegrass Underground]]''.<ref name=\"NY Post\">{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2018/03/21/cave-concert-venue-gives-new-meaning-to-underground-music-scene/|title=Cave Concert Venue Gives New Meaning to Underground Music Scene|date=March 21, 2018 |publisher=NY Post}}</ref> He has toured with [[Greensky Bluegrass]], [[The Infamous Stringdusters]], [[Leftover Salmon]], {{proper name|[[I'm With Her (band)|I'm With Her]]}}, Cabinet and others.<ref name=\"crossovertouring.com\"/><ref name=\"jambase.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.jambase.com/article/greensky-bluegrass-billy-strings-take-manhattan-recap-photos-videos/|title=Greensky Bluegrass & Billy Strings Take Manhattan|publisher=Jambase}}</ref> Of those bands he played with early in his career, he has cited Greensky Bluegrass specifically as a major influence and his \"favorite band.\"<ref name=\"Marquee Magazine\">{{cite web|url=http://marqueemag.com/2018/02/billy-strings/|title=Billy Strings breaks away from his mentor and is set to take his new band to the 'stratosphere'| date=February 1, 2018 | publisher=Marquee Magazine}}</ref>\n[[File:Billy Strings by Jesse Faatz 2023.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Billy Strings in 2023]]\nIn February 2017, Strings was named one of the six new rising stars of bluegrass by [[Acoustic Guitar (magazine)|''Acoustic Guitar'']].<ref name=\"Acoustic Guitar\">{{cite web|url=http://acousticguitar.com/next-gen-pickers-6-rising-stars-are-carrying-on-the-bluegrass-tradition-by-making-it-their-own/|title=Next-Gen Pickers: 6 Rising Stars are Carrying on the Bluegrass Tradition by Making It Their Own|date=February 16, 2017 |publisher=Acoustic Guitar}}</ref> He also collaborated with [[Molly Tuttle]] on the songs \"Sittin' on Top of the World\" and \"Billy in the Lowground\".\n\n[[File:Strings-fls.jpg|Strings at Bristol Rhythm and Roots Festival, 2017|left|thumb]]\nIn March 2018, [[PBS]] announced that Strings was to be the inaugural performer at the new cave for the renowned series ''[[Bluegrass Underground]]'' in the caverns of [[Pelham, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"The Tennessean\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/03/23/bluegrass-undergrounds-new-home-caverns/432558002/|title=First Look: Bluegrass Underground's New Home The Caverns|publisher=The Tennessean}}</ref><ref name=\"The Grundy County Herald\">{{cite web|url=http://www.grundycountyherald.com/music-and-magic-in-the-pelham-valley/|title=Music and Magic in the Pelham Valley|date=October 6, 2023 |publisher=The Grundy County Herald}}</ref>\n\n=== ''Home'' and ''Renewal'' (2019-2021) ===\nIn January 2019, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' wrote an article titled \"Why Guitarist Billy Strings Is the Bluegrass Star You Don't Want to Miss.\"<ref name=\"Rolling Stone 3\">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/billy-strings-bluegrass-must-see-774144/|title=Why Guitarist Billy Strings Is the Bluegrass Star You Don't Want to Miss|date=January 2, 2019 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]}}</ref> He was signed to [[Rounder Records]] in June 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/billy-strings-to-rounder-records/ |title=Billy Strings to Rounder Records |date= June 25, 2019 |first= John |last=Lawless |work= Bluegrass Today}}</ref> Strings released his album ''[[Home (Billy Strings album)|Home]]'' (produced and engineered by Glenn Brown) under the label on September 27, 2019.<ref name=woodward /> It became his most successful release yet, reaching No. 1 on the [[Heatseekers Albums]] and [[Bluegrass Albums]] charts, as well as debuting at No. 11 on the [[Emerging Artists]] Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/chart-beat/8532537/billy-strings-no-11-emerging-artists-chart |title=Billy Strings, Dayseeker and Temples Debut On Emerging Artists Chart |date=October 9, 2019 |first= Xander|last= Zellne |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> On September 26, 2019, Billy Strings was voted the International Bluegrass Music Association Guitar Player of the Year in Raleigh, North Carolina.\n\nHis album ''Home'' won the [[Grammy]] for Best Bluegrass Album at the [[63rd Annual Grammy Awards]].\n\nIn 2021, he joined [[Bill Kreutzmann]]'s [[Billy & the Kids]] for a number of shows, along with James Casey (saxophone).\n\nAs a solo artist, he was part of the [[Newport Folk Festival]] in July 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Newport Folk Festival stage schedule 2021 |url=https://newportfolk.org/2021-schedule/ |access-date=September 21, 2021 |publisher=Newport Folk}}</ref> On September 24, 2021, he released his third studio album, ''[[Renewal (Billy Strings album)|Renewal]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/BillyStrings/status/1420957420990435333|title=New album #RENEWAL out September 24. Preorder now}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/09/25/1040669089/grammy-winning-bluegrass-artist-billy-strings-has-a-new-album|title=Grammy Winning Bluegrass Artist Billy Strings Has A New Album|website=NPR.org |access-date=September 28, 2021}}</ref>\n\n===''Me/And/Dad'' (2022-present)===\n\nBilly Strings' touring band was expanded from a quartet to a five piece when frequent guest fiddler Alex Hargreaves was asked to become a permanent member during a show in Baltimore on July 3, 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jambase.com/article/billy-strings-alex-hargreaves-band-member|title=Billy Strings Makes Alex Hargreaves Official Band Member|website=Jambase.com |access-date=September 21, 2023}}</ref> The band consists of Billy Failing (banjo), Royal Masat (bass), Jarrod Walker (mandolin) and Alex Hargreaves (fiddle).\n\nAt the 2022 [[International Bluegrass Music Awards]], Strings was nominated for six awards, winning Entertainer of the Year for the second consecutive year, while \"Red Daisy\" won Song of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/awards/2022-ibma-bluegrass-music-awards-winners-list-1235148100/|title=Billy Strings, B\u00e9la Fleck, Dolly Parton Win Big at 2022 IBMA Bluegrass Music Awards: Winners List|last=Grein|first=Paul|date=September 30, 2022|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 5, 2022}}</ref>\n\nOn October 3, 2022, Strings announced the album ''Me/And/Dad'', a project with his father Terry Barber.<ref name=\"me/and/dad\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/billy-strings-me-and-dad-new-album-1234604449/|title=Billy Strings Picks and Sings With His Father on New Album 'Me/And/Dad'|date=October 3, 2022|last=Freeman|first=Jon|magazine=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=October 5, 2022}}</ref> While Barber is not his biological father, Strings said about Barber, \"Terry raised me and taught me how to wipe my ass, tie my shoes, and play guitar. That's my fucking dad.\"<ref name=\"me/and/dad\" />\n\nThe album, released in November 2022, is a collection of traditional, country and bluegrass music from [[George Jones]], [[Doc Watson]], [[Hank Thompson (musician)|Hank Thompson]], [[A.P. Carter]] and others. The same day the album was announced, \"Long Journey Home\" / \"[[Life to Go]]\" was released as a two-song single. Barber takes the lead vocal on the Jones-written song \"Life to Go.\"<ref name=\"me/and/dad\" />\n\n==Discography==\n{{Infobox artist discography\n| Artist       = Billy Strings\n| Image        = \n| Caption      = \n| Studio       = 3\n| Live         = 1\n| Compilation  = \n| Music videos = 10\n| EP           = 2\n| Singles      = 10\n| Option name  = As featured artist\n| Option       = 7\n| 1Option name = Collaboration albums\n| 1Option      = 3\n| 2Option name = Other appearances\n| 2Option      = 4\n}}\n\n===Albums===\n====Studio albums====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Life to Go\"<br/> {{small|(with Terry Barber)}}<ref name=\"me/and/dad\" />\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"California Sober\"<br/> {{small|(featuring [[Willie Nelson]])}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/billy-strings-willie-nelson-california-sober-collaboration-birthday-1235597716/|title=Billy Strings and Willie Nelson Commit to Going 'California Sober' in Duet Released for Willie's Birthday|last=Willman|first=Chris|date=April 27, 2023|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=June 12, 2023}}</ref>\n| 2023\n| {{Non-album single}}\n|}\n\n====As featured artist====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Slippery Eel\"\n| rowspan=3| 2021\n| [[B\u00e9la Fleck]]<br /> {{small|(featuring [[Chris Thile]] and Billy Strings)}}\n| rowspan=3| ''[[My Bluegrass Heart]]''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"This Old Road\"\n| B\u00e9la Fleck<br /> {{small|(featuring [[David Grisman]] and Billy Strings)}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"M-E-X-I-C-O\"<br />\n| 2024\n| [[Post Malone]]<br /> {{small|(featuring Billy Strings)}}\n| ''[[F-1 Trillion]]''\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\n{{Infobox musician awards\n| name = Billy Strings\n| image =\n| image_size =\n| alt =\n| caption =\n| wins = 9\n| nominations = 26\n| award1 = [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]]\n| award1W = 2\n| award1N = 4\n| award2 = [[Grammy Awards]]\n| award2W = 1\n| award2N = 6\n| award3 = [[International Bluegrass Music Awards]]\n| award3W = 6\n| award3N = 16\n}}\n\n=== Americana Music Awards ===\nThe [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]] are awarded annually by the [[Americana Music Association]] to honor the best in Americana and American roots music. Strings has received two wins from four nominations.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://americanamusic.org/awards | title=Awards }}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|2020\n|Emerging Artist of the Year\n|rowspan=4|Billy Strings\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|[[2021 Americana Music Honors & Awards|2021]]\n|rowspan=3|Artist of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|[[2022 Americana Music Honors & Awards|2022]]\n|{{Won}}\n|-\n|[[2023 Americana Music Honors & Awards|2023]]\n|{{Won}}\n{{end}}\n\n=== Grammy Awards ===\nThe [[Grammy Awards]] are awarded annually by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]. Strings has one win from six nominations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Billy Strings|url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/billy-strings/287520|website=Recording Academy Grammy Awards|access-date=5 February 2024}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[63rd Grammy Awards|2021]]\n|rowspan=2|[[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album|Best Bluegrass Album]]\n|''[[Home (Billy Strings album)|Home]]''\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2|[[64th Annual Grammy Awards|2022]]\n|''[[Renewal (Billy Strings album)|Renewal]]''\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"|[[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Performance|Best American Roots Performance]]\n|\"[[Renewal (Billy Strings album)|Love and Regret]]\"\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|rowspan=3|[[66th Annual Grammy Awards|2024]]\n|\"California Sober\" <br />{{small|(featuring [[Willie Nelson]])}}\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album|Best Bluegrass Album]]\n|''Me/And/Dad''\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance|Best Country Duo/Group Performance]]\n|\"High Note\" <br />{{small|([[Dierks Bentley]] featuring Billy Strings)}}\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n=== International Bluegrass Music Awards ===\nThe [[International Bluegrass Music Awards]] are awarded annually by the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] to honor the best in bluegrass. Strings has won seven<ref>{{Cite web |title=Awards |url=https://americanamusic.org/awards |access-date=2023-10-24 |website=AmericanaMusic.org |language=en}}</ref> awards from 16 nominations.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://thebluegrasssituation.com/read/ibma-awards-2019-see-the-winners/ | title=IBMA Awards 2019: See the Winners | date=September 27, 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://thebluegrasssituation.com/read/ibma-awards-2021-see-the-full-list-of-winners/ | title=IBMA Awards 2021: See the Full List of Winners | date=October 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/marty-raybon-back-to-bluegrass-signs-with-billy-blue-records-2/ | title=2022 IBMA Bluegrass Music Awards nominees announced | date=July 26, 2022 }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2|2019\n|New Artist of the Year\n|rowspan=4|Billy Strings\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2|Guitar Player of the Year\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=4|2020\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|Entertainer of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|Album of the Year\n|''[[Home (Billy Strings album)|Home]]''\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|Instrumental Recording of the Year\n|\"[[Home (Billy Strings album)|Guitar Peace]]\"\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|rowspan=3|2021\n|Guitar Player of the Year\n|rowspan=6|Billy Strings\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|Instrumental Group of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2|Entertainer of the Year\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=6|2022\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|Guitar Player of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|Instrumental Group of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|Album of the Year\n|''[[Renewal (Billy Strings album)|Renewal]]''\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|Song of the Year\n|\"[[Renewal (Billy Strings album)|Red Daisy]]\"\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|Instrumental Recording of the Year\n|\"[[Renewal (Billy Strings album)|Ice Bridges]]\"\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|2023\n|Entertainer of the Year\n|Billy Strings\n|{{won}}\n{{end}}\n\n== References ==\n<!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. -->\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[https://www.billystrings.com/ Official website]\n* {{imdb name|9787365}}\n* {{discogs artist|Billy Strings}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Strings, Billy}}\n[[Category:Musicians from Michigan]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Lansing, Michigan]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:1992 births]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:Rounder Records artists]]\n[[Category:Reprise Records artists]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass musicians]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Michigan]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Donna_Ulisse","to":"Donna Ulisse"}],"pages":{"23585665":{"pageid":23585665,"ns":0,"title":"Donna Ulisse","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image        =\n| name         = Donna Ulisse\n| origin       = [[Hampton, Virginia]], U.S.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|page=374|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}}</ref>\n| genre        = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation   = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active = 1991\u2013present\n| label        = [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]<br>Hadley Music Group, [[Mountain Home Records|Mountain Home]]\n}}\n\n'''Donna Ulisse''' is an American [[country music]] and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer-songwriter. Signed to [[Atlantic Records]] in 1991, she released her debut album, ''Trouble at the Door'', that year and two singles which charted on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart. She appeared on national TV shows ''[[Hee Haw]]'', ''[[Nashville Now]]'', ''[[Crook & Chase]]'', and NBC's ''[[Hot Country Nights]]''.\n\nUlisse's debut album ''Trouble at the Door'' charted the singles \"Things Are Mostly Fine\" and \"When Was the Last Time\".<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> The former received a positive review in ''[[Cash Box]]'' magazine which stated that she \"generates a soothing ballad quilted with a powerful force of emotion and inspiration\".<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Cash-Box/90s/1990/CB-1990-12-08.pdf | title=Reviews | journal=Cash Box | pages=22 | date=December 8, 1990}}</ref>\n\nAfter leaving Atlantic Records in the early 1990\u2019s, Ulisse took some time off and concentrated on song writing, however she did make some appearances. She returned in 2007, this time recording bluegrass music, with a new album ''When I Look Back'' on Hadley Music Group. Ulisse toured with her band The Poor Mountain Boys performing at festivals and concert venues. From 2007-2015, she released nine albums with Hadley Music Group. \n\nShe won the award for 2016 [[International Bluegrass Music Association]]\u2019s Songwriter of the Year and in 2017 she won International Bluegrass Music Association's song of the Year with \"I Am A Drifter\", co-written with Marc Rossi. Ulisse landed SPBGMA's Songwriter of the Year in the same year. In 2017, she signed with Mountain Home Music Company, and released her eleventh album ''Breakin' Easy'', later that year, produced by [[Doyle Lawson]].\n\nIn 2019, Ulisse signed with a new bluegrass label, Billy Blue Records, and released an album, ''Time For Love'', on November 1, 2019.\n\nUlisse released her second album and her thirteenth album overall, ''Livin' Large'', for Billy Blue Records on February 25, 2022.\n\nUlisse released her third album with Billy Blue Records, ''Mountain Lily'', on February 23, 2024.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Things Are Mostly Fine\"\n| 75\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Trouble at the Door''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"When Was the Last Time\"\n| 66\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Trouble at the Door\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Trouble with You\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Walk This Mountain Down''\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Director\n|-\n| 1991\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Things Are Mostly Fine\"\n| Richard Jernigan\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Trouble At The Door\"\n| Thom Oliphant\n|-\n| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"When I Go All Bluegrass On You\"\n| \n|-\n| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Livin' Large In A Little Town\"\n| \n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* {{Official website|http://www.donnaulisse.com/}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Ulisse, Donna}}\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Atlantic Records artists]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Hampton, Virginia]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Virginia]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Virginia]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Grandpa_Jones","to":"Grandpa Jones"}],"pages":{"1802420":{"pageid":1802420,"ns":0,"title":"Grandpa Jones","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Musical artist (1913\u20131998)}}\n{{Other people|Louis Jones}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Grandpa Jones\n| image            = Louis 'Grandpa' Jones.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Louis Marshall Jones\n| alias            = Grandpa Jones\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1913|10|20}}\n| birth_place      = [[Niagara, Kentucky]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{nowrap|{{Death date and age|mf=yes|1998|02|19|1913|10|20}}}}\n| death_place      = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Akron, Ohio]], U.S.\n| instrument       = {{hlist|[[Banjo]]|acoustic guitar}}\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]|[[gospel music|gospel]]|[[Old-time music|old-time]]}}\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Singer-songwriter|musician}}\n| years_active     = 1932\u20131998\n| label            = {{hlist|[[RCA Victor]]|[[King Records (United States)|King Records]]|[[Monument Records|Monument]]}}\n| associated_acts  = {{hlist|''[[Hee Haw]]''|[[Minnie Pearl]]|[[David \"Stringbean\" Akeman]]|[[Bradley Kincaid]]}}\n| module           = {{Infobox military person\n| embed = yes\n| allegiance = {{flag|United States}}\n| branch = {{flag|United States Army}}\n|battles = [[World War II]]\n| serviceyears = 1941\u20131945}}\n}}\n\n'''Louis Marshall Jones''' (October 20, 1913 \u2013 February 19, 1998), known professionally as '''Grandpa Jones''', was an American [[banjo]] player and [[Old-time music|old time]]/[[country music|country]] music singer. He was inducted as a member of the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1978.<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\">McCall, Michael; Rumble, John; Kingsbury, Paul, eds. (1 February 2012). The Encyclopedia of Country Music (Second ed.). Oxford University Press. pp. 269\u2013270. {{ISBN|9780195395631}}.</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nJones was born in the small farming community of [[Niagara, Kentucky|Niagara]] in [[Henderson County, Kentucky]], the youngest of 10 children in a sharecropper's family.<ref>{{cite news|title=Banjo Player Grandpa Jones, 'Hee Haw' Regular, Dies|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1998/02/21/banjo-player-grandpa-jones-hee-haw-regular-dies/98efa0e7-4896-423d-822c-263106e94168/|access-date=8 January 2018|newspaper=Washington Post|date=21 February 1998}}</ref> His father was an [[Old time fiddle|old-time fiddle]] player, and his mother was a ballad singer and herself adept on the [[concertina]].<ref name=\":0\" /> His first instrument was guitar.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite book|title=Country Music USA|last=Malone/ Laird|first=Bill C./ Tracey E.|publisher=University of Texas Press|year=1968|isbn=978-1-4773-1535-4|page=257}}</ref> Ramona Riggins, one of several women who began to gain some recognition in a musical form long dominated by men<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\"Bluegrass\">{{Cite journal|last=Green|first=Douglas B.|date=July 1979|title=Grandpa Jones|journal=Bluegrass Unlimited|pages=17\u201321}}</ref> was Grandpa's wife and musical partner of over thirty years.<ref name=\":5\">Jones, Grandpa (1939). Family Album [Phonograph]. [https://archives.etsu.edu/repositories/2/resources/755 Leon McIntyre Collection, 1970\u20132011]. Archives of Appalachia, East Tennessee State University. Johnson City, TN.</ref> Ramona first started playing the mandolin when she was six or seven years old.<ref name=\":5\" /> Jones spent his teenage years in [[Akron, Ohio]], where he began singing country music tunes on a radio show on WJW. In 1931, Jones joined the Pine Ridge String Band, which provided the musical accompaniment for the ''[[Lum and Abner]]'' show. By 1935 his pursuit of a musical career took him to [[WBZ (AM)|WBZ]] radio in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], where he met musician/songwriter [[Bradley Kincaid]], who gave him the nickname \"Grandpa Jones\" when he was 22 years old, because of his off-stage grumpiness at early-morning radio shows. Jones liked the name and decided to create a stage persona based around it. Later in life, he lived in [[Mountain View, Arkansas]]. In the 1940s he met rising country radio star [[Cousin Emmy]], from whom he learned to play the [[banjo]].\n\n==Career==\nPerforming as Grandpa Jones, he played the guitar or [[banjo]], [[yodeling|yodeled]], and sang mostly old-time [[ballad]]s. By 1937, Jones had made his way to West Virginia, where [[Cousin Emmy]] taught Jones the art of the [[clawhammer]] style of [[banjo]] playing, which gave a rough backwoods flavor to his performances.<ref name=\"Wadey\">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/obituary-grandpa-jones-1147179.html|title=Obituary: Grandpa Jones|last1=Wadey|first1=Paul|date=27 February 1998|access-date=9 January 2018|publisher=Independent}}</ref>  First experience playing music in public came at the age of 11 or thereabouts The music of the WLS Barn Dance in Chicago was a major influence on Louis, as were the [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] records his sister brought home. <!--He won a contest which is featured as singer and host in 1929, \"I won fifty dollars in ten dollar gold pieces, and of course I went right out and brought a better guitar!\" Wonder Hall, \u201cThe Red Headed Music Maker\u201d (famous for \u201cIt Ain\u2019t gonna Rain No More\u201d The winning songs were \u201cGoing Back To Texas\u201d and \u201c My Dear Old Southern Home.\u201d ???? This bit is evidently mangled and makes little sense. Comment back in once it has been clarified.--> In 1942, Jones joined [[WLW]] in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]. It was there that he met fellow Kentuckian [[Merle Travis]]. In 1943, they made their recording debuts together for [[Syd Nathan]]'s upstart [[King Records (United States)|King Records]].<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\" /> Jones was making records under his own name for King by 1944 and had his first hit with \"It's Raining Here This Morning.\"\n\nHis recording career was put on hold when he enlisted in the United States Army during [[World War II]]. Discharged in 1946, he recorded again for King. Through 1946\u20131949, when he and several Opry cast members ([[Clyde Moody]] and [[Chubby Wise]] among them) were invited to become a part of the burgeoning world of television by Washington D.C. entrepreneur Connie B Gay, he became a cast member at the Old Dominion Barn Dance, broadcast over WRVA in Richmond, Virginia.<ref name=\"Bluegrass\"/> In March 1946, he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and started performing on the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. He married Ramona Riggins on October 14, 1946. As an accomplished performer herself, she would take part in his performances. Jones' vaudeville humor was a bridge to television. His more famous songs include \"T For Texas,\" \"Are You From Dixie,\" \"Night Train To Memphis,\" \"[[Good Old Mountain Dew|Mountain Dew]],\" and \"Eight More Miles To Louisville.\"\n\nIn the fall of 1968,<ref name=\"Bluegrass\"/> Jones became a charter cast member on the long-running television show ''[[Hee Haw]]'', often responding to the show's skits with his trademark phrase \"Outrageous.\" He also played banjo, by himself or with banjo player [[David \"Stringbean\" Akeman]]. A musical segment featured in the early years had Jones and \"his lovely wife Ramona\" singing while ringing bells held in their hands and strapped to their ankles. A favorite skit had off-camera cast members ask, \"Hey Grandpa, what's for supper?\" in which he would describe a delicious, country-style meal, often in a rhyming, [[talking blues]] style. Sometimes he would describe something not so good; i.e. \"Because you were bad, thawed out [[TV dinner]]s!\"\n\n==Testimony==\nA resident of rural [[Ridgetop, Tennessee]], outside Nashville, he was a neighbor and friend of fellow musician [[David \"Stringbean\" Akeman]]. On the morning of November 11, 1973, Jones discovered the bodies of Akeman and his wife, Estelle, who had been murdered during the night by robbers.<ref>Cooper, Peter (15 October 2014). \"1973 killings brought fear to Nashville\". The Tennessean. Retrieved 10 January 2018.</ref> Jones testified at the trial of the killers; his testimony helped to secure a conviction.<ref>''Brown v. State'', unpublished decision at 1991 WL 242928.</ref>\n\n==Honors==\nIn 1978, Jones was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame. His autobiography ''Everybody's Grandpa: Fifty Years Behind the Mike'' was published in 1984.<ref name=\":3\">Jones, Louis M. with Charles K. Wolfe. (1984). ''Everybody's Grandpa: Fifty Years Behind the Mike''. Knoxville: University of Tennessee Press.<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref> In 2023, Jones was inducted into the [[American Banjo Museum Hall of Fame members|American Banjo Museum Hall of Fame]] in the Historical category.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-01-13 |title=Pickin\u2019 and a Grinnin\u2019: American Banjo Museum announces 2023 Hall of Fame inductees |url=https://kfor.com/news/local/pickin-and-a-grinnin-american-banjo-museum-announces-2023-hall-of-fame-inductees/ |access-date=2024-06-21 |website=KFOR.com Oklahoma City |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Death==\n[[File:Grandpa Jones gravestone.jpg|thumb|Jones's gravestone in Goodlettsville, Tennessee]]\nIn January 1998, Jones suffered two strokes after his second show performance at the Grand Ole Opry. He died at 7&nbsp;p.m. Central Time on February 19, 1998, at the McKendree Village Home Health Center in Hermitage, Tennessee at age 84. He was buried in the Luton Memorial Methodist Church cemetery in Goodlettsville, Tennessee.<ref>[http://www.hendersonkyhistory.com/GJonesObit.htm Profile], hendersonkyhistory.com; accessed November 22, 2015.</ref>\n\n==Discography==\nJones recorded for several labels, including [[RCA Victor]], [[King Records (United States)|King Records]] and [[Monument Records|Monument]].\n*''Grandpa Jones Sings His Greatest Hits'' (1954)<ref name=\":0\">Colin Larkin The Virgin Encyclopedia of Country Music Virgin, 1998</ref>\n* ''Country Music Hall of Fame Series'' (1992) MCA\n*''Grandpa Jones & The Brown's Ferry Four 16 Sacred Gospel Songs'', [[King Records (United States)|King Records]]\n*''Grandpa Jones Yodeling Hits'' (1963) Monument\n*''Grandpa Jones Remembers the Brown's Ferry Four''  (1966) Monument\n*''Grandpa Jones Live'' (1970) Monument<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Grandpa-Jones-Live/release/7356596|title=Grandpa Jones \u2013 Live (1970, Vinyl)|access-date=August 7, 2021|website=Discogs.com|date=December 3, 1970 }}</ref>\n\n==Singles==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rhonda_Vincent","to":"Rhonda Vincent"}],"pages":{"2026220":{"pageid":2026220,"ns":0,"title":"Rhonda Vincent","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{BLP refimprove|date=November 2023}}\n{{Short description|American bluegrass singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name            = Rhonda Vincent\n|image           = Rhonda w Mandolin.jpg\n|caption         = Rhonda Vincent on stage\n|background      = solo_singer\n|birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1962|7|13}}\n|origin          = [[Greentop, Missouri]], U.S.\n|instrument      = {{hlist|Vocals|[[mandolin]]|guitar|[[fiddle]]}}\n|genre           = {{hlist|[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]}}\n|occupation      = {{hlist|Musician|songwriter}}\n|years_active    = 1970\u2013present\n|label           = {{hlist|[[Rebel Records|Rebel]]|[[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant]]|[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]|Upper Management Music}}\n|current_member_of = Rhonda Vincent & The Rage\n|website         = {{Official website|Rhondavincent.com}}\n|spouse          = {{marriage|Herb Sandker|December 24, 1983}}\n}}\n\n'''Rhonda Lea Vincent''' (born July 13, 1962) is an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/artist.jhtml|title=CMT.com : Rhonda Vincent : Artist Main|date=April 6, 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406132753/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/artist.jhtml |archive-date=April 6, 2004 }}</ref> \n\nVincent's music career began when she was a child in her family's band The Sally Mountain Show, and it has spanned more than four decades. Vincent first achieved success in the bluegrass genre in the 1970s and 1980s, earning the respect of her mostly male peers for her mastery of the progressive chord structures and multi-range, fast-paced vocals intrinsic to bluegrass music. In media, Vincent has been dubbed the \"[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Queen of Bluegrass]]\" by several sources.<ref name='old-bio'>{{cite web | url = http://www.kvmo.net/~rhondav/rhondavincentbio.html | title = Biography | access-date = January 15, 2012 | publisher = Rhonda Vincent | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120207113834/http://www.kvmo.net/~rhondav/rhondavincentbio.html | archive-date = February 7, 2012 | url-status = dead }}</ref> Vincent is an in-demand guest vocalist for other bluegrass and country music performers, appearing on recordings by [[Dolly Parton]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Tanya Tucker]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Faith Hill]] and other notables.<ref name=\"Rhonda Vincent fact sheet\">{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:4rOkOJ4ILPUJ:www.kvmo.net/~rhondav/2010RVFactSheet.doc+&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShmgW6Btg4gqkiIk5fNpLu0o7pvfpaVgJ2fDU_XKU94-zgsvZ6ogu8yWV617OE1zZaZfVRy25UEqXdd8Tp4cCMzNDxvk4WApwkd_9HQFJMNYwGu_Sqzx1TUlU_uJ6bsco8WcLjS&sig=AHIEtbSmvsCkQUnyahzKBQl1Yhg367XmsQ&pli=1|title=Rhonda Vincent fact sheet|access-date=June 20, 2012}}</ref>\n\nVincent is an eight-time [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nominee, winning the [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/winners-nominees/122 |title=Awards Winners & Nominees Best Bluegrass Album |website=Grammy.com |access-date=March 10, 2020}}</ref> In 2020, she was inducted as a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theboot.com/rhonda-vincent-grand-ole-opry-membership/ |title=WATCH: Rhonda Vincent Invited to Join the Grand Ole Opry |website=Theboot.com |date=February 29, 2020 |access-date=March 10, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Early years==\nVincent was born in [[Kirksville, Missouri]], on July 13, 1962, and raised in nearby [[Greentop, Missouri]]. She is the oldest of three children, and the only daughter of Johnny and Carolyn Vincent. Her brother Darrin is a member of the  Award-winning bluegrass group [[Dailey & Vincent]]. Her youngest brother Brian played with the family group, but is now a top executive with the Bimeda Corporation. A fifth-generation musician, Rhonda's musical career started at age five when she sang gospel songs with her family's band, which was later known as the \"Sally Mountain Show\".<ref>Craig Morrison, \"Vincent, Rhonda\" in Kristin N Burns, ed. ''Women and Music in America since 1900: an Encyclopedia''. Westport, Ct .& London: Greenwood. 2002 {{ISBN|978-1573563093}} vol.2 p. 661</ref> Her father bought her a [[snare drum]] for her sixth birthday. At age eight, Vincent started playing [[mandolin]]. She later added [[fiddle]] to her list of instruments at 12. In an interview with ''Ingrams'' magazine, she said, \"Dad used to pick me up after school, and Grandpa would come over and we played until after dinner almost every night. There wasn\u2019t a lot going on in Greentop, but it was always hopping at the Vincent house.\"<ref name=\"Boone\">{{cite web|last=Boone|first=Dennis|url=http://www.ingramsonline.com/Apr_2012/50Missourians/Missouriansnew13.php|title=50 Missourians you should know|publisher=Ingrams magazine. Volume 38, No.&nbsp;4|date=April 2012|access-date=June 21, 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512231421/http://www.ingramsonline.com/Apr_2012/50Missourians/Missouriansnew13.php|archive-date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> Vincent recorded her first single, a version of \"[[Mule Skinner Blues]]\", in 1970. The family, including the younger brothers when they were old enough to play instruments, traveled and performed extensively across the [[Midwest]] in the 1970s and early 1980s. Except for living in [[Texas]] for a short time in 1974, and two summers (1977, 1978) spent employed as musicians at [[Silver Dollar City]] in [[Branson, Missouri]], the Vincent family used the Greentop area as home base.<ref>Janie Shriver & Jennie Higgins, ''It's a Family Affair''. Published in ''[[The Chariton Collector]]'' magazine, Spring 1982. Pg. 30\u201331</ref> The Vincent children all attended [[Schuyler County, Missouri|Schuyler County R-1]] schools, and following high school Vincent later attended [[Truman State University|Northeast Missouri State University]], majoring in accounting.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}\n\n==Solo career==\nVincent\u2019s life of music evolved into a successful career in bluegrass music after being discovered by Grand Ole Opry Star Jim Ed Brown, and later spending what she calls her musical college years recording for Giant Record. She learned about the music business from Nashville\u2019s best like James Stroud, Jack McFadden, and Stan Barnett. Even while Vincent was still performing regularly with the Sally Mountain Show, she released her first solo album ''New Dreams and Sunshine'' in 1988. In 1985, Vincent had competed in the TV series ''You Can Be a Star'' on the original version of [[The Nashville Network]]. After winning the competition, she was signed to a recording contract; her first professional performance was with country singer and [[Grand Ole Opry]] star [[Jim Ed Brown]]. In the 1990s Vincent branched out into mainstream country music, releasing a pair of albums on the [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]] label, but did not have success there.\n[[File:Rhondavincent-fls.jpg|thumb|left|Rhonda Vincent on the Watson Stage, MerleFest, 2010]]\n\nWith the release of her album ''Back Home Again'' in 2000, Vincent returned to bluegrass with the goal of expanding both the musical reach and the accessibility of the genre. The [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] (IBMA) accorded her its Female Vocalist of the Year award for the years 2000 \u2013 2006, plus IBMA Entertainer of the Year in 2001. The Society for Preservation of Bluegrass Music in America (SPBGMA) designated her its Entertainer of the Year for 2002 \u2013 2006 inclusive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/bio.jhtml|title=Rhonda Vincent|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030818170009/http://www.vh1.com/artists/az/vincent_rhonda/bio.jhtml |access-date=July 13, 2024|archive-date=August 18, 2003 }}</ref> She also performs with her band, Rhonda Vincent & the Rage.\n\nOn February 19, 2010, Vincent parted from [[Rounder Records]], after ten years with the label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1632264/rhonda-vincent-leaves-rounder-records.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100222122732/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1632264/rhonda-vincent-leaves-rounder-records.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 22, 2010|title=CMT : News : Rhonda Vincent leaves Rounder Records|publisher=CMT News|access-date=February 19, 2010}}</ref> Vincent released \"Taken\", her debut album on her own label Upper Management Music on September 21, 2010. Featuring special guests like long-time friend [[Dolly Parton]], [[Richard Marx]] and [[The Lewis Family|Little Roy Lewis]], the album entered the [[Top Bluegrass Albums]] chart at No.&nbsp;1.<ref name=\"Rhonda Vincent biography\">{{cite web|url=http://www.rhondavincent.com/|title=Rhonda Vincent biography|publisher=Vincent official website|access-date=June 19, 2012}}</ref>\n\nOn June 7, 2011, Vincent and [[Gene Watson]] released a duet album on Upper Management entitled ''Your Money and My Good Looks''. The album entered the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Billboard charts|Top Country Albums]] chart at number 71.\n\n''Sunday Mornin' Singin''', an album of old-time gospel standards, was released on July 10, 2012.\n\nOn April 1, 2017, Vincent's duet with a fellow country singer [[Richard Lynch (musician)|Richard Lynch]] was released as a track on Lynch's album \"Mending Fences\".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Papadatos|first1=Marcos|title=Review: Richard Lynch back with new country single 'Cut And Paste' |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/review-richard-lynch-back-with-new-country-single-cut-and-paste/article/489310|website=Digital Journal|date=April 2017 |access-date=April 2, 2017}}</ref>\n\nDuring an appearance at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] on April 27, Vincent announced that she and [[Daryle Singletary]] had spent the previous months recording a duets album, with further details to follow during [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA week]]. She then introduced Singletary and the two performed a couple of [[George Jones]] and [[Tammy Wynette]] songs \u2013 \"[[Golden Ring (song)|Golden Ring]]\" and \"[[One (George Jones and Tammy Wynette album)|One]]\".\n\nIt was her pivotal bluegrass album, \u201cBack Home Again\u201d on Rounder Records, that transformed Vincent into the All American Bluegrass Girl. She was crowned the New Queen of Bluegrass by \u201cThe Wall Street Journal\u201d in 2000. She is a multi-award winner, with a 2017 Grammy for Best Bluegrass Album, an Entertainer of the Year 2001, Song of the Year 2004, and unprecedented seven consecutive Female Vocalist of the Year awards from the International Bluegrass Music Association 2000 \u2013 2006.\n\nHer powerful vocal style transcends the boundaries of bluegrass music, as evidenced in her collaboration with Dolly Parton on the Elton John / Bernie Taupin Tribute Project \u201cRestoration\u201d 2018. She was invited to become a member of the Grand Ole Opry on February 28, 2020.\n\n===Touring===\nIn 2008, Vincent's band performed at Centennial Hall in [[London, Ontario]], at a concert organized by the Thames Valley Bluegrass Association.<ref>''Strings'', newsletter of the Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society, June 2008</ref>\n\n===Gospel DVD===\nIn a 2011 interview with television station [[KTVO]] Vincent announced that she and her band had recently filmed a live all-gospel DVD at a church in her hometown of Greentop, Missouri.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heartlandconnection.com/news/story.aspx?id=686151|title=Bluegrass Queen performs for the Heartland|publisher= KTVO-TV website|date=November 1, 2011|access-date=November 14, 2011}}</ref> The DVD was expected to be released sometime in 2012.\n\n==Family life==\nVincent married Herb Sandker on Christmas Eve 1983.<ref name=\"Rhonda Vincent fact sheet\"/> While it might have been more convenient to be based out of someplace like [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Vincent chose to remain close to her Missouri roots: \"My husband and I made the decision early on. I loved being in my home area. My parents are there, our relatives are there. We wanted to raise our children there. So I made the decision to commute.\"<ref name=\"Boone\"/> For a period of time in the late 1990s and early 2000s, they owned, and Sandker managed, a popular restaurant in Kirksville, Missouri, called Bogies.  <ref>{{cite web|last=Righi |first=Len |url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-2000-06-09-3304169-story.html |title=Home on the Web: Rhonda Vincent Turns to the Internet to Bond With Traditional Bluegrass Fans |website=MCall.com |date=June 9, 2000 |access-date=May 29, 2022}}</ref>\n\nVincent's elder daughter Sally wed her mother's fiddle player, Hunter Berry, in Greentop, Missouri, in 2010. Younger daughter Tensel married her mother's dobro player, Brent Burke, in 2013. Sally and Tensel have since performed with their mother, and have begun their own group with their husbands named Next Best Thing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lawless |first=John |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/the-next-best-thing/ |title=The Next Best Thing |website=Bluegrasstoday.com |date=August 4, 2008 |access-date=March 10, 2020}}</ref>\n\nSince 1987, Rhonda and the entire Vincent family have hosted a large yearly bluegrass festival on land just west of [[Queen City, Missouri]]. The Sally Mountain Bluegrass Festival is traditionally held around July 4, and attracts music fans from across the U.S. and the world. \n[[File:QueenCityMo4.jpg|thumb|A highway sign in Queen City, Missouri directing attendees to the annual Sally Mountain Bluegrass Festival]]\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Rhonda Vincent discography}}\n\n==Awards==\nTo date, Vincent and her band, The Rage, have won one [[Grammy Award|Grammy]], nineteen [[International Bluegrass Music Association|IBMA Awards]] (including the top Entertainer of the Year honor in 2001 and consecutive Female Vocalist of the year wins between 2000 and 2006) and eighty nine SPBGMA Awards.\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! 2022 || [[64th Annual Grammy Awards|Grammy Awards]] || ''Music Is What I See'' || {{nominated}}\n|}\n\n==Other honors==\n* Missouri Walk of Fame 2012 inductee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cherryblossomfest.com/pages/2012.html|title=Inductee list|publisher=Cherry Blossom Festival|year=2012|access-date=April 29, 2012}}</ref>\n* Bluegrass Star Award, Inaugural Recipient (October 16, 2010), presented by the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation of Dallas Texas.  The award is bestowed upon bluegrass artists who do an exemplary job of advancing traditional bluegrass music and bringing it to new audiences while preserving its character and heritage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluegrassheritage.org/bluegrass-star-award/|title=Bluegrass Heritage Foundation official website|website=Bluegrassheritage.org|year=2010|access-date=December 28, 2015}}</ref>\n* Champion, Celebrity Division, [[National Cornbread Festival]] cookoff. Rhonda and husband Herb are the previous owners and operators of a popular restaurant in Kirksville, Missouri.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}\n* Missouri Music Hall of Fame 2017 inductee\n* [[List of Grand Ole Opry Members|Member of the Grand Ole Opry]]\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.rhondavincent.com/ Official website]\n*{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p703}}\n\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Vincent, Rhonda}}\n[[Category:1962 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women musicians]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass mandolinists]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass musicians]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Missouri]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:People from Adair County, Missouri]]\n[[Category:People from Kirksville, Missouri]]\n[[Category:People from Schuyler County, Missouri]]\n[[Category:Rebel Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Missouri]]\n[[Category:Truman State University alumni]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Grascals","to":"The Grascals"}],"pages":{"11788043":{"pageid":11788043,"ns":0,"title":"The Grascals","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American bluegrass band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = The Grascals\n| image             = Grascals Dec 22.jpg\n| image_size        = \n| background        = group_or_band\n| origin            = [[Nashville, Tennessee]] U.S.\n| genre             = [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[southern gospel]]\n| years_active      = 2004\u2013present\n| label             = {{Hlist | [[Rounder Records]] | [[Cracker Barrel]] | Saguaro Road Records | [[Mountain Home Records|Mountain Home]]}}\n| current_members   = {{Ubl\n  | Terry Smith\n  | Danny Roberts\n  | Kristin Scott Benson\n  | Jamie Johnson\n  | John Bryan\n  | Jamie Harper\n  }}\n| past_members      = {{Ubl\n  | Dave Talbot\n  | Jimmy Mattingly\n  | Aaron McDaris\n  | Jeremy Abshire\n  | Terry Eldredge\n  | Chris Davis\n  | Adam Haynes\n  }}\n| website           = {{URL|grascals.com}}\n}}\n\n'''The Grascals''' are a six-piece American [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] band from [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. Founded in February 2004, the band has gained a level of fame by playing on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] and bluegrass festivals around the country, as well as with [[Dolly Parton]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://grascals.com/about/|title=About {{!}} The Grascals|website=grascals.com|access-date=2019-05-01}}</ref><ref name=\"bluegrasstoday.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/the-grascals-open-dolly-partons-the-vintage-tour/|title=The Grascals open Dolly Parton's \"The Vintage Tour\"|date=2005-11-23|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n==Members==\n*Terry Smith \u2013 [[upright bass]]/vocals\n*Danny Roberts \u2013 [[mandolin]]\n*Kristin Scott Benson \u2013 [[banjo]]\n*Jamie Harper \u2013 [[fiddle]]\n*John Bryan \u2013 guitar/vocals\n*Jamie Johnson \u2013 guitar/vocals\n\n=== Terry Smith ===\n\nTerry Smith was born June 15, 1960, in [[Reidsville, North Carolina]]. He moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in his early teens, after starting out playing in a family band with his mother [[Hazel Smith]], father Patrick Smith, and brother, Billy Smith. Terry has played with such legends as [[Jimmy Martin]], [[Wilma Lee Cooper]], and the [[Osborne Brothers]]. Terry and his brother, Billy, recorded an album for [[Sony Music|CBS]] Records, which evolved to a number one video on [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]] with \"Blues Stay Away From Me.\"  After touring with [[Grand Ole Opry]] member [[Mike Snider (musician)|Mike Snider]], Terry joined the Grascals and remains as a founding member.\n\n=== Danny Roberts ===\n\nDanny Roberts started playing guitar to back up Jimmy Mattingly when they were growing up in [[Leitchfield, Kentucky]]. He began to win contests for his guitar playing, and eventually, mandolin. In 1982, he co-founded the New Tradition, bluegrass/[[gospel music|gospel]] group that toured the country for close to 20 years. The band recorded 10 CDs, made \"Seed of Love\" song, the first bluegrass video to feature the [[banjo]], and even reached number one on the [[The Nashville Network|TNN]] channel. That band broke up in 2000, but Danny still continued to play with others including [[Marty Raybon]], [[Larry Cordle]], and [[Melonie Cannon]]. He also joined Ronnie Reno's band, the Reno Tradition. Danny joined the Grascals as a founding member, where he was reunited with Jimmy Mattingly.\n\n=== Kristin Scott Benson ===\nKristin Scott Benson grew up in South Carolina in a musical family and joined the Grascals in January 2009. She worked previously with Petticoat Junction, Larry Cordle & Lonesome Standard Time and the Larry Stephenson Band. She has won the International Bluegrass Music Awards and Society of the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America Banjo Player of the Year numerous times. In September 2018, she was chosen as the recipient of the ''[[Steve Martin]] Prize for Excellence'' in Banjo and Bluegrass with a $50,000 reward. Kristin is married to [[IIIrd Tyme Out]] mandolin player [[Wayne Benson]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/kristin-scott-benson-talks-about-the-steve-martin-prize/|title=Kristin Scott Benson talks about the Steve Martin Prize|date=2018-09-26|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-06}}</ref>\n\n=== John Bryan ===\nJohn Bryan sings lead vocals and plays guitar with the Grascals. He's been playing and singing bluegrass since he was a teen, with a deep, family connection to the music. John's great grandfather, Willard Watson, was a first cousin to Doc, and a fine old-time musician and dancer in his own right.  John was formerly with Larry Efaw and The Bluegrass Mountaineers when he joined the Grascals in April 2015.\n\n=== Jamie Johnson ===\nJamie Johnson was an original founding member since February 2004.  He was raised in Indiana and now makes his home in Hendersonville, Tennessee.  After an eight-year break, he has returned to the band on guitar and vocals.  The band is looking forward to singing and traveling with Jamie again and performing the incredible songs he has written.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Grascals Welcome Back Founding Member, Jamie Johnson, and Look Toward 20th Anniversary |url=https://myemail.constantcontact.com/The-Grascals-Welcome-Back-Founding-Member--Jamie-Johnson--and-Look-Toward-20th-Anniversary.html?soid=1131760830668&aid=AInl0O-kGL0 |access-date=2022-12-15 |website=IVPR |language=en-US}}</ref>\n=== Jamie Harper ===\nJamie \u201cHarp\u201d Harper plays fiddle for the Grascals and helps out on vocals as of January 2023.   He is originally from North Carolina and now makes his home near Portland, TN with his wife Lakyn and son Stetson. \u201cHarp\u201d has a long bluegrass resume performing with Sideline and Junior Sisk among others [https://bluegrasstoday.com/jamie-harper-to-the-grascals/]\n\n==Line Up Changes==\n\n* December 2006: Dave Talbot left and was replaced by Aaron McDaris on banjo beginning in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1547660/bluegrass-bands-change-lineups/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190501223751/http://www.cmt.com/news/1547660/bluegrass-bands-change-lineups/|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 1, 2019|title=Bluegrass Bands Change Lineups|date=2006-12-08|website=CMT News|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* July 2008: Jimmy Mattingly left and was replaced by Jeremy Abshire on fiddle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/jeremy-abshire-to-the-grascals/|title=Jeremy Abshire to The Grascals|date=2008-05-16|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* January 2009: Aaron McDaris left and was replaced by Kristin Scott Benson on banjo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thebluegrassspecial.com/archive/2009/january2009/bensongrascalsfeaturejan09.php|title=The Bluegrass Special {{!}} January 2009 {{!}} Features: The Grascals|website=www.thebluegrassspecial.com|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* October 2013: Jeremy Abshire left and was replaced by Adam Haynes on fiddle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/adam-haynes-to-the-grascals/|title=Adam Haynes to The Grascals|date=2013-10-25|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* April 2015: Jamie Johnson left and was replaced by John Bryan on guitar and vocals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/john-bryan-to-the-grascals/|title=John Bryan to The Grascals|date=2015-04-27|website=Bluegrass Today|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n* February 2019: Terry Eldredge left and former member Jamie Johnson returned for a few months filling the void.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |date=2019-05-09 |title=Chris Davis to The Grascals |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/chris-davis-to-the-grascals/ |access-date=2019-05-09 |website=Bluegrass Today |language=en-US}}</ref>\n*May 2019: Chris Davis joined the band on guitar and vocals.<ref name=\":0\" />\n*September 2022: Chris Davis departed the Grascals, 9/24/2022, playing his final show with the band at the LeConte Center, Pigeon Forge, TN<ref name=\":0\" />\n*December 2022: founding member Jamie Johnson returned to the band following an eight-year hiatus.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Grascals Welcome Back Founding Member, Jamie Johnson, and Look Toward 20th Anniversary |url=https://myemail.constantcontact.com/The-Grascals-Welcome-Back-Founding-Member--Jamie-Johnson--and-Look-Toward-20th-Anniversary.html?soid=1131760830668&aid=AInl0O-kGL0 |access-date=2022-12-15 |website=IVPR |language=en-US}}</ref>\n*January 2023: Jamie Harper joined the Grascals, replacing Adam Haynes on fiddle  [https://bluegrasstoday.com/jamie-harper-to-the-grascals/]\n\n== History ==\n\nThe original concept of the Grascals occurred when the four core members, Terry Eldredge, Jamie Johnson, Jimmy Mattingly, and Dave Talbot, asked Terry Smith and Danny Roberts to join a new group they were wanting to start. They played one of their first shows at the Station Inn in February 2004 with special guest [[Osborne Brothers|Bobby Osborne]]. The Grascals began recording their first album in 2004, which would simply be a self-titled album on [[Rounder Records]]. This album featured such songs as \"Me and John and Paul\" written by [[Harley Allen]], \"[[Where Corn Don't Grow]]\" and another popular cover song, \"Viva Las Vegas,\" which featured Dolly Parton.  During the recording, [[Dolly Parton]] showed interest in wanting to play with the Grascals.  The band soon became Dolly's opening act, as well as her bluegrass band.<ref name=\"bluegrasstoday.com\"/> Performing at [[Dollywood]] and the [[Grand Ole Opry]], the band and Dolly played a cover version of [[Elvis]]'s song, [[Viva Las Vegas (song)|\"Viva Las Vegas.\"]] The [[The grascals (album)|first album]] made it on to the Billboard charts, as well as many country and bluegrass charts. Also on the album cover, Dolly is quoted saying, \"One of the greatest albums I've ever heard.\"<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/the-grascals|title=The Grascals Chart History|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n== Notable accomplishments ==\n\n* 2004\u2013present: The Grascals have appeared on the stage of the Grand Ole Opry many times as a band.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opry.com/artist/grascals|title=The Grascals|date=2013-12-20|website=Grand Ole Opry|language=en|access-date=2019-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cybergrass.com/node/1063#sthash.I025AnK5.dpbs|title=2 Cups. 4 Cups. 6 Cups, a Winner \u2013 The Grascals Make 115th Opry Appearance |website=www.cybergrass.com|access-date=2019-05-06}}</ref>\n*April 2, 2006: Performed at the Millennium Stage at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]] in Washington, DC. The concert was part of the Center's C''ountry: A Celebration of America's Music'' series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/the-grascals-to-perform-at-kennedy-center/|title=The Grascals Bluegrass'' with $50,000 reward.[https://bluegrasstoday.com/kristin-scott-benson-talks-about-the-steve-martin-prize/]\n\n== Awards ==\n\n===International Bluegrass Music Awards===\nThe Grascals have won the following 10 International Bluegrass Music Association ([[International Bluegrass Music Awards]]) awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ibma.org/recipients-inductees/|title=Recipients & Inductees|website=International Bluegrass Music Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ibma.org/award-recipients/the-grascals/|title=The Grascals|website=International Bluegrass Music Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-03}}</ref>\n\n* 2005 Emerging Artist of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2005 Song of the Year \"Me and John and Paul\", The Grascals (artists), Harley Allen (songwriter) \n* 2006 Album of the Year \u2013 Celebration of Life: Musicians Against Childhood Cancer (Compilation Project/Various Artists), Skaggs Family Records\n* 2006 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2007 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2008 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2009 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2010 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n* 2011 Banjo Performer of the Year (tie) \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n*2019 Banjo Performer of the Year \u2013 Kristin Scott Benson\n\n=== Society of the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America ===\nThe Grascals have also been awarded these 28 awards by the Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spbgma.com/archives.html|title=Archives |website=www.spbgma.com|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n* 2006 Song of the Year \u2013 ''Me and John and Paul'' by The Grascals for Rounder Records\n* 2006 Bluegrass Album of the Year \u2013 ''The Grascals'' by The Grascals for Rounder Records\n* 2006 Mandolin Performer of the Year \u2013 Danny Roberts\n* 2006 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2007 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2007 Bluegrass Band of the Year (Overall) \u2013 The Grascals\n* 2008 2022 Bass Performer of the Year \u2013 Terry Smith\n\n=== Grammy Nominations ===\nThe Grascals have received three Grammy Nominations for the following:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/grascals|title=The Grascals|date=2019-02-15|website=grammy.com|language=en|access-date=2019-05-02}}</ref>\n\n* 2005 Best Bluegrass Album \u2013 ''The Grascals'' (Rounder Records)\n* 2006 Best Bluegrass Album \u2013 ''Long List Of Heartaches'' (Rounder Records)\n* 2012 Best Bluegrass Album \u2013 ''Life Finds A Way'' (Mountain Home)\n\n===
