people]]\n[[Category:American musicians with disabilities]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Doyle_Lawson","to":"Doyle Lawson"}],"pages":{"7385057":{"pageid":7385057,"ns":0,"title":"Doyle Lawson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American bluegrass and gospel musician}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Doyle Lawson\n| image        = Doyle Lawson and his band.jpg\n| caption      = Lawson (left) and his band harmonize during the 2006 [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]] National Heritage Fellows concert\n| birth_place  = [[Sullivan County, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1944|04|20}}\n| genre        = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n| occupation   = [[Singing|Singer]]\n| instrument   = [[Mandolin]]\n| years_active = 1963\u20132021\n| website      = {{URL|https://www.doylelawson.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Doyle Wayne Lawson'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/894305355 |title=Brother Have You Heard |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=April 26, 2023}}</ref> (born April 20, 1944) is an American traditional [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[Southern gospel]] [[musician]].<ref name=aj>{{cite book|title=Appalachian Journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2PwRAAAAYAAJ|year=1980|pages=331\u2013332}}</ref> He is best known as a [[mandolin]] player, vocalist, producer, and leader of the 6-man group '''Doyle Lawson & Quicksilver'''.<ref name=\"Jones2008\">{{cite book|author=[[Loyal Jones]]|title=Country Music Humorists and Comedians|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qiOyjQZOaigC&pg=PA238|date=8 October 2008|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-03369-8|pages=238\u2013}}</ref> Lawson was inducted into the International Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame in 2012.\n\n==Early life==\n\nDoyle Lawson was born in Fordtown, [[Sullivan County, Tennessee]],<ref name=\"McNeil2013\">{{cite book|author=W. K. McNeil|title=Encyclopedia of American Gospel Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=beGNAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA226|date=18 October 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-37700-7|pages=226\u2013}}</ref> the son of Leonard and Minnie Lawson. The Lawson family moved to [[Sneedville]] in 1954.<ref name=\"Ledgin2004\">{{cite book|author=Stephanie P. Ledgin|title=Homegrown Music: Discovering Bluegrass|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7kgBY8tV6zYC&pg=PA47|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-98115-0|pages=47\u2013}}</ref> Lawson grew up listening to the [[Grand Ole Opry]] on Saturday nights. This is where he heard mandolinist [[Bill Monroe]], the \"founding father\" of [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], and his band ''the Blue Grass Boys''.\n\nLawson became interested in playing the mandolin around the age of eleven so his father borrowed a mandolin from Willis Byrd, a family friend and fellow musician. Doyle taught himself how to play the mandolin by listening to the radio and records, and watching an occasional TV show.<ref name=aj /> Later Lawson learned to play the [[guitar]] and [[banjo]] as well.<ref name=\"McNeil2013\" />\n\n==Career==\n===Early career===\nIn 1963, aged 18 or 19, Lawson went to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] to play the banjo with [[Jimmy Martin|Jimmy Martin and the Sunny Mountain Boys]].<ref name=\"WolffDuane2000\">{{cite book|author1=Kurt Wolff|author2=Orla Duane|title=Country Music: The Rough Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Jorozp1yp4C&pg=PA228|year=2000|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=978-1-85828-534-4|pages=228\u2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 1966, he started playing with [[J.D. Crowe]] and the Kentucky Mountain Boys (later called the [[New South (band)|New South]]) in [[Lexington, Kentucky]]. He returned to play the mandolin and sing tenor with Martin in 1969 for six months, and then played again with Crowe until August 1971.<ref name=\"Ledgin2004\" /><ref name=cont>{{cite book|title=Contemporary Musicians|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uwo5AQAAIAAJ|year=2006|publisher=Gale Research, Incorporated|isbn=978-0-7876-8068-8|pages=101\u2013102}}</ref>\n\nIn September, 1971, Lawson started playing with [[The Country Gentlemen]] and remained part of the band for almost eight years. During that time, in 1977, he backed up U.S. Senator [[Robert Byrd]] on his ''Mountain Fiddler'' album. In  March 1979, Lawson left the Country Gentlemen with the intention of forming a band and creating his own sound.<ref name=\"Ledgin2004\" /><ref name=\"McNeil2013\"/>\n\n===Doyle Lawson & Quicksilver===\nWithin a month Lawson had formed ''Doyle Lawson and Foxfire'', with Jimmy Haley on guitar, [[Lou Reid]] on bass, and [[Terry Baucom]] on banjo.<ref name=\"McNeil2013\"/>  The band name was soon changed to ''Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver''.<ref name=\"Goldsmith2004\">{{cite book|author=Thomas Goldsmith|title=The Bluegrass Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LgAGzopOTbYC&pg=PA248|year=2004|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-02914-1|pages=248\u2013}}</ref><ref>\"No one since the late great Bill Monroe melds bluegrass with gospel music quite like the former Country Gentlemen member Doyle Lawson\u2026\" [[Memphis Commercial Appeal]] (what date?).</ref> In 1981, through [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]], Lawson with this lineup released the critically acclaimed ''Rock My Soul'', an album that would become a landmark bluegrass gospel project.<ref name=\"WolffDuane2000\" /><ref name=\"Rosenberg2005\">{{cite book|author=Neil V. Rosenberg|title=Bluegrass: A History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hp1Sm81MYboC&pg=PA376-IA10|year=2005|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-07245-1|pages=376\u2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Option|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rytLAAAAYAAJ|year=1987|publisher=Sonic Options Network|page=64}}</ref>  With a new bassist, Randy Graham, the band recorded a second gospel album, ''Heavenly Treasures'', also on Sugar Hill.<ref name=\"McNeil2013\"/><ref name=\"Goldsmith2004\"/>\n\nShortly thereafter, Graham, Baucom and Haley left to form their own band.  Lawson hired guitarist [[Russell Moore and IIIrd Tyme Out|Russell Moore]], banjoist [[Scott Vestal]] and bassist Curtis Vestal, and continued to perform.  After a time Ray Deaton took over on bass.<ref name=\"McNeil2013\"/>\n\nIn 1989 the band won song of the year at the [[International Bluegrass Music Awards]] for \"Little Mountain Church House\". In 1997, ''There's a Light Guiding Me'' was a 39th Annual Grammy Award nominee for Best Southern Gospel, Country Gospel or Bluegrass Gospel Album.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1997-01-08-ca-16471-story.html|title=The Complete List of Nominees|date=1997-01-08|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2017-01-27}}</ref> Through the years, Quicksilver toured regularly, performing at festivals concerts and other musical events.<ref>{{cite book|title=No Depression|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=025LAAAAYAAJ|year=2004|publisher=No Depression|pages=22, issues 49\u201354}}</ref>\n\nIn 1998, Lawson and Quicksilver became the first bluegrass band to perform at the [[National Quartet Convention]]. Lawson and Quicksilver performed in [[Ontario]], Canada at the [[Tottenham Bluegrass Festival]] in June 2001<ref>''Strings'', newsletter of the Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society, May/June 2001</ref> and again in June 2015. Lawson and Quicksilver provided the background vocals to the song \"Dazzling Blue\" on Paul Simon's 2011 album ''So Beautiful or So What''. In 2015, ''In Session'' was nominated for Best Bluegrass Album at the 58th Annual Grammy Awards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/awards/58th-annual-grammy-awards?cat=611 |title=58th Annual Grammy Awards |publisher=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=2024-06-14}}</ref>\n[[File:Doyle Lawson & Quicksilver on stage at the 2015 Tottenham Bluegrass Festival in Ontario, Canada.jpg|thumb|300px|Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver on stage at the 2015 Tottenham Bluegrass Festival in Ontario, Canada]]\nLawson composed a number of the band's songs and tunes. His instrumental piece \"Rosine\", is a tribute to [[Rosine, Kentucky|Monroe's birthplace]] and features, among other things, strains from the singer's 1967 instrumental \"Kentucky Mandolin\".<ref>[http://ibmaawards.org/node/43#2012 Profile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121203195413/http://ibmaawards.org/node/43#2012 |date=December 3, 2012}}, ibmaawards.org; accessed October 30, 2015.</ref> Lawson hosts the annual Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver Festival in [[Denton, North Carolina]]. In 2021, Lawson announced his retirement as a bandleader. Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver played their last show in the winter of 2021.\n\n==Personal life==\nDoyle has been married to Suzanne Lawson since 1978. He has one son, two daughters and a grandchild. Doyle rededicated his life to [[Christianity]] in May 1985 and is a practicing member of Cold Spring Presbyterian Church.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}\n\n==Band members==\n===Original members===\n*Doyle Lawson-mandolin, vocal\n*Jimmy Haley-guitar,  vocal (1979-1985)\n*[[Lou Reid]]-bass,  vocal (1979-1982)\n*Terry Baucom-banjo, vocal (1979-1985, 2003\u20132007)\n\n===Final members===\n*Doyle Lawson-mandolin,  vocal\n*Eli Johnston-bass, banjo, vocal (2013-2018, 2020\u20132021)\n*Stephen Burwell-fiddle (2014-2020, 2021)\n*Jerry Cole-bass, guitar, vocal (2018-2021)\n*Matt Flake-fiddle, bass, vocal (2020-2021)\n*Ben James-guitar, vocal (2020-2021)\n\n===Other past members===\n*Randy Graham-bass, vocal  (1982-1985)\n*Russell Moore-guitar, vocal (1985-1991)\n*Scott Vestal-banjo, vocal (1985-1988)\n*Curtis Vestal-bass, vocal (1985-1986)\n*Ray Deaton-bass, vocal (1986-1991)\n*Jim Mills-banjo, vocal (1988-1992)\n*Mike Hartgrove-fiddle (1989-1991, 2005\u20132007)\n*John Bowman-guitar, vocal (1991-1992)\n*Shelton Feazell-bass, vocal (1991-1993)\n*Shawn Lane-fiddle, guitar, vocal (1992-1994)\n*Jimmy Stewart-dobro, fiddle (1992-1994)\n*Brad Campbell-banjo, vocal (1992-1994)\n*John Berry-bass, vocal (1993-1994)\n*Barry Abernathy-banjo, vocal (1994-1998)\n*Dale Perry-bass, banjo, vocal (1994-2003, 2009\u20132011)\n*Steve Gulley-guitar, vocal (1994-1996)\n*Owen Saunders-fiddle (1994-1997)\n*Barry Scott-guitar, bass, vocal (1996-2005)\n*Jim VanCleve-fiddle (1997-1998)\n*Doug Bartlett-fiddle, vocal (1998-2001)\n*Jamie Dailey-bass, guitar, vocal (1998-2007)\n*Hunter Berry-fiddle (2001-2002)\n*Jesse Stockman-fiddle (2002-2005)\n*Jess Barry-fiddle (2002-2003)\n*Darren Beachley-bass, guitar, vocal (2005-2009)\n*Alan Johnson-fiddle, vocal  (2007-2008)\n*Joey Cox-banjo (2007-2009)\n*Carl White-bass, drums, vocal (2007-2009, 2011\u20132012)\n*Josh Swift-dobro, vocal (2007-2020)\n*Brandon Godman-fiddle (2008-2009)\n*Jason Barie-fiddle (2009-2014)\n*Corey Hensley-guitar, bass, vocal (2009-2013)\n*Jason Leek-bass, vocal (2009-2010)\n*Mike Rogers-guitar, vocal (2010-2013)\n*Jessie Baker-banjo (2011-2012)\n*Joe Dean-banjo, vocal (2012-2020)\n*Dustin Pyrtle-guitar, vocal (2013-2018)\n*Jake Vanover-guitar, vocal (2018-2020)\n\n====Timeline====\n<timeline>\nImageSize  = width:900 height:auto barincrement:20\nPlotArea   = Out''\n| \n| rowspan=\"2\"| Sugar Hill\n|-\n| 2007\n| ''Best of the Sugar Hill Years''\n| \n|}\n\n==Awards==\n\nLawson is a recipient of a 2006 [[National Heritage Fellowship]] awarded by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], which is the United States government's highest honor in the folk and traditional arts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/year/2006 |title=NEA National Heritage Fellowships 2006 |author=<!--Not stated-->  |website=www.arts.gov |publisher=National Endowment for the Arts |access-date=January 6, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200521114746/https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/year/2006 |archive-date=May 21, 2020 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n===International Bluegrass Music  = Musician, singer-songwriter, radio show host\n| instruments     = [[Mandolin]], [[bouzouki]], [[mandola]], [[banjo]], [[guitar]], [[tenor guitar]], [[drums]], [[sitar]], [[piano]], [[violin]], [[viola]], [[cello]], [[double bass]], [[vocals]]\n| years_active    = 1989\u2013present\n| label           = {{Plainlist|\n* [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]\n* [[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]]\n}}\n| associated_acts = [[Nickel Creek]], [[Punch Brothers]], [[Mutual Admiration Society (collaboration)|Mutual Admiration Society]], [[Mike Marshall (bluegrass musician)|Mike Marshall]], [[Edgar Meyer]], [[The Goat Rodeo Sessions]], [[Vulfpeck]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.christhile.com}}\n}}\n'''Christopher Scott Thile''' ({{IPAc-en|\u02c8|\u03b8|i\u02d0|l|i}};<ref>{{cite AV media |date=August 5, 2013 |title=Mandolin Master Chris Thile Plays Bluegrass and Bach |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2LUPtADLYjM  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/2LUPtADLYjM |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|access-date=March 12, 2018 |location=YouTube |publisher=[[PBS NewsHour]] }}{{cbignore}}</ref> born February 20, 1981) is an American [[mandolin]]ist, singer, songwriter, composer, and radio personality, best known for his work in the progressive acoustic trio [[Nickel Creek]] and the acoustic folk and progressive bluegrass quintet [[Punch Brothers]]. He is a [[MacArthur Fellows Program|2012 MacArthur Fellow]].<ref>{{cite news|title=2012 MacArthur Foundation 'Genius Grant' Winners|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2012-macarthur-foundation-genius-grant-winners#overlay-context=users/rjagodzinski|date=1 October 2012|agency=Associated Press|access-date=October 1, 2012|archive-date=October 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002000603/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2012-macarthur-foundation-genius-grant-winners#overlay-context=users/rjagodzinski|url-status=dead}}</ref> From 2016 to its cancellation in 2020, he hosted the radio variety show ''[[Live from Here]]''.<ref name=\"aphc\">{{cite news |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/garrison-keillors-reign-terror-over-americas-airwa-221476 |newspaper=[[The A.V. Club]] |date=June 27, 2015 |last=Hughes |first=William |title=Garrison Keillor's Reign of Terror over America's Airwaves Finally Set to End}}</ref><ref name=\"Bream20161015\">{{cite news |last=Bream |first=Jon |url=http://www.startribune.com/chris-thile-seems-right-at-home-as-new-host-of-a-prairie-home-companion/397212461/#1 |title=Chris Thile seems right at home as new 'Prairie Home Companion' host |work=[[Star Tribune]] |date=October 15, 2016 |access-date=2016-10-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.livefromhere.org/about/history | title= A Brief History about Live from Here | author=  | date= December 18, 2017 | website= Livefromhere.org | access-date= December 18, 2017 | archive-date= December 22, 2017 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171222050757/https://www.livefromhere.org/about/history/ | url-status= dead }}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nThe three members of Nickel Creek met in 1989 at [[Carlsbad, California]]'s That Pizza Place, listening to weekly bluegrass shows with their parents. Their first album, ''[[Little Cowpoke]]'', was released on December 31, 1993. Later albums included ''[[Nickel Creek (album)|Nickel Creek]]'' and ''[[This Side]]'', which went platinum and won a [[Grammy Awards of 2003#Folk|Grammy]] for Best Contemporary Folk Album, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|title=Past Winners Search {{!}} 2002|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=2002&genre=All|website=The GRAMMYs|access-date=2 December 2016}}</ref> In 2005, Nickel Creek released ''[[Why Should the Fire Die?]]'', which received critical acclaim and sold 250,000 units.<ref>[http://indiehq.com/2006/09/20/independent-sales-chart-9-20-06/#more-235]{{Dead link|date=September 2018|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref>\n\nThile has also released solo albums, including [[Not All Who Wander Are Lost (album)|''Not All Who Wander Are Lost'']] (2001) and 2004's [[Deceiver (Chris Thile album)|''Deceiver'']], on which he wrote, composed, sang, and played every part. In 2008, Thile released a collaboration album with bassist [[Edgar Meyer]], and he also plans to release a collaborative album with [[Hilary Hahn]].<ref name=\"edgarmeyer\">{{cite web | url = http://www.carnegiehall.org/article/box_office/events/evt_8401_ma.html?selecteddate=03172007#0 | title = Tensions Mountain Boys at Carnegie Hall | publisher = [[Carnegie Hall]] | date = March 17, 2007 | access-date = 2007-08-30 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083157/http://www.carnegiehall.org/article/box_office/events/evt_8401_ma.html?selecteddate=03172007 | archive-date = September 29, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=\"hilaryhahn\">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/news.php?id=15490 |title=Nonesuch Records Signs Singer/Composer/Mandolinist Chris Thile and His New Band, Punch Brothers |magazine=All About Jazz |date=October 9, 2007 |access-date=2007-10-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225112354/http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/news.php?id=15490 |archive-date=December 25, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref>\n\n===Personal life===\nIn 2003, Thile married fashion designer Jesse Meighan. The couple divorced in 2004, after 18 months of marriage.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Film Review: How to Grow a Band|date = January 10, 2008|url = http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/content_display/esearch/e3icb95fb02525fc2700dd9e5227d53f03e|publisher = Film Journal|access-date = November 15, 2014|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141129021244/http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/content_display/esearch/e3icb95fb02525fc2700dd9e5227d53f03e|archive-date = November 29, 2014|url-status = dead}}</ref>\n\nThile married actress [[Claire Coffee]] on December 23, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title = Mandolinist Chris Thile and Actress Claire Coffee Wed|date = December 25, 2013|url = http://www.cybergrass.com/node/3246|publisher = Cybergrass|access-date = December 25, 2013|website = cybergrass.com|archive-date = December 26, 2013|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131226012313/http://www.cybergrass.com/node/3246|url-status = dead}}</ref> Coffee and Thile have a son named Calvin Eugene Thile, born on May 15, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/05/15/claire-coffee-welcomes-son-calvin-eugene/|title=Claire Coffee Welcomes Son Calvin Eugene|work=People|date=May 15, 2015|access-date=May 20, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150520214341/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/05/15/claire-coffee-welcomes-son-calvin-eugene/|archive-date=May 20, 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n[[Baseball Hall of Fame]] member [[Sam Thompson]] is Thile's great-great-great-great-uncle.<ref>{{Twitter|christhile/statuses/488351338091520002|Chris Thile Tweet}}</ref>\n\n==History==\n\n===1981\u20132000: Early life and career===\nThile was born in [[Oceanside, California]], in 1981. His earliest memories of music are listening to [[Stan Getz]]'s recording of \"[[The Girl from Ipanema]]\" before he even turned one year old. When he was two, his family started going to That Pizza Place, where he listened to John Moore's band Bluegrass Etc. When Thile was four, his family moved to [[Idyllwild, California]].\n\nThile began playing the mandolin at the age of five, taking occasional lessons from John Moore. At age eight, Thile's family and the Watkins family formed [[Nickel Creek]]. The band performed at many California bluegrass festivals, and as a result Chris had to be [[homeschooling|home-schooled]]. At age twelve, he won the mandolin championship at the [[Walnut Valley Festival]] in [[Winfield, Kansas]].\n\nThat same year, 1993, Thile made a demo tape and sent it to the Sugar Hill and Rounder record labels. Both labels showed interest, but the Thiles went with Sugar Hill.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ibluegrass.com/bg_posting3.CFM?p__i=426&p__r=&p__a=inter | title = Chris Thile: Covering the Bases | publisher = iBluegrass.com | date = May 20, 1999 | access-date = 2007-08-30 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071121182607/http://www.ibluegrass.com/bg_posting3.CFM?p__i=426&p__r=&p__a=inter | archive-date = November 21, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> The next year, Chris Thile released his first solo album, ''[[Leading Off]]'', featuring mostly original compositions.\n\nIn 1995, the Thile family moved to [[Murray, Kentucky]], where Chris' father Scott Thile accepted a position at [[Murray State University]] as a musical instrument technician.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waynerice.com/bgbios/bgbiosn.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214081710/http://waynerice.com/bgbios/bgbiosn.htm |archive-date=December 14, 2014 |title=N}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://campus.murraystate.edu/staff/scott.thile/index.html|title=Scott E. Thile|publisher=Campus.murraystate.edu|access-date=February 13, 2015|archive-date=October 13, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013134640/http://campus.murraystate.edu/staff/scott.thile/index.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 1997, Chris released ''[[Stealing Second]]'' and Nickel Creek released ''[[Here to There]]''. Chris went on to attend [[Murray State University]] for a few semesters, where he was a music major.<ref name=\"bases\"/> In 2000, he went to [[Nashville]] to play mandolin on [[Dolly Parton]]'s bluegrass/Appalachian folk album ''[[Little Sparrow]]''.\n\n===2001\u20132005: ''Wander'' and ''Deceiver''===\n{{Main|Not All Who Wander Are Lost (album)|Deceiver (Chris Thile album)}}\nFollowing the major success of the album ''[[Nickel Creek (album)|Nickel Creek]]'', Thile released ''[[Not All Who Wander Are Lost (album)|Not All Who Wander Are Lost]]'' in 2001. The album featured guest appearances from several well-known instrumentalists such as Stuart Duncan, [[B\u00e9la Fleck]], [[Edgar Meyer]], [[Jerry Douglas]], and [[Bryan Sutton]].\n\nIn 2003, Thile teamed up with mandolinist [[Mike Marshall (bluegrass musician)|Mike Marshall]] for the duet album ''Into the Cauldron'', which included original pieces as well as pieces by [[Charlie Parker]] and [[J. S. Bach]]. Also in 2003, Thile joined [[Mark O'Connor]] for his double CD set \"Thirty-Year Retrospective\" which was nominated for a Grammy. In 2004, Thile released ''[[Deceiver (Chris Thile album)|Deceiver]]'', an experimental album on which he recorded every track himself. This included electric guitar, piano, drums, violin, viola, cello, and bass. ''Deceiver'' demonstrated some pop/rock songwriting in addition to \"newgrass\".\n\n===2006\u2013present: Punch Brothers and Edgar Meyer project===\n{{Main|How to Grow a Woman from the Ground|Punch (album)}}\n[[File:Chris Thile 2008 3.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Chris Thile with Punch Brothers at Wintergrass, 2008]]\nIn August 2006, Nickel Creek announced that at the end of the year, they would no longer be recording together as a group, and their tour scheduled through 2007 would be their last for an indefinite period of time. In February 2014, the group announced that it would be releasing another album.\n\nThile was a judge for the fifth annual Independent Music Awards to support independent artists' careers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp |title=Past Judges for the Independent Music Awards Include |publisher=Independentmusicawards.com |access-date=February 13, 2015 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024722/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp |archive-date=July 13, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>\n\nIn 2006, Thile formed [[Punch Brothers|How to Grow a Band]], with whom he recorded ''[[How to Grow a Woman from the Ground]]'', Thile's fifth album. In an interview with the ''Nashville City Paper'', Thile described the band's formation:\n{{blockquote|We got together one night just to drop a ton of money, drink too much wine, eat steaks, and commiserate about our failed relationships. We had gotten to play together a few days before and we had said that we needed to do something musical together. With our hearts smashed to pieces, it became more urgent \u2013 our lives had gone the same way for so long. I knew I wanted to have a band with Gabe [Witcher], but I didn't know if it would be a rock ensemble, an ambitious acoustic classical thing or a bluegrass group. We played, and there was a serious, instantaneous connection. Then I knew I wanted to put together a bluegrass band \u2013 one with a lot of range, but aesthetically a bluegrass band.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://nashvillecitypaper.com/index.cfm?section=12&screen=news&news_id=51705  | title = Nickel Creek's Thile 'grows' a new band | publisher = Nashville City Paper | date = August 23, 2006 | access-date = 2007-10-13 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060826212803/http://nashvillecitypaper.com/index.cfm?section=12&screen=news&news_id=51705 |archive-date = August 26, 2006}}</ref>\n}}\n\nThe band consisted of Chris Thile (mandolin), [[Gabe Witcher]] (fiddle/violin), [[Chris Eldridge]] (guitar), Greg Garrison (bass), and [[Noam Pikelny]] (banjo). [[Bryan Sutton]] has also filled in on guitar when necessary while Eldridge played out commitments to [[The Infamous Stringdusters]]. In 2007, the band officially changed its name first to \"The Tensions Mountain Boys\" and then \"[[Punch Brothers]]\".\n\nOn March 17, 2007, at [[Carnegie Hall]], this group debuted Thile's ambitious \"The Blind Leaving the Blind\", a 40-minute suite in four movements that Thile told [[NPR]] was written in part to deal with his 2004 divorce.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2008/02/29/69406288/bluegrass-suite-packs-a-progressive-punch|title=Bluegrass Suite Packs a Progressive 'Punch'|date=February 29, 2008|work=NPR.org|access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Chris Thile 2008 1.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Chris Thile with Punch Brothers at Wintergrass, 2008]]\nPunch Brothers released its first album, \"[[Punch (album)|Punch]]\", February 26, 2008, on [[Nonesuch Records]]. The album featured Thile's suite \"The Blind Leaving the Blind\", as well as other original songs.<ref name=\"hilaryhahn\" />\n\nTo promote \"Punch\", Thile and Punch Brothers planned a year-long tour in 2008, as well as a February 29 appearance on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno/calendar/02252008.shtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331114400/http://www.nbc.com/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno/calendar/02252008.shtml |archive-date=March 31, 2009 |title=Show Calendar}}</ref> In late 2008, Paul Kowert replaced Garrison on bass. Punch Brothers released ''[[Antifogmatic (album)|Antifogmatic]]'' on February 15, 2010, and continued to tour. On November 5, 2010, the band performed \"Rye Whiskey\" on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' with [[Steve Martin]] guesting on banjo.\n\nPunch Brothers released their third album, [[Who's Feeling Young Now?]], in early 2012.\n\nIn November 2014, Punch Brothers released a single entitled \"I Blew It Off\", from their then-untitled fourth album. In December 2014, the band announced the scheduled release of an upcoming album and simultaneous release of another new single, \"Julep\".\n\nIn August 2008, Thile and [[double bass|bassist]] [[Edgar Meyer]] announced the release date of the duo's planned debut album. The album was released on Thile's label [[Nonesuch Records]] on September 23, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nonesuch.com/journal/chris-thile-edgar-meyer-preview-new-album-at-aspen|title=Chris Thile, Edgar Meyer Preview New Album at Aspen|work=Nonesuch Records Official Website|date=August 13, 2008 |access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref> Commenting on the collaboration, Thile said \"Edgar is one of the biggest influences on my musical life, and now I'm in a duo with him and writing songs with him. This was my dream. I always wondered what it would be like to be playing music this hard.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nonesuch.com/albums/edgar-meyer-and-chris-thile|title=Edgar Meyer and Chris Thile|work=Nonesuch Records Official Website|date=September 23, 2008 |access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref> The duo toured in September and October 2008 to promote the album.\n\nIn 2012, Thile won a [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur Fellowship]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rao|first1=Mallika|title=Chris Thile, Youngest MacArthur Genius of 2012, On His 'Dauntingly Lofty' New Status|url=https://www.carolinaperformingarts.org/the-overture/interview-chris-thile-youngest-macarthur-genius-of-2012-on-his-dauntingly-lofty-new-status/|website=Carolinaperformingarts.org|access-date=September 1, 2014|archive-date=September 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903103919/https://www.carolinaperformingarts.org/the-overture/interview-chris-thile-youngest-macarthur-genius-of-2012-on-his-dauntingly-lofty-new-status/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014, Thile recorded a new collaborative album with [[Edgar Meyer]] entitled [[Bass & Mandolin]] and embarked on a tour with Meyer to support the album.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nonesuch Releases Chris Thile and Edgar Meyer's \"Bass & Mandolin\" on September 9|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-releases-chris-thile-edgar-meyer-bass-mandolin-september-9-2014-08-06|website=www.nonesuch.com|date=August 6, 2014 |access-date=September 1, 2014}}</ref>\n\nAlso in 2014, Thile reunited with Nickel Creek to release a new album called ''[[A Dotted Line]]'' in celebration of their 25th anniversary. The group also embarked on a national tour titled NC25.<ref name=\"nonesuch\">[http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-releases-first-nickel-creek-album-nine-years-a-dotted-line-april-1-2014-02-18 \"Nonesuch Releases First Nickel Creek Album in Nine Years, \"A Dotted Line,\" April 1\"]. ''[[Nonesuch Records]]''. February 18, 2014. Retrieved February 18, 2014.</ref>\n\nPunch Brothers released [[The Phosphorescent Blues]], their fourth album, and The Wireless EP in 2015. They also released their fifth and sixth albums, [[All Ashore (album)]] and [[Hell on Church Street]], in 2018 and 2022 respectively.\n\n===Side projects===\n[[File:Amazing David Grisman, Chris Thile, Enrique Coria Winterhawk (Greyfox) Bluegrass Festival 1998.webm|thumb|right|[[David Grisman]], Chris Thile and [[Enrique Coria]] at the [[Grey Fox Bluegrass Festival]]  in 1998]]\nThile is featured in the documentary ''Bluegrass Journey'', along with the rest of Nickel Creek. He has also appeared on a number of other artists' recordings, including [[B\u00e9la Fleck]]'s ''[[Perpetual Motion (album)|Perpetual Motion]]'', playing arrangements of Baroque, Impressionist, Classical and other styles of music with Fleck and Edgar Meyer; ''Jam Session'', with [[Mark O'Connor]], [[Frank Vignola]], [[Bryan Sutton]], and Jon Burr; the [[Dixie Chicks]]' ''Home'', [[Kate Rusby]]'s ''[[Awkward Annie]]'', [[Julie Fowlis]]'s ''[[Cuilidh]]'', [[Dolly Parton]]'s ''[[Little Sparrow]]'', [[Dierks Bentley]]'s ''Up on the Ridge'', [[Jacob Collier]]'s \"[[Djesse Vol. 2]]\", and [[Sarah Jarosz]]'s ''Song Up in Her Head'' and ''Follow Me Down''.\n\nThile has performed as a duo with guitarist and vocalist Michael Daves since 2005.<ref>{{cite web|last=Klein|first=Bradley|title=Chris Thile and Michael Daves Interview|url=http://www.mandolincafe.com/news/publish/mandolins_001351.shtml|publisher=Mandolin Cafe|access-date=May 9, 2011}}</ref> They released their debut album, ''Sleep With One Eye Open'', on May 10, 2011. Recorded at [[Jack White (musician)|Jack White]]'s studio, the album consists of 16 classic bluegrass duets. Jack White also produced and played on the duo's 7\" vinyl record ''Man in the Middle'' on [[Third Man Records]]. Thile and Daves met in 2005 at a bluegrass jam at NYC's Baggot Inn.\n\nIn 2009 Thile completed a mandolin concerto entitled ''Ad astra per alas porci''. The work was commissioned by a consortium of orchestras including the [[Colorado Symphony Orchestra]], [[Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra]], [[Oregon Symphony]], [[Alabama Symphony Orchestra]], [[Winston-Salem Symphony]], [[Delaware Symphony Orchestra]], [[Portland Symphony Orchestra]], and [[Interlochen Center for the Arts]]. Thile performed the world premiere of the first movement with the Interlochen Arts Camp World Youth Symphony Orchestra under director [[Jung-Ho Pak]], and premiered his entire concerto with the [[Colorado Symphony Orchestra]] on September 17, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/chris-thile-premieres-his-mandolin-concerto-with-colorado-symphony-2009-09-16|title=Chris Thile Premieres His Mandolin Concerto with Colorado Symphony|work=Nonesuch Records Official Website|date=September 16, 2009 |access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/oregonian-chris-thile-reinvents-his-instrument-with-mandolin-concerto-2009-09-29|title=Oregonian: Chris Thile Reinvents His Instrument with Mandolin Concerto|work=Nonesuch Records Official Website|date=September 29, 2009 |access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bluegrassjournal.com/2009/09/01/chris-thile-composes-mandolin-concerto/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219132849/http://www.bluegrassjournal.com/2009/09/01/chris-thile-composes-mandolin-concerto/ |archive-date=February 19, 2012 |title=Chris Thile composes Mandolin Concerto |first=Dan |last=Tackett |date=September 1, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.violinist.com/blog/laurie/20099/10496/|title=Reviews of Chris Thile's Mandolin Concerto|publisher=Violinist.com|access-date=February 13, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, he recorded ''[[The Goat Rodeo Sessions]]'' with cellist [[Yo-Yo Ma]], bassist [[Edgar Meyer]] and fiddle player [[Stuart Duncan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yo-yoma.com/music/goat-rodeo-sessions|title=The Goat Rodeo Sessions|work=The Official Yo-Yo Ma Site|access-date=February 13, 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214034542/http://www.yo-yoma.com/music/goat-rodeo-sessions|archive-date=February 14, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On October 25, 2011, he appeared on the Tonight Show as a member of the Yo-Yo Ma and Friends musical act.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/episodes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022010811/http://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/episode-guide/|url-status=dead|title=Watch The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon Episodes at NBC.com|archive-date=October 22, 2011|access-date=July 17, 2021|website=Nbc.com}}</ref> On June 19, 2020, the same group of musicians released a second album entitled ''[[Not Our First Goat Rodeo]]''.\n\nThile released a solo album entitled ''Bach: Sonatas and Partitas, Vol. 1'' in June 2013. The work comprises three works by [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] written for solo violin: Sonata No. 1 in G minor, BWV 1001; Partita No. 1 in B minor, BWV 1002; and Sonata No. 2 in A minor, BWV 1003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-releases-chris-thile-bach-sonatas-partitas-vol-1-august-6-2013-06-19 |title=Nonesuch Releases Chris Thile's \"Bach: Sonatas and Partitas, Vol. 1\" on August 6 &#124; Nonesuch Records |date=June 19, 2013 |publisher=Nonesuch.com |access-date=2017-10-18}}</ref>\n\nFor 2018\u201319, Thile was named to the [[Barbara Knowles Debs|Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair]] at [[Carnegie Hall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/chris-thile-carnegie-hall-debs-composers-chair-2018-19-season-2018-01-25 |title=Chris Thile to Hold Carnegie Hall Debs Composer's Chair for 2018\u201319 Season &#124; Nonesuch Records |publisher=Nonesuch.com |date=2018-01-25 |access-date=2019-03-15}}</ref>\n\nIn 2021 the artist was inter alia part of the [[Newport Folk Festival]] in July.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Newport Folk Festival stage schedule 2021 |url=https://newportfolk.org/2021-schedule/ |access-date=2021-09-21 |website=newportfolk.org}}</ref>\n\nIn 2024, Thile provided the singing voice and mandolin performance of Wendell in the [[Country Bear Jamboree#Musical Jamboree|Country Bear Musical Jamboree]] at [[Walt Disney World]]'s [[Magic Kingdom]].\n\n===''A Prairie Home Companion / Live from Here''===\n{{main|Live from Here}}\n[[File:2016-01-30CarlileJaroszThilePunchBrosAPHC.jpg|thumb|right|Thile hosting ''A Prairie Home Companion'' with guest [[Brandi Carlile]]]]\nThile made his first appearance on [[Garrison Keillor]]'s radio show ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' in 1996, at age 15 and has returned numerous times\u2014as a solo artist, with Nickel Creek, and with Punch Brothers. On February 7 and 14 in 2015 and January 30 and February 6, 2016, he was the show's guest host. \n<ref>{{cite web\n |url          = http://prairiehome.org/special-guest-host-chris-thile-february-2015/\n |title        = Special Guest Host Chris Thile \u2013 February 7 & 14, 2015\n |author       = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->\n |date         = February 3, 2015\n |website      = prairiehome.org\n |access-date  = 2015-04-03\n |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304084457/http://prairiehome.org/special-guest-host-chris-thile-february-2015/\n |archive-date = March 4, 2016\n |url-status     = dead\n |df           = mdy-all\n}}</ref> On July 21, 2015, Keillor officially announced that he was leaving the show and that Thile would succeed him as permanent host in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |\nurl= http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/chris-thile-become-full-time-host-prairie-home-companion|\ntitle= It's official: chris thile to become full time host of 'a prairie home companion'|\nauthor=Cameron Matthews |\ndate= July 21, 2015|\nwebsite= thebluegrasssituation.com|\naccess-date= 2015-07-21\n}}</ref>  Thile's first show as host took place on October 15, 2016, at the [[Fitzgerald Theater]] in St. Paul.<ref name=\"Bream20161015\"/> On February 18, 2017, Thile announced that his version of the show had been renewed for another season.  On December 16, 2017, at the Town Hall theater in New York, Thile announced that the show would be renamed ''[[Live from Here]]''. The show continued airing live on public radio until its final show, on May 30, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Live from Here with Chris Thile Episodes|url=https://www.livefromhere.org/shows|access-date=2020-07-30|website=www.livefromhere.org|language=en|archive-date=June 26, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200626070025/https://www.livefromhere.org/shows|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[American Public Media]], the producer of the show, halted production as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic's effect on shows with live audiences;<ref>{{Cite web|title=About the Show {{!}} Live from Here with Chris Thile|url=https://www.livefromhere.org/pages/about|access-date=2020-07-30|website=www.livefromhere.org|language=en}}</ref> on June 14, 2020, Minnesota Public Radio announced the show's cancellation.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Hudak |first1=Joseph |title='Live From Here With Chris Thile' Canceled Because of COVID-19 Pandemic |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/live-from-here-chris-thile-canceled-covid-1016113/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=8 July 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n* 1996 \u2013 Nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance]] for \"Scotland\" from ''True Life Blues: The Songs of [[Bill Monroe]]''\n* 1997 \u2013 [[International Bluegrass Music Association|IBMA]] award for Album of the Year for ''True Life Blues: The Songs of [[Bill Monroe]]''\n* 2001 \u2013 IBMA award for Mandolinist of the Year\n* 2002 \u2013 Won [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album]] for ''[[This Side]]'' (with [[Nickel Creek]])\n* 2005 \u2013 Nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical]] for ''[[Deceiver (Chris Thile album)|Deceiver]]''\n* 2006 \u2013 Nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance]] for \"The Eleventh Reel\"\n* 2007 \u2013 [[BBC]]'s Folk Musician of the Year\n* 2007 \u2013 Nominated for IBMA Mandolinist of the Year\n* 2008 \u2013 Nominated for [[Americana Music Association]] Instrumentalist of the Year\n* 2012 \u2013 Nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]] for ''Sleep with One Eye Open'' (with Michael Daves)\n* 2012 \u2013 MacArthur Fellowship ($500,000 'Genius Grant')\n* 2013 \u2013 Won [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album]] for ''[[The Goat Rodeo Sessions]]'' (with [[Yo-Yo Ma]], [[Stuart Duncan]], and [[Edgar Meyer]])\n* 2014 \u2013 Won [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Instrumental Album]] for ''Bass & Mandolin'' (with [[Edgar Meyer]])<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2015-nominees-winners-list-story.html#page=1 \"Grammys 2015: Complete list of winners and nominees\"]. ''Los Angeles Times''.</ref>\n* 2015 \u2013 Awarded Honorary Doctorate from [[The New School]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newschool.edu/pressroom/pressreleases/2014/CommencementPost.htm |title=ZADIE SMITH ADDRESSES NEW SCHOOL GRADUATES |date=2014-05-23 }}</ref>\n* 2019 \u2013 Won [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album]] for ''[[All Ashore (album)|All Ashore]]'' (with [[Punch Brothers]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/02/10/693166443/2019-grammy-awards-the-full-list-of-winners |title=2019 Grammy Awards: The Full List Of Winners |publisher=NPR |date=2019-02-10 |access-date=2019-03-15}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Solo===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"6\" | Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]\n! [EP]\n* 2015: ''[[The Phosphorescent Blues]]''\n* 2015: ''The Wireless'' [EP]\n* 2018: ''[[All Ashore (album)|All Ashore]]''\n* 2022: ''[[Hell on Church Street]]''\n\n===Mutual Admiration Society===\n* 2004 ''[[Mutual Admiration Society (album)|Mutual Admiration Society]]'' ([[Nickel Creek]] and [[Glen Phillips (singer)|Glen Phillips]])\n\n===Theme park attractions===\n* 2024 ''[[Country Bear Jamboree#Musical Jamboree|Country Bear Musical Jamboree]]'' (Wendell,Zeke)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}\n\n==External links==\n{{commons category|Chris Thile}}\n* {{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/chris-thile-mn0000779146/biography|title=Chris Thile \u2013 Biography \u2013 AllMusic|author=Linda Seida|work=AllMusic|access-date=February 13, 2015}}\n* {{cite web |url=http://www.waynerice.com/bgbios/index.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321201702/http://www.waynerice.com/bgbios/index.htm |archive-date=March 21, 2009 |title=Bluegrass Bios}}\n* {{Discogs artist}}\n\n==Multimedia==\n* [https://web.archive.org/web/20080320095521/http://www.woodsongs.com/showlist.asp Listen and/or watch Chris Thile on 5 episodes] of the [[WoodSongs Old-Time Radio Hour]]: No.&nbsp;165 as a member of [[Nickel Creek]]; Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Del_McCoury","to":"Del McCoury"}],"pages":{"2253954":{"pageid":2253954,"ns":0,"title":"Del McCoury","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American bluegrass musician}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2023}}\n{{third-party|date=March 2013}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Del McCoury\n| image           = Del-mccoury-fls.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| caption         = McCoury in 2007\n| birth_name      = Delano Floyd McCoury\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1939|2|1}}\n| birth_place     = [[Bakersville, North Carolina]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bluegrasshall.org/inductees/delano-floyd-del-mccoury/#:~:text=Delano%20Floyd%20%E2%80%9CDel%E2%80%9D%20McCoury%20was,York%20County%20in%20southeastern%20Pennsylvania |title=Hall of Fame Inductees: Del McCoury |website=Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame & Museum |access-date=January 17, 2021}}</ref> or [[York, Pennsylvania]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.delmccouryband.com/|title=Del McCoury Band|website=Del McCoury Band}}</ref>\n| death_date      =\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Old-time music|old-time]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer, musician\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, banjo\n| years_active    = 1958\u2013present\n| label           = [[Rounder Records]], McCoury Music\n| current_member_of = [[Del McCoury Band]]\n| past_member_of = [[The GrooveGrass Boyz]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.delmccouryband.com}}\n}}\n'''Delano Floyd McCoury''' (born February 1, 1939) is an American [[bluegrass music]]ian. As leader of the [[Del McCoury Band]], he plays guitar and sings lead vocals along with his two sons, [[Ronnie McCoury]] and [[Rob McCoury]], who play mandolin and banjo respectively. In June 2010, he received a [[National Heritage Fellowship]] lifetime achievement award from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] and in 2011 he was elected into the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame]].\n\n==Career==\nMcCoury has had a long career in bluegrass. Although originally hired as banjo player, he sang lead vocals and played rhythm guitar for [[Bill Monroe]]'s Blue Grass Boys in 1963,<ref>{{cite book |first1=Kurt |last1=Wolff |first2=Orla |last2=Duane |title=Country Music: The Rough Guide |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Jorozp1yp4C&pg=PA234 |year=2000 |publisher=[[Rough Guides]] |isbn=978-1-85828-534-4 |pages=234\u2013235}}</ref> with whom he first appeared on the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]''. McCoury briefly appeared with the [[Golden State Boys]] in 1964 before taking a series of day jobs in construction and logging, while continuing to work as an amateur musician in Maryland, Virginia and Pennsylvania.<ref name=\"GACTV\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/musicbeat/dmccoury120505.html |title=Del McCoury makes bluegrass a family affair |website=[[Great American Family|GACTV]] |date=December 5, 2005 |access-date=February 11, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060110154435/http://www.gactv.com/musicbeat/dmccoury120505.html |archive-date=January 10, 2006}}</ref>\n\nIn the 1980s his sons began performing with him. Fiddler [[Tad Marks]] and bass player Mike Brantley joined McCoury's group in early 1990s. McCoury's group toured widely throughout the US.<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Kingsbury |editor-first=Paul |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=untabCgOVkgC&dq=del+McCoury&pg=PA335 |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=1998 |page=335 |isbn=9780199770557}}</ref> They relocated to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] as they began to attract attention. Fiddler Jason Carter and bassist Mike Bub joined in 1992. Alan Bartram joined the band as bassist in 2005. McCoury became a member of the Grand Ole Opry in October 2003.\n\nMcCoury was also one of many performers at [[The Clearwater Concert]] at Madison Square Garden on May 3, 2009. The event celebrated the 90th birthday of [[Pete Seeger]].\n\nMcCoury has influenced a great number of bands, including [[Phish]], with whom he has shared the stage several times,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://phish.net/setlists/2000.html |title=Setlists: 2000 |website=Phish.net}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://phish.net/setlists/1999.html |title=Setlists: 1999 |website=Phish.net}}</ref> and who have covered his songs.<ref name=\"coversproject.com\">{{cite web |title=Del McCoury Band |url=https://www.coversproject.com/artist/del%20mccoury%20band |website=The Covers Project |access-date=May 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180220151920/https://www.coversproject.com/artist/del%20mccoury%20band |archive-date=February 20, 2018}}</ref> He has also performed with [[The String Cheese Incident]] and [[Donna the Buffalo]], and recorded with [[Steve Earle]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Schulman |first1=David |title=Del McCoury: Old-School Music, New Audience |url=https://www.npr.org/2005/06/20/4684144/del-mccoury-old-school-music-new-audience |access-date=May 27, 2023 |work=Morning Edition |publisher=NPR |date=June 20, 2005}}</ref> McCoury has covered songs by artists as diverse as [[The Lovin' Spoonful]], [[Tom Petty]], and [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]].<ref name=\"coversproject.com\" /> McCoury has appeared at festivals including [[Bonnaroo]], [[High Sierra Music Festival|High Sierra]],<ref name=\"GACTV\" /> the [[Hardly Strictly Bluegrass]], The Telluride Bluegrass Festival, and the [[Newport Folk Festival]].<ref name=\"delmccouryband.com\">{{cite web |title=Del McCoury Band News |url=http://www.delmccouryband.com/news.cfm |website=Del McCoury Band |access-date=May 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721155218/http://www.delmccouryband.com/news.cfm |archive-date=July 21, 2006}}</ref> His television appearances include ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' and the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''.<ref name=\"delmccouryband.com\" /> Del has a very enthusiastic fan base, known as the [[Del-Heads]].\n\n[[Image:Del McCoury Band OSMF 2013 - Ron Baker.jpg|right|thumb|Del McCoury Band \u2013 Old Settler's Music Festival (2013)]]\n\nIn October 2009, The Del McCoury Band began offering fans recordings of their performances on [[USB flash drives]] available immediately after their concerts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aderra.net/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=4&products_id=11 |title=The del McCoury Band Live in Chico CA &#91;20091128DELMC&#93; - $25.00 : Live Concert Recordings on Flash Drives, Aderra USB live music Recordings |website=aderra.net |access-date=January 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091227023832/http://aderra.net/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=4&products_id=11 |archive-date=December 27, 2009 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2010, McCoury received a lifetime achievement award from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] in the field of folk and traditional arts, including a stipend of $25,000.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/24/nea-will-honor-18-artists/ |title=NEA Will Honor 18 Artists |first=Kate |last=Taylor |department=ArtsBeat |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 24, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, he joined the 11th<ref>{{cite web |url=https://independentmusicawards.com/judges/11th-annual-ima-judges/ |title=11th Annual IMA Judges |website=Independent Music Awards |access-date=September 4, 2013}}</ref> annual Independent Music Awards judging panel to assist independent musicians' careers.\n\n==DelFest==\n[[Image:Del McCoury Band Delfest 2009.jpg|thumb|right|Del McCoury Band at 2nd Annual [[DelFest]] (2009)]]\nIn 2008, Del McCoury started [[DelFest]], an annual bluegrass festival in [[Cumberland, Maryland|Cumberland]], Maryland, held at the [[Allegany County Fairgrounds]].<ref name=\"DelFest\">{{Cite web|url=http://delfest.com/|title=Home|website=DelFest.com}}</ref> Del McCoury Band plays every night at each of the festivals.\n\nThe 5th annual DelFest occurred in May 2012,<ref name=\"DelFest\" /> and major bluegrass acts played such as [[Steve Martin]] with the [[Steep Canyon Rangers]], [[Yonder Mountain String Band]], [[Leftover Salmon]], [[Infamous Stringdusters]], [[Railroad Earth]], [[B\u00e9la Fleck]], and [[Sam Bush]], most of which had returned from previous years at the festival.\n\nIn previous years, acts such [[Peter Rowan]], [[David Grisman]], [[Jesse McReynolds]], [[The Avett Brothers]], [[Old Crow Medicine Show]], [[Trampled by Turtles]], [[Greensky Bluegrass]], and [[Psychograss]] have played.\n\nThe 14th DelFest occurred in May 2022, after a two-year delay caused by the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref name=\"DelFest\" />\n\n==Discography==\n\n[[Image:HSB 2005 - Del McCoury.jpg|right|thumb|Del McCoury \u2013 Hardly Strictly Bluegrass (2005)]]\n\n===Solo albums===\n* 1968: ''Del McCoury Sings Bluegrass'' ([[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]]) reissued in 1992 as ''I Wonder Where You Are Tonight'' with two previously unissued tracks\n* 1971: ''Livin' on the Mountain'' ([[Rebel Records|Rebel]]) released in 1976\n* 1971: ''Collector's Special'' (Grassound) released in 1976\n* 1974: ''Our Kind of Grass'' ([[Rebel Records|Rebel]] SLP-1569) released in 1978\n* 1975: ''\tDel McCoury'' ([[Rebel Records|Rebel]] SLP 1542)\n* 1988: ''Don't Stop The Music'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]])\n\n===With [[The GrooveGrass Boyz]]===\n*1998: ''GrooveGrass\u00ae 101 featuring the GrooveGrass Boyz\u2122''\n\n===With the [[Del McCoury Band]]===\n{{main|Del McCoury Band}}\n\n*1992: ''Blue Side of Town''\n*1993: ''A Deeper Shade of Blue''\n*1996: ''The Cold Hard Facts''\n*1999: ''[[The Mountain (Steve Earle album)|The Mountain]]'' <small>(with [[Steve Earle]])</small>\n*1999: ''The Family''\n*2001: ''Del and the Boys''\n*2003: ''It's Just the Night''\n*2005: ''[[The Company We Keep]]''\n*2006: ''The Promised Land''\n*2008: ''Moneyland''\n*2009: ''Family Circle''\n*2011: ''American Legacies'' <small>(with the [[Preservation Hall Jazz Band]])</small>\n*2012: ''Old Memories''\n*2013: ''The Streets of Baltimore''\n*2016: ''Del and [[Woody Guthrie|Woody]]''\n*2017: ''Del McCoury Still Sings Bluegrass''\n\n===As the McCoury Brothers (with Jerry McCoury)===\n* 1987: ''The McCoury Brothers'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]])\n\n===With the Dixie Pals===\n* 1973: ''High on a Mountain'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]])\n* 1975: ''Del McCoury And The Dixie Pals'' (Revonah R-916)\n* 1980: ''Live in Japan'' (Copper Creek)\n* 1981: ''Take Me To The Mountains'' (Leather LBG-8107) reissued in 1983 as [[Rebel Records|Rebel]] REB 1622)\n* 1983: ''Best Of Del McCoury And The Dixie Pals'' ([[Rebel Records|Rebel]] REB 1610)\n* 1985: ''Sawmill'' ([[Rebel Records|Rebel]] REB 1636)\n* 1991: ''Classic Bluegrass'' ([[Rebel Records|Rebel]]) compilation of 1974-1984 Rebel Records recordings\n\n===With [[Mac Wiseman]] and [[Doc Watson]]===\n* 1998: [[Del Doc & Mac]] ([[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]])\n\n===Also appears on===\n* 2011: [[Audie Blaylock]] and Redline - ''I'm Going Back to Old Kentucky: A Bill Monroe Celebration'' (Rural Rhythm)\n\n==Awards and honors==\nDel McCoury has won 31 [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] Awards, including Entertainer of the Year four consecutive times<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pollstar.com/news/viewhotstar.pl?Artist=DELMCR |title=Pollstar -- HotStar the del McCoury Band |access-date=February 11, 2006 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060209045124/http://pollstar.com/news/viewhotstar.pl?Artist=DELMCR |archive-date=February 9, 2006}}</ref> (nine total<ref name=\"delmccouryband.com\" />). McCoury has also won IBMA Male Vocalist of the Year four times. In 2004 he was nominated for the Best Bluegrass Album [[Grammy Award]] for ''It's Just The Night'', and in 2006 he won his first Grammy Award, in the same category, for ''The Company We Keep''.<ref name=\"delmccouryband.com\" /> In 2014, McCoury was nominated and won his second Grammy Award for ''The Streets of Baltimore''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/del-mccoury |title=Artist: Del McCoury |website=www.grammy.com |publisher=Recording Academy |access-date=January 17, 2021}}</ref> He was a recipient of a 2010 [[National Heritage Fellowship]] awarded by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], which is the United States government's highest honor in the folk and traditional arts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/list?title=&field_year_value=2010 |title=NEA National Heritage Fellowships 2010 |website=www.arts.gov |publisher=National Endowment for the Arts |access-date=January 17, 2021}}</ref> McCoury received the Bluegrass Star Award, presented by the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation, in 2015. The award is bestowed upon bluegrass artists who do an exemplary job of advancing traditional bluegrass music and bringing it to new audiences while preserving its character and heritage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluegrassheritage.org/bluegrass-star-award/|title=Bluegrass Heritage Foundation official website|website=Bluegrassheritage.org|year=2010|access-date=December 28, 2015}}</ref>\n\n===International Bluegrass Music Association Awards===\n[[Image:Mccoury-band.jpg|right|thumb|Del McCoury Band, 2007]]\n\n*1990 Male Vocalist of the Year \u2013 Del McCoury<ref name=\"ecm\">{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PA620|date=January 4, 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-992083-9|pages=620\u2013}}</ref>\n*1991 Male Vocalist of the Year \u2013 Del McCoury\n*1992 Male Vocalist of the Year \u2013 Del McCoury<ref name=\"ecm\" />\n*1994 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Del McCoury Band\n*1994 Album of the Year \u2013 ''A Deeper Shade of Blue''; Del McCoury\n*1996 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Del McCoury Band\n*1996 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 Del McCoury\n*1996 Male Vocalist of the Year \u2013 Del McCoury\n*1997 Instrumental Group of the Year \u2013 The Del McCoury Band\n*1997 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Del McCoury Band\n*1997 Album of the Year \u2013 ''True Life Blues \u2013 The Songs of [[Bill Monroe]]''; [[Sam Bush]], [[Vassar Clements]], Mike Compton, [[Jerry Douglas]], [[Stuart Duncan]], Pat Enright, Greg Garing, [[Richard Greene (fiddle player)|Richard Greene]], David Grier, [[David Grisman]], [[John Hartford]], [[Bobby Hicks]], Kathy Kallick, [[Laurie Lewis]], [[Mike Marshall (musician)|Mike Reischman, [[Peter Rowan]], Craig Smith, [[Chris Thile]], [[Tony Trischka]], [[Roland White]].\n*1998 Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Del McCoury Band<ref name=\"ecm\" />\n*1999 Entertainer of the Entertainer of the Year \u2013 The Del McCoury Band\n*2004 Album of the Year \u2013 ''It's Just the Night''; The Del McCoury Band\n\n==Notes and references==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External
