This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Keith_Whitley","to":"Keith Whitley"}],"pages":{"431125":{"pageid":431125,"ns":0,"title":"Keith Whitley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer (1954\u20131989)}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Keith Whitley\n| image            = KeithWhitley.jpg\n| caption          = Whitley performing in June 1988\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Jackie Keith Whitley<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2019/05/08/keith-whitley-country-music-hall-of-fame-exhibit-lorrie-morgan/1141495001/|title=Keith Whitley's family remembers their father, husband on 30th anniversary of his death|work=Tennessean|date=May 8, 2019}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{birth date|1954|7|1|mf=y}}\n| birth_place      = [[Ashland, Kentucky]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|1989|5|9|1954|7|1|mf=y}}\n| death_place      = [[Goodlettsville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Sandy Hook, Kentucky]], U.S.\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation       = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active     = 1970\u20131989\n| spouse = {{marriage|[[Lorrie Morgan]]|1986}}\n| past_member_of = Clinch Mountain Boys, [[New South (band)|New South]]\n| label            = [[RCA Records|RCA]]\n}}\n'''Jackie Keith Whitley''' (July 1, 1954 \u2013 May 9, 1989) was an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. During his career, he released only two albums but charted 12 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, and 7 more after his death.\n\nBorn in [[Ashland, Kentucky]], Whitley grew up in nearby [[Sandy Hook, Kentucky]]. He began his career there in 1970, performing in [[Ralph Stanley]]'s band. Establishing himself as a lead singer in bluegrass music, Whitley moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 1983 and began his recording career there. His first Top 20 Country Hit single, \"[[Miami, My Amy]]\", was released in 1986. In 1988, his first three singles from his studio album ''[[Don't Close Your Eyes (album)|Don't Close Your Eyes]]'', the [[Don't Close Your Eyes (Keith Whitley song)|title song]], \"[[When You Say Nothing at All]]\" and \"[[I'm No Stranger to the Rain]]\" were number one hits. Years of alcoholism severely compromised his health and he died of alcohol intoxication in 1989 at his Goodlettsville home at the age of 34. His later singles, \"[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me (song)|I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]\",  \"[[It Ain't Nothin']]\", and \"[[I'm Over You (Keith Whitley song)|I'm Over You]]\", were released after his death.\n\nIn 2022, Whitley was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"cmhof\">{{cite web | url=https://eu.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2022/05/17/country-music-hall-fame-class-2022-inductees/9805843002/ | title=Keith Whitley, Jerry Lee Lewis and Joe Galante are headed to the Country Music Hall of Fame }}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nWhitley was born to Faye Ferguson (editor of ''The Elliott County News'') and Elmer Whitley (an electrician) in [[Ashland, Kentucky]], but was raised 46 miles away in [[Sandy Hook, Kentucky|Sandy Hook]], and attended Sandy Hook High School.<ref name=HicksJ-TKP-1991-09-25>Hicks, Jack. \u2013 \"Singer Keith Whitley's Memory Alive Through Songs, Love in Home Town\". \u2013 ''[[The Cincinnati Post|The Kentucky Post]]''. \u2013 September 25, 1991.</ref><ref name=LH-L-1989-05-10>\"Country Music Star Keith Whitley Dead at 33\". \u2013 ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]''. \u2013 May 10, 1989.</ref> He had two brothers, Randy and Dwight, and a sister, Mary.<ref name=LockwoodFE-LH-L-1998-06-27>Lockwood, Frank E. \u2013 \"Bikers, Sandy Hook Pay Tribute to Favorite Son\". \u2013 Lexington Herald-Leader (KY) \u2013 Saturday, June 27, 1998.</ref><ref name=LockwoodFE-LH-L-1999-06-28>Lockwood, Frank E. \u2013 \"Singing in Rain\". \u2013 Lexington Herald-Leader (KY) \u2013 Saturday, June 28, 1999.</ref> The Whitley family is of [[English Americans|English]] and [[Scotch-Irish Americans|Scots-Irish]] descent and has lived in the [[Elliott County, Kentucky|Elliott County]] area since the 1840s.\n\nWhile Whitley was a teenager in Sandy Hook, he and his friends would pass the time drinking [[Rum-running|bootleg]] [[Bourbon whiskey|bourbon]] and racing their cars down mountain roads at dangerous speeds. Whitley was once in a car whose driver attempted to round a curve at {{convert|120|mph|kph}}. The car wrecked, killing his friend and almost breaking Whitley's neck. In another incident, he drove his car off a {{convert|120|ft|m|adj=on}} cliff into a frozen river, escaping with only a broken [[collar bone]].<ref name=AP>Associated Press \u2013 \"Whitley Just Getting Started Despite 18-Year Music Career\". \u2013 Salina Journal (KS) \u2013 Thursday, October 27, 1988.</ref>\n\nWhitley's older brother Randy was killed in an October 1983 motorcycle accident.<ref name=\"HicksJ-TKP-1991-09-25\" /><ref name=\"LockwoodFE-LH-L-1998-06-27\" />\n\n==Musical career==\nWhitley is known for his neotraditional brand of country popularized by hit artists such as [[George Strait]] and [[Randy Travis]].\n\nIn 1969, he performed in a musical contest in [[Ezel, Kentucky]], with brother Dwight on five-string banjo. [[Ricky Skaggs]] was also in the contest. Skaggs and Whitley instantly bonded and subsequently became close friends.<ref name=RoweN-RT-D-1986-04-20>Rowe, Norman. \u2013 Album Echoes Country Classics\". \u2013 ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''. \u2013 April 20, 1986</ref>\n\nWhitley and Skaggs, both sixteen years old, were discovered in Ft. Gay, West Virginia, by [[Ralph Stanley]], who was 45 minutes late for a gig due to a flat tire.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Stanley opened the door of the club and heard what he thought was the [[Stanley Brothers]] playing on a jukebox. However, it was Whitley and Skaggs, who \"sounded just like me and Carter in the early days\".{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} The two soon joined Stanley's band. Whitley became lead singer for Stanley in 1974.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}  Whitley also played with [[J.D. Crowe & the New South]] in the mid-1970s.<ref name=AP/> During this period, he established himself as one of the most versatile and talented lead singers in bluegrass. His singing was heavily influenced by [[Carter Stanley]] and [[Lefty Frizzell]]. He moved to [[Nashville]] in 1983 to pursue a country music career and soon signed a record deal with [[RCA Records]].<ref name=AP/>\n\nWhitley's first solo album, ''A Hard Act to Follow'', was released in 1984, and featured a more mainstream country style. While Whitley was working hard to achieve his own style, the songs he produced were inconsistent. Critics regarded the album as too erratic. Whitley honed his sound within the next few years for his next album, ''L.A. to Miami''.\n\n''L.A. to Miami'', released in 1985, would give him his first Top 20 country hit single, \"Miami, My Amy\". The song was followed by three more hit songs: \"Ten Feet Away\", \"Homecoming '63\", and \"Hard Livin'\", The album also included \"[[On the Other Hand]]\" and \"[[Nobody in His Right Mind Would've Left Her]]\". \"On the Other Hand\" was pitched to Whitley before [[Randy Travis]] released the song as a single and when Whitley's version wasn't released as a single, Travis released his in 1986, as did [[George Strait]] with \"Nobody in His Right Mind Would've Left Her\".\n\nDuring his tour to promote ''L.A. to Miami'', he met and began a romantic relationship with country singer [[Lorrie Morgan]]. They were married in November 1986 and  had their only child, a son, Jesse Keith Whitley in June 1987. Whitley also adopted Lorrie's daughter, Morgan, from her first marriage.\n\nDuring the new recording sessions in 1987, Whitley began feeling that the songs he was  were not up to his standards, so he approached RCA and asked if the project of 15 songs could be shelved. He also asked if he could take a major role in creating the songs and in production. The new album, titled ''[[Don't Close Your Eyes (album)|Don't Close Your Eyes]]'', was released in 1988, and the album sold extremely well. The album contained one of the many songs that Whitley had a hand in writing in his years at Tree Publishing, \"It's All Coming Back to Me Now\". On the album was a remake of [[Lefty Frizzell]]'s classic standard \"I Never Go Around Mirrors,\" and the song became a huge hit at Whitley's concerts. The first three singles from the album\u2014\"When You Say Nothing at All,\" \"I'm No Stranger to the Rain,\" and the title cut\u2014all reached No. 1 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s country charts during the autumn of 1988 and the winter of 1989, with the title track \"Don't Close Your Eyes\" being ranked as ''Billboard''\u2019s No. 1 Country song of 1988. Shortly thereafter, \"I'm No Stranger to the Rain\" also earned Whitley his first and only [[Country Music Association]] award as a solo artist and a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance|Best Country Vocal Performance, Male]].\n\nIn early 1989, Whitley approached RCA chairman [[Joe Galante]] with the intention of releasing \"I Never Go Around Mirrors\" as a single. Galante approved of the musical flexibility that Whitley achieved with the song; however, he suggested that Whitley record something new and more upbeat. The result was a song Whitley had optioned for his previous album called ''[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]'', and was to result in his next album release.\n\nWhitley was scheduled to be invited to join the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]'' in late May 1989. He was posthumously inducted as a former member on October 14, 2023, in a tribute concert held during that night's ''Opry'' broadcast.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Keith Whitley to be celebrated by Garth Brooks, more, at October Opry event |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/09/15/keith-whitley-to-be-celebrated-by-garth-brooks-more-at-october-opry-event/70863977007/ |access-date=2023-10-15 |website=The Tennessean |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Death==\nOn May 9, 1989, Whitley had a brief phone call with his mother and was later visited by his brother-in-law, Lane Palmer.  The two had coffee and were planning a day of golf and lunch, after which Whitley planned to start writing songs for him and Lorrie Morgan to record when she returned from her concert tour. Palmer left at approximately {{nowrap|8:30 a.m.}},<ref name=JinkinsS-FWST-1997-10-14>Jinkins, Shirley. \u2013 \"A country music love story of death, drinking and devotion\". \u2013 ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]''. \u2013 October 14, 1997.</ref> asking Whitley to be ready to leave within an hour. Upon returning, Palmer found Whitley unresponsive on his bed and called an ambulance. Whitley was taken to the hospital where he was pronounced dead. He was 34.\n\nThe official cause of death was acute ethanolism ([[alcohol poisoning]]).<ref name=LH-L-1989-05-10 /> [[Davidson County, Tennessee|Davidson County]] Medical Examiner Charles Harlan stated that Whitley's blood alcohol level was 0.47 (the equivalent of 20 one-ounce shots of 100-[[proof (alcohol)|proof]] whiskey).<ref>\"Alcohol Cuts Short a promising career\". \u2013 [[Associated Press]]. \u2013 (c/o ''[[Salina Journal]]''). \u2013 August 10, 1989.</ref><ref>Edwards, Joe. \u2013 \"Keith Whitley discovered dead \u2013 Alcohol overdose cause of death\". \u2013 ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]''. \u2013 May 10, 1989.</ref><ref name=AP-CT-1989-05-10>\"Country Singer Keith Whitley, 33\". \u2013 [[Associated Press]]. \u2013 (c/o ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''). \u2013 May 10, 1989.</ref><ref>Hurst, Jack. \u2013 \"Whitley's Last Days\". \u2013 ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. \u2013 May 14, 1989.</ref><ref>Green, Barbara. \u2013 \"Whitley Fans Hate 'To See a Good Man Go To Waste\". \u2013 ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''. \u2013 May 17, 1989.</ref> He was born in 1954 per his birth certificate and passport, but RCA and his [[Headstone|grave marker]] erroneously recorded his birth year as 1955.<ref name=WhitburnJ-TBBofT40CH-p382>Whitburn, Joel (2006). \u2013 ''The Billboard Book of Top 40 Country Hits''. \u2013 Second Edition. \u2013 New York: Billboard Books. \u2013 p.382. \u2013 {{ISBN|978-0-8230-8291-9}}.</ref><ref name=\"Birth-Year\">Stambler, Irwin, and Grelun Landon (2000). \u2013 ''Country Music: The Encyclopedia''. \u2013 New York: St. Martin's Press. \u2013 p.533. \u2013 {{ISBN|978-0-312-26487-1}}.<br />\u2014Carlin, Richard (2003). \u2013 ''Country Music: A Biographical Dictionary''. \u2013 New York: Routledge \u2013 p.427. \u2013 {{ISBN|978-0-415-93802-0}}.<br />\u2014Larkin, Colin (1995). \u2013 ''The Guinness Encyclopedia of Popular Music''. \u2013 New York: Stockton Press \u2013 P.4462. \u2013 {{ISBN|978-0-85112-662-3}}.<br />\u2014Stanton, Scott (2003). \u2013 ''The Tombstone Tourist: Musicians''. \u2013 New York: Pocket Books. \u2013 p.395. \u2013 {{ISBN|978-0-7434-6330-0}}.<br />\u2014Hicks, Jack. \u2013 \"Singer Keith Whitley's Memory Alive Through Songs, Love in Home Town\". \u2013 ''[[The Cincinnati Post|The Kentucky Post]]''. \u2013 September 25, 1991.<br />\u2014\"Country Music Star Keith Whitley Dead at 33\". \u2013 ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]''. \u2013 May 10, 1989.<br />\u2014Hurst, Jack. \u2013 \"Whitley's Last Days\". \u2013 ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. \u2013 May 14, 1989.<br />\u2014\"Alcohol Kills Country Singer Keith Whitley\". \u2013 [[United Press International]]. \u2013 (c/o ''[[The San Francisco Chronicle]]''). \u2013 May 10, 1989.</ref>\n\nThe day after his death, [[Music Row]] was lined with black ribbons in memory of Whitley. He is buried in the [[Spring Hill Cemetery (Nashville)|Spring Hill Cemetery]] outside [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]. His gravestone reads, \"Forever yours faithfully\" (part one) and \"His being was my reason\" (part two).\n\n==Posthumous releases==\nAt the time of his death, Whitley had just finished work on his third and final studio album, ''[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]''. The album was released three months after his death, on August 1, 1989. The album produced two more No.&nbsp;1 hits, with the title track and \"It Ain't Nothin'.\" \"I'm Over You\" also was in the Top 5 in early 1990, reaching No. 3.\n\nTwo new songs were added to \"Greatest Hits\": The first, \"Tell Lorrie I Love Her\" was written and recorded at home by Whitley for Morgan, originally intended as a work tape for Whitley's friend Curtis 'Mr. Harmony' Young to sing at Whitley's wedding. The second was \"'Til a Tear Becomes a Rose\", a 1987 demo taken from Tree that originally featured harmony vocals by childhood friend Ricky Skaggs. Lorrie Morgan, with creative control and license to Whitley's namesake, recorded her voice alongside Whitley's, and released it as a single, which rose to No. 13 and won them 1990's CMA award for Best Vocal Collaboration as well as a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Vocal Collaboration]].\n\nRCA also released a compilation of performance clips (from his days in the Ralph Stanley-Fronted Clinch Mountain Boys), interviews, and some previously unreleased material under the title \"Kentucky Bluebird\". The album produced hits for Whitley as well, including a duet with [[Earl Thomas Conley]], named \"Brotherly Love,\" which peaked at No. 2 in late 1991 and gave Whitley his second consecutive posthumous Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Vocal Collaboration]].\n\nIn 1994, Whitley's widow, Lorrie Morgan, organized several of Whitley's friends in bluegrass and some of the big names in country at the time to record a [[tribute]] album to Whitley. The album, ''[[Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album]]'', was released in September 1994 via BNA. It included covers of Whitley's songs from artists such as [[Alan Jackson]], [[Diamond Rio]], and Ricky Skaggs. The album also included four previously unreleased tracks recorded by Whitley in 1987, one of which had Morgan dubbed in as a duet partner. The album also included two original songs: \"Little Boy Lost\", co-written and sung by [[Daron Norwood]], and \"A Voice Still Rings True\", a multi-artist song.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1994/08/11/crowning-touch-3/|title=Crowning Touch 'Red Hot + Country' Album Delayed To Include Crosby, Stills And Nash|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=August 11, 1994|work=[[The Chicago Tribune]]|access-date=February 17, 2014}}</ref> [[Alison Krauss]]'s rendition of \"When You Say Nothing at All\" was released as a single from the album, reaching number 3 on the country charts in 1995.\n\nIn 1995, the album ''Wherever You Are Tonight'' was released, produced by Lorrie Morgan, featuring restored demos of 1986\u20131988, with crisper 1990s recording techniques and a full orchestra. The album and single of the same name both did very well on the Billboard and R&R charts and \"Super Hits\" and \"The Essential Keith Whitley\" followed in 1996. \"The Essential\" contained the remastered and long since unavailable LP and Whitley's debut, the 6-Track \"A Hard Act to Follow\", and a scrapped song from 1986's \"LA to Miami\", \"I Wonder Where You Are Tonight\".\n\n==Legacy==\nSeveral film projects depicting Whitley's life were slated, but none have come to fruition. One idea was a film version of the George Vescey-Lorrie Morgan-penned ''Forever Yours, Faithfully''. While Morgan's book was a benchmark in piecing together Whitley's final moments, perhaps the most research went into a project titled ''Kentucky Bluebird'', which was to star writer/actor/director [[David L. Keith|David Keith]]. This project was in [[development hell]] for several years, and was halted in late 2006 after difficulties with casting and funding. Another film project, started in 2004 by songwriter Jeff Swope, was a biopic chronicling Whitley's life and passing. The last information about the project came in 2010, when he announced that pre-production was set to begin, pending investors.<ref>Mirrors, The Keith Whitley Story \u2013 [[WordPress]], April 13, 2010</ref>\n\nDespite his brief moment in the spotlight, Whitley's legacy remains.<ref name=\"Watts 2019 m180\">{{cite web | last=Watts | first=Cindy | title=Keith Whitley's family remembers him on 30th anniversary of his death | website=The Tennessean | date=May 8, 2019 | url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2019/05/08/keith-whitley-country-music-hall-of-fame-exhibit-lorrie-morgan/1141495001/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"Morris 2009 u881\">{{cite web | last=Morris | first=<!-- -->Edward | title=Keith Whitley's Musical Legacy Endures Two Decades After His Death | website=CMT | date=May 8, 2009 | url=https://www.cmt.com/news/ijbw6b/keith-whitleys-musical-legacy-endures-two-decades-after-his-death | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221206210924/https://www.cmt.com/news/ijbw6b/keith-whitleys-musical-legacy-endures-two-decades-after-his-death | url-status=dead | archive-date=December 6, 2022 | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> He was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2022;<ref name=\"cmhof\"/> prior to that, he was the subject of an exhibit detailing his life and legacy.<ref name=\"Hall 2019 z408\">{{cite web | last=Hall | first=Kristin M. | title=New exhibit shows Keith Whitley's tragic, but lasting legacy | website=The Seattle Times | date=May 3, 2019 | url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/new-exhibit-shows-keith-whitleys-tragic-but-lasting-legacy/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> Whitley retains a persistent influence on country artists, including [[Tim McGraw]], [[Ronnie Dunn]], and [[Dierks Bentley]].<ref name=\"Roland Roland 2014 w795\">{{cite magazine | last=Roland | first=Tom | title=How Keith Whitley's Conflicted Legacy Spawned an 'Authentic' Country Revival | magazine=Billboard | date=May 6, 2014 | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/keith-whitley-jake-worthington-the-voice-country-authentic-6077549/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> Newer artists like [[Morgan Wallen]] are among his progenitors; a song named after Whitley features on Wallen's 2023 double album, ''[[One Thing at a Time]]'',<ref name=\"Nicholson Nicholson 2023 p810\">{{cite magazine | last=Nicholson | first=Jessica | title=Morgan Wallen Celebrates New Album 'One Thing at a Time' For a Packed House in Nashville | magazine=Billboard | date=March 4, 2023 | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/morgan-wallen-one-thing-at-a-time-album-nashville-concert-review-1235279928/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref> which won the approval of Whitley's widow and son.<ref name=\"Country Now 2023 r033\">{{cite web | title=Lorrie Morgan and Jesse Keith Whitley React To Morgan Wallen's New Song That Tributes Keith Whitley | website=Country Now | date=January 12, 2023 | url=https://countrynow.com/lorrie-morgan-and-jesse-keith-whitley-react-to-morgan-wallens-new-song-that-tributes-keith-whitley/ | access-date=September 7, 2023}}</ref>\n\nWhitley is the only person to be posthumously recognized as a former member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]], without ever being an active member. Management had scheduled Whitley for an appearance in late May 1989, where he was to be invited to join, but his death on May 9 interrupted those plans. As the Opry has a policy only inducting living artists as members, Whitley's induction was scrapped. During a Keith Whitley tribute show at the Opry on October 14, 2023, [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Lorrie Morgan]] announced that Whitley's name would be engraved on a plaque and included in the Opry's Member Gallery backstage, alongside every act who has held Opry membership at some point in the show's history, dating to 1925.\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Keith Whitley discography}}\n*1984: ''[[A Hard Act to Follow]]'' (EP)\n*1985: ''[[L.A. to Miami]]''\n*1988: ''[[Don't Close Your Eyes (album)|Don't Close Your Eyes]]''\n*1989: ''[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]''\n*1991: ''[[Kentucky Bluebird]]''\n*1995: ''[[Wherever You Are Tonight]]''\n*2000: ''Sad Songs & Waltzes''\n\n===''Billboard'' number-one hits===\n*\"[[Don't Close Your Eyes (Keith Whitley song)|Don't Close Your Eyes]]\" (1 week, 1988)\n*\"[[When You Say Nothing at All]]\" (2 weeks, 1988)\n*\"[[I'm No Stranger to the Rain]]\" (2 weeks, 1989)\n*\"[[I Wonder Do You Think of Me (song)|I Wonder Do You Think of Me]]\" (1 week, 1989)\n*\"[[It Ain't Nothin']]\" (1 week, 1990)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n=== Grammy Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[32nd Grammy Awards|1990]]\n|\"[[I'm No Stranger to the South (band) members]]\n[[Category:People from Elliott County, Kentucky]]\n[[Category:RCA Records Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Kentucky]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Leslie_Satcher","to":"Leslie Satcher"}],"pages":{"11894886":{"pageid":11894886,"ns":0,"title":"Leslie Satcher","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Leslie Satcher\n| image               = \n| caption             = \n| image_size          = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Leslie Winn Satcher\n| birth_place         = Paris, Texas, U.S.\n| birth_date          = {{birth year and age|1962}}\n| death_date          = \n| origin              = \n| instrument          = Vocals\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]<br>[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1989\u2013present\n| label               = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]\n| website             = http://lesliesatcher.com/\n}}\n\n'''Leslie Winn Satcher''' (born 1962) is a singer-songwriter based in [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]]. She has recorded two albums of her own, and has additionally co-written several singles for such artists as [[George Strait]], [[Martina McBride]], [[Pam Tillis]], [[Gretchen Wilson]], [[Patty Loveless]], and [[Vince Gill]].\n\n==Biography and career==\nLeslie grew up in her birthplace of [[Paris, Texas|Paris]], Texas, United States, where she sang in local churches and schools \u2013 an experience which she lists as one of her biggest influences.<ref>{{cite web| title = Letters From Leslie| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]| year = 2001| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472356/20030606/satcher_leslie.jhtml| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040721/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472356/20030606/satcher_leslie.jhtml| url-status = dead| archive-date = September 30, 2007| accessdate = June 21, 2007  }}</ref> In 1989, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to pursue her dream of being a country music singer, but found a niche writing the songs for which she is most well known \u2013 including many by notable country music acts like [[Patty Loveless]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[Reba McEntire]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Tarradell| first = Mario| title = This train is bound for glory| publisher = [[Dallas Morning News]]| date = April 2, 2002}}</ref><ref name=\"leg\">{{cite web| title = H.C.R. No. 106| publisher = [[Texas State Legislature]]| date = February 2, 2007| url = http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/html/HC00106I.htm| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }}</ref> [[Pam Tillis]] reached No.&nbsp;12 on the country charts in 1998 with Satcher's \"I Said a Prayer\". In 2002, [[Martina McBride]]'s performance of her song \"[[When God-Fearin' Women Get the Blues]]\" reached No.&nbsp;8 in the United States, while her 2006 song \"Politically Uncorrect\", performed by [[Merle Haggard]] and [[Gretchen Wilson]], reached No.&nbsp;23 and was nominated for a Grammy award.<ref>{{cite web| title = Students to perform at Country Music Hall of Fame| publisher = [[Country Music Hall of Fame]]| date = April 2, 2006| url = http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=2025| accessdate = June 21, 2007| url-status = dead| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070501201911/http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com/site/news_detail.aspx?cid=2025| archivedate = May 1, 2007}}</ref>\n\nAt the same time, her singing career also began to take off, following her signing with [[Warner Bros. Records]], and the release of her first album ''[[Love Letters (Leslie Satcher album)|Love Letters]]'' in 2002.<ref name=\"leg\"/> This was followed by the independent release of ''[[Creation (Leslie Satcher album)|Creation]]'' in 2005, which she has been touring to promote.<ref name=\"abc\">{{cite web|last=Mackay |first=Jacquie |title=Who writes the songs for the Nashville greats? |publisher=[[ABC Records|ABC]] |date=April 3, 2006 |url=http://www.abc.net.au/capricornia/stories/s1606735.htm |accessdate=June 21, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819124152/http://www.abc.net.au/capricornia/stories/s1606735.htm |archivedate=August 19, 2006 }}</ref> Her work has met with critical acclaim, with the [[Texas State Legislature]] calling her:\n\n<blockquote>[Able] to craft songs that capture the ears and hearts of music lovers and honoring her [...] for bringing further acclaim to the illustrious musical reputation of the Lone Star State; and, be it further [..] an expression of high regard by the Texas House of Representatives and Senate.<ref name=\"leg\"/></blockquote>\n\n[[USA Today]] listed her as part of a \"groundswell\" in traditional country and bluegrass music.<ref>{{cite web| last = Mansfield| first = Brian| title = O country music, where art thou?| publisher = [[USA Today]]| date = July 9, 2007| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/2001-07-09-country-usat.htm| accessdate = June 21, 2007 }}</ref> Leslie Satcher continues to write and sing, after taking some time off in 2006.<ref name=\"abc\"/>\n\nIn 2008, two songs she co-wrote with [[Monty Holmes]], \"[[Troubadour (song)|Troubadour]]\" and \"House Of Cash\" were recorded by [[George Strait]].\n\nIn 2017, Leslie and The Electric Honey Badgers released the single \"This Won't Take Long\", featuring [[Vince Gill]] and [[Sheryl Crow]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://musicrow.com/2017/09/leslie-satcher-joined-by-vince-gill-sheryl-crow-on-new-single-out-today/|title=Leslie Satcher Joined By Vince Gill, Sheryl Crow On New Single, Out Today|date=September 2, 2017|work=MusicRow \u2013 Nashville's Music Industry Publication \u2013 News, Songs From Music City|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Love Letters (Leslie Satcher album)|Love Letters]]''\n| \n* Release date: November 14, 2000\n* Label: [[Warner Bros. Records]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Creation''\n| \n* Release date: July 18, 2005\n* Label: Jellan Records\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! Album\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love Letters from Old Mexico\"\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Love Letters''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Burn Me Down\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Ode to Billie Joe]]\"\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Slow Way Home\"\n|-\n|2017\n! scope=\"row\"|\"This Won't Take Long\"\n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://lesliesatcher.com/ Leslie Satcher's homepage]\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20040403204357/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/satcher_leslie/artist.jhtml Profile at Country Music Television]\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20070607163634/http://www.csusa.org/caw/caw_2006_press_articles_satcher.htm Leslie Satcher on copyright awareness]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Satcher, Leslie}}\n[[Category:1962 births]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass musicians]]\n[[Category:People from Paris, Texas]]\n[[Category:Warner Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dierks_Bentley","to":"Dierks Bentley"}],"pages":{"2104801":{"pageid":2104801,"ns":0,"title":"Dierks Bentley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician (born 1975)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Dierks Bentley\n| image           = DierksBentleyApr10.jpg\n| caption         = Bentley in 2010\n| alias = Douglas \"Doug\" Douglason\n| birth_name      = Frederick Dierks Bentley<ref>{{cite web|title = Dierks Bentley Reveals the Real Story Behind His Name and How He Knew His Wife Was The One|url = http://www.glamour.com/entertainment/blogs/obsessed/2015/05/dierks-bentley-reveals-the-sto|website = Glamour|access-date = May 28, 2015|first = Glamour|last = Magazine|date = May 26, 2015}}</ref>\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1975|11|20}}<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |last1=Jeffries |first1=David |title=Dierks Bentley |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/dierks-bentley-mn0000825883/biography |website=AllMusic |access-date=July 1, 2018}}</ref>\n| birth_place     = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S.\n| genre           = {{Hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]}}\n| occupation      = Musician, singer-songwriter, record producer\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, banjo, tuba\n| years_active    = 2001\u2013present\n| label           = Dangling Rope, [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]<!-- PLEASE DO NOT ADD ADDITIONAL LABELS WITHOUT A RELIABLE SOURCE. AND DO NOT REMOVE THE NOTE! -->\n| current_member_of = [[Hot Country Knights]]\n| website         = {{URL|dierks.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Frederick Dierks Bentley''' ({{IPAc-en|'|d|\u025c\u02d0r|k|s}}; born November 20, 1975)<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. In 2003, he signed to [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] and released his eponymous [[Dierks Bentley (album)|debut album]]. Both it and its follow-up, 2005's ''[[Modern Day Drifter]]'', are certified Platinum in the United States, and his third album, 2006's ''[[Long Trip Alone]]'', is certified Gold. It was followed in mid-2008 by a greatest hits package. His fourth album, ''[[Feel That Fire]]'', was released in February 2009, and a [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] album, ''[[Up on the Ridge]]'', was released on June 8, 2010. His sixth album, ''[[Home (Dierks Bentley album)|Home]]'', followed in February 2012, as did a seventh one, ''[[Riser (album)|Riser]]'', in 2014. Bentley's eighth album, titled ''[[Black (Dierks Bentley album)|Black]]'', was released in May 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/dierks-bentley-black-details/ |title=Dierks Bentley Reveals Details for Upcoming 'Black' Album |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=March 29, 2016 |access-date=May 27, 2016}}</ref> and his ninth, ''[[The Mountain (Dierks Bentley album)|The Mountain]]'', was released in June 2018. His tenth studio album, ''[[Gravel & Gold]]'',  was released in February 2023.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dierks-bentley-new-song-gold-1389845/ | title=Dierks Bentley Learns to Enjoy the Ride in New Song 'Gold' | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=July 29, 2022 }}</ref>\n\nBentley's studio albums have accounted for 27 singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]] charts, of which 18 have reached No. 1: his debut single, \"[[What Was I Thinkin']]\", \"[[Come a Little Closer (Dierks Bentley song)|Come a Little Closer]]\", \"[[Settle for a Slowdown]]\", \"[[Every Mile a Memory]]\", \"[[Free and Easy (Down the Road I Go)]]\", \"[[Feel That Fire (song)|Feel That Fire]]\", \"[[Sideways (Dierks Bentley song)|Sideways]]\", \"[[Am I the Only One (Dierks Bentley song)|Am I the Only One]]\", \"[[Home (Dierks Bentley song)|Home]]\", \"[[5-1-5-0]]\", \"[[I Hold On]]\", \"[[Drunk on a Plane]]\", \"[[Say You Do (Dierks Bentley song)|Say You Do]]\", \"[[Somewhere on a Beach]]\", \"[[Different for Girls (Dierks Bentley song)|Different for Girls]]\", \"[[Woman, Amen]]\", \"[[Living (song)|Living]]\" and \"[[Beers on Me]]\". Eight more of his singles have reached the top 5.\n\n==Early life==\nBentley was born on November 20, 1975,<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> in [[Phoenix, Arizona]], as the son of Leon Fife Bentley (August 16, 1923 \u2013 June 1, 2012), a bank vice president, and Catherine Childs. His father was born in [[Glasgow, Missouri]], to Richard Thomas Bentley Jr. and Mary Cecile ({{nee}} Fife) Bentley, and was a First Lieutenant in [[World War II]]. His middle name, Dierks (which he now uses as his first name publicly), is also his maternal great-grandmother's surname. He attended Culver Summer Schools and Camps in Indiana<ref>cite web | url=https://alumni.culver.org/page.aspx?pid=903</ref> and graduated from [[Lawrenceville School|The Lawrenceville School]] in New Jersey in 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawrenceville.org/about/history/notable-alumni/index.aspx |title=NOTABLE ALUMNI |publisher=The Lawrenceville School |access-date=October 16, 2014 }}</ref> Afterward, he spent a year at the [[University of Vermont]] (UVM) before transferring to [[Vanderbilt University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where he graduated in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/dierks-bentley-childhood-bruce-springsteen/ |title=Dierks Bentley Opens Up About His Childhood and Finds a Fan in Bruce Springsteen |publisher=Tasteofcountry.com |date=March 22, 2011 |access-date=February 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/espn/thelife/music/news/story?id=6563304 |title=Country music star Dierks Bentley jumps into hockey with both boots  |publisher=ESPN |date=May 24, 2011 |access-date=February 25, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n===2003\u201305: ''Dierks Bentley'' and ''Modern Day Drifter''===\nBentley worked at The Nashville Network (now [[Paramount Network]]), researching old footage of [[Country music|country]] performances. During this time, Bentley was banned from the [[Grand Ole Opry]] for trespassing on the grounds of the Opry House for research purposes, a ban that would be lifted when Bentley's first album was released.<ref>{{Cite web |last=West |first=Lacey |title=Dierks Bentley Is the Only Country Singer To Be Banned By The Grand Ole Opry Before Ever Performing There |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/11/30/dierks-bentley-is-the-only-country-singer-to-be-banned-by-the-grand-ole-opry-before-ever-performing-there/ |access-date=2022-12-02 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref> In 2003, [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] released Bentley's self-titled debut album. The album's first single, \"[[What Was I Thinkin']]\", reached No. 1 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts<ref name=\"Country Songs\">{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=dierks bentley|chart=Country Songs}}|title=Dierks Bentley Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Songs|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=April 28, 2011}}</ref> later that year. The next two singles from the album \u2013 \"[[My Last Name]]\" and \"[[How Am I Doin']]\" \u2013 reached No. 17<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> and No. 4,<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> respectively. The album was certified [[Platinum album|Platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].\n\nBentley's second album, ''[[Modern Day Drifter]]'', was released in 2005. It spawned two No. 1 singles in \"[[Come a Little Closer (Dierks Bentley song)|Come a Little Closer]]\"<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> and \"[[Settle for a Slowdown]]\",<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> as well as the No. 3 hit \"[[Lot of Leavin' Left to Do]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> The album was also certified Platinum.\n\nIn 2005, Bentley won the [[Country Music Association|CMA Award]] for the Horizon Award (now Best New Artist) and was invited to be a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Opry Member List PDF |url=http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf |date=April 23, 2012 |access-date=June 29, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607030858/http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf |archive-date=June 7, 2012 }}</ref> The induction took place on October 1, 2005. Bentley stands as the third-youngest member after [[Carrie Underwood]] and [[Josh Turner]].\n\n===2006\u201308: ''Long Trip Alone'' and ''Greatest Hits/Every Mile a Memory 2003\u20132008''===\n[[File:Dierks 5.jpg|thumb|right|Dierks Bentley performing in [[Saginaw, Michigan]], March 31, 2007]]\nOn June 10, 2006, Bentley released his third album, ''[[Long Trip Alone]]''. The album produced two No. 1 hits in \"[[Every Mile a Memory]]\"<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> in 2006 and \"[[Free and Easy (Down the Road I Go)]]\"<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> in 2007. The [[Long Trip Alone (song)|title track]] reached No. 10 on the country charts,<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> while the fourth single, \"[[Trying to Stop Your Leaving]]\", peaked at No. 5.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/>\n\nIn 2007, Bentley released a live DVD titled ''Live and Loud at the Fillmore'', which was filmed in [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]].\n\nIn a March 2008 interview, Bentley said he would let his fans be the executive producers of his first greatest hits album, ''[[Greatest Hits/Every Mile a Memory 2003\u20132008]]''. The album was released on May 6, 2008. An album cut, \"Sweet & Wild\", reached No. 51 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> The song was an uncredited duet with fellow country singer [[Sarah Buxton (singer)|Sarah Buxton]].\n\n===2009\u201310: ''Feel That Fire'' and ''Up on the Ridge''===\n[[File:Dierks Bentley-14 Feb-2009.jpg|right|thumb|230px|alt=Dierks Bentley|Bentley opening for [[Brad Paisley]] at [[Scotiabank Place]] in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], February 14, 2009]]\nBentley's fourth studio album,<ref>{{cite news |id={{ProQuest|1030653514}} |last1=Caimmanica |first1=Jon |title=Critics' Choice: New CDs: Dierks Bentley |work=The New York Times |date=February 2, 2009 |page=C4 |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage-9C0DEFDA143CF931A35751C0A96F9C8B63.html }}</ref> ''[[Feel That Fire]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sessions.aol.ca/video/feel-that-fire/dierks-bentley/692/ |title=Dierks Bentley In Studio Performance at Sessions@AOL |publisher=[[Sessions@AOL]]|access-date=February 25, 2014}}</ref> was released in February 2009. Its [[Feel That Fire (song)|title track]], co-written by Brett Beavers and [[The Warren Brothers]], became Bentley's sixth No. 1 hit<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> in February 2009, and the album's second single, \"[[Sideways (Dierks Bentley song)|Sideways]]\", became his seventh<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> in summer 2009. The third and final single, \"[[I Wanna Make You Close Your Eyes]]\", peaked at No. 2.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/>\n\nBentley released his fifth studio album, ''[[Up on the Ridge]]'', on June 8, 2010. The [[Up on the Ridge (song)|title track]] was released on iTunes on April 20, 2010. The song peaked at No. 21 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart,<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> becoming Bentley's first single to miss the Top 10 since \"My Last Name\". The second single from the album, \"[[Draw Me a Map]]\", reached No. 33.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/>\n\n===2012\u201313: ''Home'' and ''Country & Cold Cans'' EP===\n[[File:Dierks Bentley meets with service members before his concert for the Players Championship at the Tournament Players Club Sawgrass during Military Appreciation Day in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., May 8, 2013 130508-N-TC587-036.jpg|right|thumb|230px|Bentley meeting with service members before a concert during [[Military Appreciation Day]] in [[Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida]], May 8, 2013]]\nBentley's sixth album, ''[[Home (Dierks Bentley album)|Home]]'', was released on February 7, 2012, led by the single, \"[[Am I the Only One (Dierks Bentley song)|Am I the Only One]]\", which reached No. 1 on the ''Billboard'' Country Singles.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/dierks-bentley-am-i-the-only-one-no-1/ |title=Dierks Bentley Goes No. 1 With 'Am I the Only One' |publisher=Tasteofcountry.com |date=August 22, 2011 |access-date=February 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McDonnell |first=Brandy |url=http://blog.newsok.com/bamsblog/2011/09/08/dierks-bentley-joe-walsh-jerrod-niemann-and-eli-young-band-to-play-okc-zoo-amphitheatres-family-jam-oct-14/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021055223/http://blog.newsok.com/bamsblog/2011/09/08/dierks-bentley-joe-walsh-jerrod-niemann-and-eli-young-band-to-play-okc-zoo-amphitheatres-family-jam-oct-14/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 21, 2012 |title=Dierks Bentley, Joe Walsh, Jerrod Niemann and Eli Young Band to play OKC Zoo Amphitheatre's Family Jam Oct. 14 &#124; News OK |publisher=Blog.newsok.com |date=September 8, 2011 |access-date=February 25, 2014 }}</ref> The second single off the album is \"[[Home (Dierks Bentley song)|Home]]\", which was co-written by Bentley, Brett Beavers and [[Dan Wilson (musician)|Dan Wilson]], and also reached No. 1<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> on March 24, 2012. A third single, \"[[5-1-5-0]]\", was released shortly after \"Home\" fell from No. 1 on the country chart.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> Dierks has been quoted by ''[[American Songwriter]]'', explaining: \"I wrote too many songs. I wrote 70. I wrote a lot. There's 64 that are never going to see the light of day. That's 64 days that I can't get back.\"<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/02/great-quotations-dierks-bentley-2/ |title=Great Quotations: Dierks Bentley |magazine=American Songwriter |first=Evan |last=Schlansky |date=February 24, 2012 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014092956/http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/02/great-quotations-dierks-bentley-2/ |archive-date=October 14, 2012 |access-date=June 6, 2012 }}</ref>\n\nOn August 21, 2012, Bentley released the ''Country & Cold Cans'' [[Extended play|EP]] on iTunes. It includes five songs, including a radio edit of the track \"[[Tip It On Back]]\" from his album ''[[Home (Dierks Bentley album)|Home]]''. Bentley paid for the studio time to record the EP himself.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2012/08/15/dierks-bentley-country-cold-cans-ep-back-porch/ | title=Dierks Bentley's 'Country & Cold Cans' EP: Hear 'Back Porch' here \u2013 EXCLUSIVE | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=August 15, 2012 | access-date=December 19, 2012}}</ref> On October 23, Bentley and [[Miranda Lambert]] announced the co-headlined 33-show Locked and Reloaded Tour, which began on January 17, 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tasteofcountry.com/miranda-lambert-dierks-bentley-2013-locked-reloaded-tour/ | title=Miranda Lambert, Dierks Bentley Announce 2013 Locked and Reloaded Tour | website=Taste of Country | date=October 23, 2012 | access-date=December 20, 2012}}</ref>\n\n===2014\u20132015: ''Riser''===\nBentley's seventh album, ''[[Riser (album)|Riser]]'', was released on February 25, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=Whitaker|first=Sterling|title=Dierks Bentley Sets Release Date for 'Riser'|url=http://theboot.com/dierks-bentley-riser-release-date/|access-date=January 6, 2014|newspaper=The Boot|date=January 6, 2014}}</ref> The album's first single, \"[[Bourbon in Kentucky]]\", was released to country radio on June 10, 2013. It peaked at No. 45 on the ''Billboard'' [[Country Airplay]] chart,<ref name=\"Country Airplay\">{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=dierks bentley|chart=Country Airplay}}|title=Dierks Bentley Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Airplay|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=November 8, 2012}}</ref> becoming Bentley's lowest-charting single to date. The album's second single, \"[[I Hold On]]\", was released on August 26, 2013, and became his first No. 1 on the Country Airplay chart<ref name=\"Country Airplay\"/> in April 2014 and his 11th overall to do so. The third single, \"[[Drunk on a Plane]]\", followed that same month and reached No. 1 on Country Airplay in August 2014 and was also a strong commercial hit, reaching No. 27 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> The album's fourth single, \"[[Say You Do (Dierks Bentley song)|Say You Do]]\", was released on October 6, 2014; it reached No. 1 on Country Airplay in May 2015. The [[Riser (song)|title track]] became the album's fifth single in June 2015.\n\nBentley, along with [[Eric Paslay]], is featured on [[Charles Kelley]]'s debut solo single, \"The Driver\", which was released on September 28, 2015. The song received a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance|Best Country Duo/Group Performance]] for the [[58th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref name=\"Grammy nom\">{{cite magazine|last1=Vain|first1=Madison|title=Lady Antebellum's Charles Kelly reacts to his Grammy nom for 'The Driver'|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/12/07/charles-kelley-grammy-nomination-reaction|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|date=December 7, 2015|access-date=December 9, 2015}}</ref>\n\n===2016\u20132017: ''Black''===\nBentley released his eighth album, ''[[Black (Dierks Bentley album)|Black]]'', on May 27, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nicholson|first1=Jessica|title=Dierks Bentley Prepping Eighth Studio Album, 'Black'|url=http://www.musicrow.com/2016/01/dierks-bentley-prepping-eighth-studio-album-black/|access-date=January 11, 2016|work=[[MusicRow]]|date=January 11, 2016}}</ref> The album's first single, \"[[Somewhere on a Beach]]\", was released on January 25, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Single Releases |url=http://www.musicrow.com/calendars-2/single-releases/ |website=[[MusicRow]] |access-date=January 8, 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212165034/http://www.musicrow.com/calendars-2/single-releases/ |archive-date=February 12, 2014 }}</ref>\n\nBentley co-hosted the [[51st Academy of Country Music Awards]] on April 3, 2016, where he was also nominated for the Male Vocalist of the Year and Video of the Year awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dierks.com/news?n_id=1550|title=Dierks Bentley Unveils Black Short Film Series|publisher=Dierks.com|date=April 1, 2016|access-date=April 22, 2016}}</ref>\n\nBentley released a series of four short films for songs from ''Black'', with episode 1 being the song \"I'll Be the Moon\" featuring [[Maren Morris]]. The following episode serves as the video for \"What the Hell Did I Say\".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/dierks-bentley-ill-be-the-moon-video-20160401|title=See Dierks Bentley's Provocative 'I'll Be the Moon' Video|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|author=Dunkerley, Beville|date=April 1, 2016|access-date=April 22, 2016}}</ref> The album's second single, \"[[Different for Girls (Dierks Bentley song)|Different for Girls]]\" featuring [[Elle King]], was released to country radio on June 6, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations|url=http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|website=All Access|access-date=May 27, 2016}}</ref> It reached No. 1 on Country Airplay in October 2016. The album's [[Black (Dierks Bentley song)|title track]] was released to country radio as the third single on November 14, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases |title=FMQB: Radio Industry News, Music Industry Updates, Nielsen Ratings, Music News and more! |work=[[FMQB]] |access-date=November 28, 2016 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111135304/http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases |archive-date=November 11, 2016 }}</ref>\n\nHe was also selected as one of 30 artists to perform on \"Forever Country\", a [[Mashup (music)|mashup track]] of \"[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]\", \"[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]\" and \"[[I Will Always Love You]]\", which celebrates 50 years of the [[CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062|title=30 Country Music Stars Join Forces for Historic CMA Music Video|work=ABC News|date=September 22, 2016|access-date=June 22, 2017}}</ref>\n\n===2018\u20132021: ''The Mountain'' and ''Hot Country Knights''===\nOn June 8, 2018, Bentley released ''[[The Mountain (Dierks Bentley album)|The Mountain]]'', his ninth studio album, via Capitol Records Nashville. All three singles from the album \u2013 \"Women, Amen\", \"Burning Man\" and \"Living\" \u2013 reached No. 1 (the second of which, however, only being recognized by [[Mediabase]]).\n\nBentley's side project, a '90s country parody band called [[Hot Country Knights]], signed on with Bentley's label Universal Music Group Nashville as a separate recording act in 2020. The act consists of Bentley and his road band, all of whom operate under stage names; Bentley uses the name Douglas \"Doug\" Douglason.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dierks-bentley-band-hot-country-knights-record-deal-933070/|title=Dierks Bentley's Faux Band Hot Country Knights Signs Real Record Deal|first=Jon|last=Freeman|date=January 2, 2020|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=January 23, 2020}}</ref> They released their debut single, \"Pick Her Up\" \u2013 which was co-written by Bentley with [[Jim Beavers]] and [[Brett Beavers]], and features guest vocals from [[Travis Tritt]]<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dierks-bentley-hot-country-knights-pick-her-up-travis-tritt-941853/|title=Dierks Bentley's Hot Country Knights Sing With Travis Tritt in New Song 'Pick Her Up'|first=Jon|last=Freeman|date=January 23, 2020|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=January 23, 2020}}</ref> \u2013 on January 23, 2020.\n\nBentley released a new single, \"[[Gone (Dierks Bentley song)|Gone]]\", on October 22, 2020.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dierks-bentley-new-song-gone-1079622/|title = Dierks Bentley Ghosts Friends and Family in His New Song 'Gone'|magazine = [[Rolling Stone]]|date = October 22, 2020}}</ref> The song was his highest-charting single on the [[Billboard Hot 100]] since his 2003 debut, \"What Was I Thinkin'\". On July 29, 2021, he released  \"[[Beers on Me]]\" featuring [[Hardy (singer)|Hardy]] and [[Breland (musician)|Breland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dierks-bentley-breland-hardy-beers-on-me/|title=Dierks Bentley Enlists Breland + Hardy for 'Beers on Me' [Listen]|work=[[Taste of Country]]|last=Whitaker|first=Sterling|date=July 29, 2021|access-date=August 22, 2021}}</ref> He also joined [[James Barker Band]] on the single \"[[New Old Trucks]]\" in October 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/james-barker-band-teams-up-with-dierks-bentley-for-new-old-trucks/|title=James Barker Band Teams Up With Dierks Bentley for \"New Old Trucks\"|date=October 8, 2021|access-date=October 12, 2021|work=The Country Note}}</ref>\n\n===2022\u2013present: ''Gravel & Gold''===\nOn July 29, 2022, Bentley released the lead single, \"[[Gold (Dierks Bentley song)|Gold]]\", from his tenth studio album, ''[[Gravel & Gold]]'', which was released on February 24, 2023.<ref name=\"auto\"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dierks-bentley-gravel-and-gold-album/ | title=Dierks Bentley Rolls Out Plans for His 10th Studio Album, 'Gravel & Gold' | last=Liptak | first=Carena | date=January 12, 2023 | access-date=January 12, 2023 | work=Taste of Country}}</ref> On November 19, he released \"High Note\", a bluegrass track featuring [[Billy Strings]].<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dierks-bentley-billy-strings-high-note-1234632469/ Dierks Bentley and Billy Strings Get Baked for the Apocalypse in 'High Note'] ''Rolling Stone''.</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nBentley married Cassidy Black on December 17, 2005, in [[Mexico]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1519097/dierks-bentley-elopes-to-mexico.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125201304/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1519097/dierks-bentley-elopes-to-mexico.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 25, 2013 |title=News : Dierks Bentley Elopes to Mexico |publisher=CMT |date=December 21, 2005 |access-date=February 25, 2014}}</ref> They live in Nashville, Tennessee with their three children and his two dogs, George and Bear.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20264181,00.html |title=Dierks Bentley: Baby Bliss |access-date=October 5, 2008 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref> The couple have two daughters<ref>{{cite web |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2008/10/05/dierks-bentley/ |title=Dierks Bentley Welcomes Daughter Evalyn Day |date=October 5, 2008 |access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://theboot.com/dierks-bentley-wife-cassidy-baby-christmas/ |title= Dierks Bentley and Wife Cassidy Welcome Daughter No. 2 |website= The Boot |date=December 25, 2010 |access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref> and a son.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://celebritybabies.people.com/2013/10/10/dierks-bentley-welcomes-son-knox/ |title=Dierks Bentley Welcomes Son Knox |date=October 10, 2013 |access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref> One daughter makes a vocal appearance on the song \"Thinking of You\" from Bentley's 2012 album, ''Home'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=INkvQpjfrHY |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/INkvQpjfrHY |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Dierks Bentley \"I'm Thinking of You\" with daughter Evie at Ryman 'Home' Show|via=YouTube|date=February 3, 2012 |access-date=August 11, 2014}}{{cbignore}}</ref> and their son appears in the music video for Bentley's 2019 single, \"[[Living (song)|Living]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theboot.com/dierks-bentley-living-music-video-son-knox/ |title=After 'Living', Dierks Bentley Might Have to Make a Music Video With Each of His Kids|date=April 18, 2019|work =The Boot |first=Carena|last= Liptak }}</ref>\n\nBentley holds a private pilot license. He owns a [[Cirrus SR22|Cirrus SR22T]]<ref>{{cite web|first=Stephen |last=Betts |url=http://theboot.com/dierks-bentley-airplane/ |title=Dierks Bentley Finds a New Way To Fly |publisher=The Boot |date=October 3, 2012 |access-date=February 26, 2019}}</ref> and flies a [[Cessna CitationJet/M2|Cessna Citation CJ4]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nbaa.org/professional-development/on-demand-education/nbaa-go/2020-vbace/vbace-newsroom/bentley-reaffirms-ill-always-take-that-call-as-a-business-aviation-advocate/ |title=News : Bentley Reaffirms 'I'll Always Take That Call' As A Business Aviation Advocate' |publisher=NBAA |date=December 2, 2020 |access-date=December 3, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Tours==\n;Headlining\n{{col-begin}}\n{{col-2}}\n*High Times and Hangovers Tour (2006)\n*Locked and Loaded Tour (2007)\n*Free and Easy Summer Tour (2007)\n*Throttle Wide Open Tour replaced [[Blake Shelton]]\n|-\n| 2018\n| ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]''\n| Himself\n| Season 15 finale results\n|-\n| 2021\n| ''The Voice''\n| Himself\n| Advisor to Team [[Blake Shelton|Blake]]\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons category|Dierks Bentley}}\n* {{official website|http://www.dierks.com}}\n* {{allMusic}}\n\n{{Dierks Bentley}}\n{{CMA New Artist}}\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Bentley, Dierks}}\n[[Category:1975 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Arizona]]\n[[Category:Capitol Records artists]]\n[[Category:Grand Ole Opry members]]\n[[Category:People from Tempe, Arizona]]\n[[Category:Vanderbilt University alumni]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Phoenix, Arizona]]\n[[Category:Lawrenceville School alumni]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Arizona]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Culver Academies alumni]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Arizona]]\n[[Category:Sigma Alpha Epsilon members]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Norman_Blake_(American_musician)","to":"Norman Blake (American musician)"}],"pages":{"1268563":{"pageid":1268563,"ns":0,"title":"Norman Blake (American musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}}\n{{BLP sources|date=July 2013}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Norman Blake\n| image            = \n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = yes\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Norman L. Blake\n| birth_date       = {{birth-date and age|March 10, 1938}}\n| birth_place      = [[Chattanooga]], Tennessee, U.S.\n| instrument       = Guitar, mandolin, six-string banjo, fiddle, dobro, banjo, viola, harmonica\n| genre            = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[folk music|folk]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation       = Musician, singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 1954\u2013present\n| label            = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Flying Fish Records|Flying Fish]], [[Takoma Records|Takoma]], [[Shanachie Records|Shanachie]], [[Red House Records|Red House]], Plectrafone/Western Jubilee\n| spouse           = [[Nancy Blake]]\n| associated_acts  = [[Johnny Cash]], [[Kris Kristofferson]]\n}}\n\n'''Norman L. Blake''' (born March 10, 1938) is a traditional American stringed instrument artist and songwriter. He is half of the eponymous '''Norman & Nancy Blake''' band with his wife, Nancy Blake.\n\n==Music career==\n\n===Early performing===\nBlake was born in [[Chattanooga]], Tennessee, and grew up in [[Sulphur Springs, Alabama]]. He listened to old-time and country music on the radio by [[the Carter Family]], the [[Skillet Lickers]], [[Roy Acuff]], and the Monroe Brothers ([[Charlie Monroe|Charlie]] and [[Bill Monroe]]).<ref name=\"ND\">{{cite web|title=Norman & Nancy Blake - The old-fashioned way|url=https://www.nodepression.com/norman-nancy-blake-the-old-fashioned-way/|website=No Depression|access-date=20 May 2019|date=1 January 2006}}</ref> He learned guitar at age 11 or 12, then [[mandolin]], [[dobro]], and [[fiddle]] in his teens. When he was 16, he dropped out of school to play music professionally.<ref name=\"Stone\">{{cite web|last1=Stone|first1=Steven|title=Norman Blake|url=https://www.vintageguitar.com/2902/norman-blake/|website=Vintage Guitar|access-date=26 November 2016|date=12 December 2003}}</ref>\n\nIn the 1950s, Blake joined the Dixieland Drifters and performed on radio broadcasts, then joined the Lonesome Travelers. When he was drafted in 1961, he served as an Army radio operator in the [[Panama Canal Zone]]. He started a popular band known as the [[Fort Kobbe|Kobbe]] Mountaineers.<ref name=\"Stambler\">{{cite book|last1=Stambler|first1=Irwin|last2=Stambler|first2=Lyndon|title=Folk and blues : the encyclopedia|date=2001|publisher=St. Martin's Press|location=New York|isbn=0312200579|pages=34\u201335|edition=1}}</ref> A year later, while he was on leave, he recorded the album ''Twelve Shades of Bluegrass'' with the Lonesome Travelers.<ref name=\"Wolff\">{{cite web|last1=Wolff|first1=Kurt|title=Norman Blake {{!}} Biography & History {{!}} AllMusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/norman-blake-mn0000387352/biography|website=AllMusic|access-date=26 November 2016}}</ref>\n\n===Nashville and Johnny Cash===\nAfter being discharged from the Army, Blake moved to Nashville and became a [[studio musician]].<ref name=\"Stambler\" /> For ten years, he toured and recorded with country singer [[Johnny Cash]]<ref name=\"Wolff\" /> and continued to play with Cash  intermittently over the next thirty.<ref name=\"Stone\" /> He met Nancy Short, a cellist with a [[classical music]] background who was playing in a folk group. He was asked by [[Bob Dylan]] to play on the country-folk album ''[[Nashville Skyline]]'', then became a member of the house band on Johnny Cash's TV show.<ref name=\"ND\" /><ref name=\"Stambler\" /> [[Kris Kristofferson]], one of the guests, hired Blake to tour with him. Blake recorded with folk singer [[Joan Baez]] and appeared on her hit song \"[[The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down]]\".<ref name=\"Wolff\" /> In 1971, he became a member of the bluegrass group Aero-plain, led by multi-instrumentalist [[John Hartford]] with fiddler [[Vassar Clements]], a short-lived project.<ref name=\"Stambler\" /><ref name=\"Wolff\" />\n\nBlake also played dobro on the 1972 album ''[[Will the Circle be Unbroken (Nitty Gritty Dirt Band album)|Will the Circle Be Unbroken]]'' by the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]].<ref name=\"circle\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/will-the-circle-be-unbroken-mw0000193505/credits |title=Will the Circle Be Unbroken: Credits |website=AllMusic |access-date=March 19, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 1972, Blake recorded his first solo album, ''[[Home in Sulphur Springs]]'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]], 1972).<ref name=\"Wolff\" /> Soon after his debut, he and Nancy recorded their first album, ''[[The Fields of November]]'' ([[Flying Fish Records|Flying Fish]], 1974), with Nancy on hillbilly cello. They married in 1975 and performed together for twenty years.<ref name=\"ND\" /><ref name=\"Stambler\" />\n\n===Style===\nMost of the music that Norman Blake plays could be described as neo-traditionalist Americana folk and roots music (folk, bluegrass, country, blues), and many of the songs he plays are [[Traditional music|traditional]], but he plays this acoustic type of music with a style, speed, and quality that has evolved and progressed in the modern age. Though probably best known for his fluid renditions of classic fiddle tunes transcribed for the guitar (\"Fiddler's Dram/Whiskey Before Breakfast\"), Blake has also written songs that have become bluegrass and folk standards, such as \"Ginseng Sullivan\", \"Slow Train through Georgia\", \"Billy Gray\", and \"Church Street Blues\".\n\nBlake has also written and published songs of a political nature, such as \"Don\u2019t Be Afraid of the Neo-Cons.\"<ref name=\":0\" />\n\nBlake is known for his tastefully simple-sounding style, saying, \"I\u2019m more interested in the music and the tone than I am the licks.\"<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |last=Campbell |first=Phil |date=2007-11-21 |title=Interview: Norman Blake |url=https://www.fretboardjournal.com/features/interview-norman-blake/ |access-date=2022-11-28 |website=Fretboard Journal |language=en}}</ref>\n\nAlthough known as one of the most prominent steel-string guitar [[flatpicking|flatpickers]], Blake is a multi-instrumentalist and vocalist. Other instruments he plays include the [[mandolin]], [[Guitjo (six-string)|6-string banjo]], [[fiddle]], [[dobro]], [[banjo]] and [[viola]].<ref>CD liner notes from ''The Fields of November'', Flying Fish Records, 1992</ref> He is known for his loose, right-hand guitar technique, which arose out of his mandolin technique. Also well known is his devotion to 12-fret guitars, including Martin 00s, 000s, D18s, D28s, and Gibsons, like his 1929 12-fret Nick Lucas special.\n\n=== Collaborations ===\nBlake has collaborated with [[Tony Rice]] on the albums, \"Blake and Rice,\" and \"Blake and Rice 2,\" which include many tunes, including some of Blake's originals.<ref>{{Citation |last=Tony Rice |title=Blake & Rice |date=1992 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Blake-Rice-Tony-Norman/dp/B0000002HV |publisher=Rounder |language=English |access-date=2022-12-06 |last2=Norman Blake |last3=Norman Blake & Tony Rice}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Tony Rice |title=Blake & Rice 2 |date=1992 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Blake-Rice-2-Norman-Tony/dp/B0000002JB |publisher=Rounder |language=English |access-date=2022-12-06 |last2=Norman Blake |last3=Norman Blake & Tony Rice}}</ref> Blake also released an album with Mike Compton called, \"Gallop to Georgia,\" which showcases many Old-Time tunes.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Mike Compton |url=https://www.mikecompton.net/ |access-date=2022-12-06 |website=Mike Compton |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n===Awards and honors===\nBlake played on the album ''[[Raising Sand]]'' by [[Robert Plant]] and [[Alison Krauss]], which won five Grammy Awards, and on the soundtrack ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou? (soundtrack)|O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'', which won a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]].\n\nNorman & Nancy Blake received Grammy nominations in the Best Traditional Folk Recording category for ''Blind Dog'', ''Just Gimme Somethin' I'm Used To'', ''While Passing Along This Way'', and ''The Hobo's Last Ride''. In 1986 Norman Blake was chosen Best Multi-Instrumentalist by the readers of ''Frets'' magazine.<ref>[http://www.flatpick.com/Pages/Featured_Artist/norman.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921055726/http://www.flatpick.com/Pages/Featured_Artist/norman.html|date=September 21, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n* ''[[Home in Sulphur (Plectrafone/Western Jubilee, 2015)\n* ''Brushwood Songs & Stories'' (Plectrafone/Western Jubilee, 2017)\n* ''Day By Day'' (Plectrafone/Western Jubilee, 2021)\n\n===Soundtracks===\n* ''[[O Brother, Union"}],"pages":{"49486575":{"pageid":49486575,"ns":0,"title":"The Washboard Union","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian country trio}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = The Washboard Union\n| image           = Washboard Union 2021.jpg\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       = yes\n| alias           =\n| origin          = [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|Washboard Union Productions|[[Universal Music Canada]]|[[Warner Music Canada]]}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.thewashboardunion.com/}}\n| current_members = David John Roberts<br />Aaron Grain<br />Chris Duncombe\n| past_members    = \n}}\n'''The Washboard Union''' is a Canadian [[country music]] group from [[Vancouver, British Columbia]] led by principal members David Roberts, Aaron Grain (aka Brett Ellis) and Chris Duncombe.<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web|title=The Washboard Union Biography|url=http://www.cmt.ca/artist/washboard-union|website=[[CMT (Canadian TV channel)|CMT]]|access-date=February 19, 2016|archive-date=March 25, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325120117/http://www.cmt.ca/artist/washboard-union|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Abdellatif|first1=Nouran|title=Washboard Union performing for first time in Leduc|url=http://www.leducrep.com/2016/01/18/washboard-union-performing-for-first-time-in-leduc|access-date=February 19, 2016|work=Leduc Rep|date=January 18, 2016}}{{Dead link|date=May 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nAaron Grain and Chris Duncombe met in [[Kelowna]], British Columbia at age 15 when Duncombe's father began dating Grain's mother.<ref name=\"cmt\" /> Duncombe and Grain eventually moved to Vancouver, where they met David Roberts, who was living in a Point Grey mansion.<ref name=\"cmt\" /> The three began writing and singing together.<ref name=\"cmt\" /> They originally performed under the name Run GMC.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kelowna: Nothing wishy-washy about The Washboard Union|url=http://www.kelownacapnews.com/entertainment/159610005.html|access-date=February 19, 2016|work=Kelowna Capital News|date=June 19, 2012}}{{Dead link|date=May 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Their debut album, ''The Washboard Union'', was released in 2012 and produced by [[Garth Richardson]] and [[Bob Ezrin]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Varty|first1=Alexander|title=Washboard Union explores a new road|url=https://www.straight.com/music/411911/washboard-union-explores-new-road|access-date=February 19, 2016|work=[[The Georgia Straight]]|date=August 20, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2015, The Washboard Union recorded an [[extended play]], ''In My Bones'', at RCA Studio A in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] with producer [[Trey Bruce]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Washboard Union|url=http://music.cbc.ca/#!/artists/The-Washboard-Union|website=[[CBC Music]]|access-date=February 19, 2016}}</ref> It was released by Slaight Music/[[Warner Music Canada]] on July 10, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hudson|first1=Alex|title=The Washboard Union Make Major Label Debut with New EP|url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/washboard_union_make_major_label_debut_with_new_ep|access-date=February 19, 2016|work=[[Exclaim!]]|date=May 22, 2015}}</ref> The first single, \"Some Day\", went top 40, and the second and third singles, \"Maybe It's the Moonshine\" & \"Shot of Glory\", reached the top 10 and top 5 respectively on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" /> In October 2015, The Washboard Union won the British Columbia Country Music Association Award for Roots Canadiana of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marchand|first1=Francois|title=Dallas Smith ropes in the wins at 2015 B.C. Country Music Awards|url=http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2015/10/27/dallas-smith-ropes-in-the-wins-at-2015-b-c-country-music-awards/|access-date=February 19, 2016|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=October 27, 2015|archive-date=March 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302045618/http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2015/10/27/dallas-smith-ropes-in-the-wins-at-2015-b-c-country-music-awards/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nThe Washboard Union's next album, ''What We're Made Of'', was produced by Matt Rovey (Zac Brown Band, Dean Brody) in Nashville and Jeff \"Diesel\" Dalziel in Toronto and Vancouver over the winter of 2017/18.  The album's first single, \u201cShine\u201d, was the band's third Top Ten Country Radio hit which they performed live on the Canadian Country Music Awards and walked away with a CCMA Award for 2017 Roots Artist of the Year.\n\nIn 2018, the group performed in Liverpool, Nova Scotia at the Queens Place Emera Centre.<ref>[https://www.thechronicleherald.ca/living/the-best-nova-scotia-concerts-of-2018-270134/ \"The best Nova Scotia concerts of 2018\"]. ''Chronicle Herald'', Stephen Cooke, Dec 20, 2018</ref> On November 22, 2019, The Washboard Union released \"Country Thunder\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://youtube.com/watch?v=IST7pMNjC2s|title=The Washboard Union - Country Thunder - Official Music Video|website=[[YouTube]]|date=November 22, 2019 |accessdate=August 6, 2021}}</ref> as the leadoff single to their third studio album, ''Everbound'', which was released on April 24, 2020. The album's second single was \"Dock Rock,\" followed by \"If She Only Knew\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicexpress.ca/the-washboard-union-reveal-new-single-if-she-only-knew/|title=The Washboard Union Reveal New Single 'If She Only Knew'|website=The Music Express|date=October 28, 2020 |accessdate=August 6, 2021}}</ref> and \"Never Run Outta Road.\"\n\nIn 2023, the band released their single \"[[I Run on Country]]\" as part of a new partnership with [[Universal Music Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2023/03/24/the-washboard-union-shares-i-run-on-country-interview/|title=The Washboard Union shares \"I Run On Country\" (Interview)|date=March 24, 2023|first=Jenna|last=Melanson|work=Canadian Beats Media|access-date=July 26, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:22em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Washboard Union''\n| \n* Release date: June 26, 2012\n* Label: self-released\n* Formats: [[Compact disc|CD]], [[Music download|digital download]]\n|-\n!
