women guitarists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from New York (state)]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Larry_Cordle","to":"Larry Cordle"}],"pages":{"17482044":{"pageid":17482044,"ns":0,"title":"Larry Cordle","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=September 2010}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Larry Cordle\n| image            = \n| caption          = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = \n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1948|11|16}}\n| birth_place       = Eastern [[Kentucky]], U.S.\n| origin           = United States\n| instrument       = Guitar<br />vocals\n| genre            = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]<br />[[country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter<br />musician\n| years_active     = 199x-present\n| label            = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]], Shell Point, [[Lonesome Day Records|Lonesome Day]]\n| website          = {{URL|www.larrycordle.com}}\n| associated_acts  = [[Carl Jackson]], [[Jerry Salley]]\n}}\n'''Larry Cordle''' (born November 16, 1948) is an American [[country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer-songwriter\n.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/larry-cordle-mn0000124925/biography |title=Artist Biography |author=Linda Seida |publisher=allmusic.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015}}</ref> Cordle is most famous for his song \"[[Murder on Music Row]]\",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/murder-on-music-row-mw0000625171 |author=William Ruhlmann |title=AllMusic Review |publisher=allmusic.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015 }}</ref> which was recorded by [[George Strait]] and [[Alan Jackson]] and received the [[Country Music Association]] Award for Vocal Event of the Year, and CMA nomination for Song of the Year, in 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/cma-awards/2000.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114055357/http://www.cmt.com/cma-awards/2000.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 14, 2014 |title=CMA Awards, Archive 2000 |publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] |access-date=September 7, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nCordle has written songs for [[Garth Brooks]] (\"Alabama Clay\" and \"Against the Grain\", the latter of which was also recorded by [[The Oak Ridge Boys]]), [[Mountain Heart]] (\"Bitter Harvest\"), [[Ricky Skaggs]] (\"Callin' Your Name\", \"Highway 40 Blues\",  \"[[Heartbreak Hurricane]]\"), [[Loretta Lynn]] (\"Country In My Genes\"), [[George Strait]] (\"Hollywood Squares\"), [[Trisha Yearwood]] (\"Lonesome Dove\"), [[Kathy Mattea]] (\"Lonesome Standard Time\"), [[Diamond Rio]] (\"Mama, Don't Forget To Pray For Me\") and [[Bradley Walker]] (\"When I'm Hurtin'\") .\n\nCordle also has a career of his own, with his band Lonesome Standard Time. He founded the band in 1990 with his friend Glen Duncan. He received a Grammy nomination for the group's debut album, self-titled, in 1992. In 2005, Cordle's band played at the Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival. On his album 2007 \"Took Up and Put Down\", he sings \"The First Train Robbery\"; a song about the [[Reno Gang]] written from brother William Reno's perspective. The Song was written by Chris Stuart<ref>\"Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival\", ''Strings'', newsletter of the [[Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society]], October 2005.</ref>\n\nCordle performed on two bluegrass tribute albums for the British rock band [[the Moody Blues]]: ''[[Moody Bluegrass (musical project)|Moody Bluegrass]]: A Nashville Tribute to the Moody Blues'' (2004), and ''Moody Bluegrass TWO... Much Love'' (2011).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4247134 |title=Moody Bluegrass: Rocking Through the Hills |publisher=NPR.org |date=December 3, 2004|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/moody-bluegrass-two%E2%80%A6much-love/ |title=Moody Bluegrass Two\u2026Much Love |publisher=bluegrasstoday.com |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref>\n\nAlong with friends [[Carl Jackson]] and [[Jerry Salley]], the trio (Cordle, Jackson & Salley) recorded the song \"You\u2019re Running Wild\" on the [[Louvin Brothers]] tribute on [[Universal South Records]], which features numerous country music stars singing songs made famous by the legendary duo. Entitled ''[[Livin', Lovin', Losin': Songs of the Louvin Brothers]]'', this project won the [[2004 Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Country Album of the Year]]. The trio tours across the country and performs the hits they wrote for others.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Larry Cordle & Lonesome Standard Time===\n* ''[[Larry Cordle, Glen Duncan & Lonesome Standard Time]]'', Sugar Hill Records (1992)\n* ''[[Murder on Music Row]]'', Shell Point Records (2000)\n* ''[[Songs from the Workbench]]'', Shell Point Records (2003)\n* ''[[Lonesome Skynyrd Time: A Bluegrass Tribute to Lynyrd Skynyrd]]'', CMH Records (2004)\n* ''[[All-Star Duets]]'', MightyCord Records (2014)\n\n===Solo===\n* ''[[Took Down and Put Up]]'' (2007)\n* ''[[Pud Marcum's Hangin']]'', MightyCord Records (2011)\n* ''[[Give Me Jesus]]'', MightyCord Records (2017)\n* ''[[Tales From East Kentucky]]'' (2018)\n* ''[[Where the Trees Know My Name]]'', MightyCord Records (2021)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.larrycordle.com Official website]\n* [{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p33809|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic profile]\n{{CMA for Song of the Year}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cordle, Larry}}\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:1949 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Kentucky]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mark_O'Connor","to":"Mark O'Connor"}],"pages":{"1196907":{"pageid":1196907,"ns":0,"title":"Mark O'Connor","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American violinist and composer}}\n{{Other people|Mark O'Connor}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Mark O'Connor\n| image            = Mark O'Connor, bluegrass musician on stage at Cambridge Folk Festival, 1985.jpg\n| caption          = O'Connor on stage at the 1985 [[Cambridge Folk Festival]]\n| background       = non_vocal_instrumentalist\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1961|08|05}}<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark O'Connor biography|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/oconnor_mark/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040223003441/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/oconnor_mark/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 23, 2004|publisher=CMT|access-date=January 28, 2017}}</ref>\n| birth_place      = [[Mountlake Terrace, Washington]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[jazz]], [[classical music|classical]]\n| occupation       = Musician, composer, teacher, author\n| instrument       = Violin, fiddle, guitar, mandolin\n| years_active     = 1974\u2013present\n| label            = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]], [[Sony Classical Records]]\n| associated_acts  = [[David Grisman Quintet]], [[Strength in Numbers (band)|Strength in Numbers]], [[Dixie Dregs|The Dregs]]\n| website          = {{URL|markoconnor.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Mark O'Connor''' (born August 5, 1961) is an American [[Musical styles (violin)#Fiddle|fiddle]] player, composer, guitarist, and mandolinist whose music combines [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[country music|country]], [[jazz]] and [[classical music|classical]]. A three-time [[Grammy Award]] winner, he has won six [[Country Music Association Award for Musician of the Year|Country Music Association Musician Of The Year]] awards and was a member of three influential [[musical ensemble]]s: the [[David Grisman Quintet]], [[Dixie Dregs|The Dregs]], and [[Strength in Numbers (band)|Strength in Numbers]].<ref name=\"Mark O\u2019Connor, Violin\">{{cite web |url=https://fromthetop.org/musician/mark-oconnor/ |title=Mark O'Connor, Violin |publisher=fromthetop.org |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref>\n\nO'Connor has released 45 albums, of mostly original music, over a 45-year career. He has recorded and performed mostly his original American Classical music for decades. An expert at traditionally-based fiddle and bluegrass music, he also plays other instruments proficiently, including the violin, guitar and mandolin.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thebluegrasssituation.com/read/mark-oconnor-pickin-in-the-wind/ |title=Mark O'Connor, 'Pickin' in the wind' |author=Hiltner, Justin |date=7 August 2018 |publisher=thebluegrasssituation.com |access-date=16 May 2022 }}</ref> He has appeared on 450 albums, composed nine concertos and has put together groundbreaking ensembles. His mentors have included [[Benny Thomasson]]<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark O'Connor: On Learning, Playing, and Teaching Strings, American-style by Peter Anick|url=http://www.fiddle.com/Articles.page?Index=1&ArticleID=53719|publisher=Fiddle Magazine|date=August 21, 2010}}</ref> who taught O'Connor to fiddle as a teenager, French jazz violinist [[St\u00e9phane Grappelli]]<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark O'Connor Hot Swing on Mountain Stage|url=https://www.npr.org/2010/04/05/125541952/mark-oconnor-on-mountain-stagewith|publisher=NPR|date=April 5, 2010}}</ref> with whom O'Connor toured as a teenager, and guitarists [[Chet Atkins]], [[Doc Watson]] and [[Steve Morse]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Chet Atkins and Mark O'Connor|url=http://www.misterguitar.us/news/markoconnor2a.html|publisher=Mister Guitar|author=Tom Redmond|date=January 28, 2017}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nO'Connor was born and raised in the suburb of [[Mountlake Terrace, Washington]], where his father was a construction worker and his mother was a dance teacher.<ref name=\"Violin Virtuoso Mark O\u2019Connor\">{{cite web |url=https://americanprofile.com/articles/violin-virtuoso-mark-oconnor/ |title=Violin Virtuoso Mark O'Connor |author=Roberts, M.B. |date=5 August 2010 |publisher=americanprofile.com |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref> His mother insisted that he learn to play the guitar at the age of  five and, by the age of ten had taught himself to play the [[Flamenco guitar]].<ref name=\"Violin Virtuoso Mark O\u2019Connor\"/> As an  eight-year-old in 1969, O'Connor watched fiddle player [[Doug Kershaw]] perform the song \"[[Diggy Liggy Lo]]\" on ''[[The Johnny Cash Show (TV series)|The Johnny Cash Show]]'', leaving such an impression on him that he begged his parents to purchase him a fiddle for the next three years before they finally gave him one for his eleventh birthday.<ref name=\"Mark O'Connor's Art: Fiddling With The Best\">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1993/11/19/mark-oconnors-art-fiddling-with-the-best/ad489226-573c-4281-b521-c7aff4a63e5a/ |title=Mark O'Connor's Art: Fiddling With The Best |author=Himes, Geoffrey |work=washingtonpost.com |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref><ref name=\"Mark O'Connor - fiddle whiz keeps it in the family\">{{cite web |url=http://www.robadamsjournalist.com/index.asp?pageid=665624 |title=Mark O'Connor - fiddle whiz keeps it in the family |author=Adams, Rob |publisher=robadamsjournalist.com |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref>\n\nIn 1973, O'Connor's mother drove him and his little sister from Seattle to Nashville, Tennessee, where a local friend suggested that he might be allowed to play at the Picking Parlour.<ref name=\"Mark O'Connor - fiddle whiz keeps it in the family\"/> His performance at the Picking Parlour left the local audience stunned that a twelve-year-old knew so many old-time fiddle songs.<ref name=\"Mark O'Connor - fiddle whiz keeps it in the family\"/> A couple of days later, he made his [[Grand Ole Opry]] debut, introduced by [[Roy Acuff]], and became the youngest musician to sign a recording contract with [[Rounder Records]].<ref name=\"Mark O'Connor - fiddle whiz keeps it in the family\"/>\n\nO'Connor won national titles on the fiddle, guitar, and mandolin as a teenager.<ref name=\"Mark O'Connor Biography\">{{cite web |url=https://musicianguide.com/biographies/1608001028/Mark-O-Connor.html |title=Mark O'Connor Biography |author=LaBorie, Tim |publisher=musicianguide.com |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref><ref name=\"Mark O\u2019Connor picks up his guitar again for Markology II\">{{cite web |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/mark-oconnor-picks-up-his-guitar-again-for-markology-ii/ |title=Mark O'Connor picks up his guitar again for Markology II |author=Lawless, John |date=19 April 2021 |publisher=bluegrasstoday.com |access-date=16 May 2022 }}</ref> In 1975, at the age of thirteen, O'Connor won the [[WSM (AM)]], [[Tennessee]], and [[Grand Ole Opry]] sponsored Grand Masters Fiddle Championships in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], against amateur and professional competitors of all ages.<ref name=\"Mark O\u2019Connor picks up his guitar again for Markology II\"/><ref>{{Cite web|title=Grand Master Fiddler Championship Past Winners|url=http://www.grandmasterfiddler.com/14103.html|publisher=Grand Master Fiddler|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328053616/http://www.grandmasterfiddler.com/14103.html|archive-date=March 28, 2012}}</ref> That same year he won another national championship on acoustic guitar, at the [[Walnut Valley Festival|National Flat Pick Guitar Championship]] in [[Winfield, Kansas]].<ref name=\"Mark O\u2019Connor picks up his guitar again for Markology II\"/><ref>{{Cite web|title=National Guitar Flat Pick Champion Archive|url=http://wvfest.com/contests/bycontest.html?contestid=1|publisher=Walnut Valley Festival|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724175648/http://www.wvfest.com/contests/bycontest.html?contestid=1|archive-date=July 24, 2011}}</ref>\n\nAfter graduating from the [[Mountlake Terrace High School]] in 1979, O'Connor joined the [[David Grisman Quintet]] as the replacement for guitar player, [[Tony Rice]], and went out on tour with Stephane Grappelli with whom he performed at [[Carnegie Hall]] when he was only seventeen-years-old.<ref name=\"Violin Virtuoso Mark O\u2019Connor\"/><ref name=\"Mark O'Connor's Art: Fiddling With The Best\"/><ref name=\"Mark O\u2019Connor picks up his guitar again for Markology II\"/> As a teenager, he was also a member of the seminal instrumental group The Dregs, previously known as [[Dixie Dregs]].<ref name=\"Mark O'Connor Biography\"/> At age 19, He won the [[The Whites|Buck White]] International Mandolin Championship in [[Kerrville, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/mark-oconnor-shares-his-career-as-an-american-master/ |title=Mark O'Connor shares his career as an American Master |author=Zimmerman, Lee |date=10 May 2019 |publisher=bluegrasstoday.com |access-date=16 May 2022 }}</ref> He is a four-time grand champion (1979, 1980, 1981 and 1984) at the [[National Oldtime Fiddlers' Contest]] in [[Weiser, Idaho]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = National Oldtime Fiddlers Contest Past Winners|url=http://fiddlecontest.com/gallery/displayimage.php?album=11&pid=47&slideshow=4000|publisher=Fiddle Contest|access-date=July 9, 2020}}</ref> Several of his teenage albums are noteworthy and inspired a generation of young acoustic musicians, such as \"Pickin' In The Wind\", \"A Texas Jam Session\", \"Markology\" and \"False Dawn\".\n\n==Musical career==\n{{BLP sources section|date=March 2017}}\nO'Connor composes, arranges, and records American music in genres that include folk, classical, and jazz. His works include concertos, and compositions for [[orchestra]], [[string quartet]]s, [[string trio]]s, [[Choir|choral music]], solo unaccompanied pieces, folk and bluegrass ensemble and a [[symphony]] (see [[#Compositions|Compositions]]). After releasing six albums as a teen on [[Rounder Records]], O'Connor signed a long term record deal with [[Warner Bros. Records]] in Nashville. He released a series of instrumental albums such as \"Elysian Forest\" and \"On The Mark\" as well as teaming up with [[Bela Fleck]], [[Sam Bush]], [[Jerry Douglas]] and [[Edgar Meyer]] for \"Strength In Numbers\". His first award winning albums that catapulted him into the international stage include \"New Nashville Cats\" and \"Heroes\" both released on [[Warner Bros.]]\n\nO'Connor's \"Fiddle Concerto (1992)\", a [[violin concerto]] in [[American fiddle|American fiddle style]] commission by the [[Santa Fe Symphony Orchestra and Chorus]], has been performed over 250 times, making it one of the most performed concertos written in the last 50 years.<ref>{{Cite web|title=ShoreFire Media Official Bio for Mark O'Connor|url=http://www.shorefire.com/index.php?a=bio&o=244|publisher=ShoreFire Media|access-date=March 6, 2017}}</ref> The recording of the concerto was conducted by [[Marin Alsop]] and \"Concordia Orchestra\".\n\nIn 1993, O'Connor teamed up with [[Charlie Daniels]] to record a sequel to Daniels' 1979 single \"[[The Devil Went Down to Georgia]]\" entitled \"The Devil Comes Back To Georgia\". O'Connor and Daniels recorded the song alongside [[Johnny Cash]], [[Marty Stuart]] and [[Travis Tritt]]. The song was on O'Connor's album, [[Heroes (1993 album)|''Heroes'']]. Between 1995 and 2000, O'Connor teamed up with [[Yo-Yo Ma]] and [[Edgar Meyer]] to release \"Appalachia Waltz\" and \"Appalachian Journey\" spending nearly 2 years at the top of the classical music Billboard charts.\n\nIn 1996, O'Connor composed ''The Olympic Reel'' for the closing ceremonies of the [[1996 Summer Olympics]] in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].<ref name=\"wordpress\">{{Cite web|url=http://olympicceremonies.wordpress.com/1996-atlanta-closing-ceremony-music-list/|title=1996 Atlanta Closing Ceremony Music List &#124; Olympic Ceremonyography|website=olympicceremonies.wordpress.com|date=30 August 2008|access-date=November 10, 2018}}</ref> It premiered in front of 100,000 people at [[Centennial Olympic Stadium]], as well as 3.5&nbsp;billion people from the television viewing audience.<ref name=\"sitemason\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sitemason.com/site/kGwSPe/olympic.reel.html|title=Mark O'Connor Sheet Music|website=sitemason.com|access-date=November 10, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn 1997, O'Connor and others composed and performed music based on folk melodies as arrangements for the [[American Revolutionary War]]-era [[PBS|Public Broadcasting Service]] documentary miniseries, ''[[Liberty!|Liberty! The American Revolution]]'' (the companion album is ''Liberty!''). The [[theme music]] for the miniseries is O'Connor's ''Song of the Liberty Bell.''<ref>{{Cite web|title=LIBERTY! The American Revolution, Series: The Music of Liberty|url=https://www.pbs.org/ktca/liberty/liberty_music.html|publisher=PBS|access-date=March 6, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 1999, he recorded his ''Fanfare For The Volunteer'' with the [[London Philharmonic Orchestra]] for Sony Classical,<ref>{{Cite web|title=Fanfare for the Volunteer [sound recording]|url=http://www.chipublib.org/search/details/cn/1718332|publisher=Chicago Public Library}}</ref> and one of his most critically acclaimed orchestral pieces ''American Seasons'', which alludes to [[The Four Seasons (Vivaldi)]], for Sony Classical<ref>{{Cite web|title=American Seasons: Review |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/mark-oconnor-the-american-seasons-r55500|publisher=AllMusic.com|access-date=March 6, 2017}}</ref> as well. \"American Seasons\", and his \"Strings & Threads\" Suite (1986) was performed by The Metamorphosen Chamber Orchestra in 2001 at the Great Performers concert at [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]].\n\nIn a review by ''The New York Times'', \"if Dvorak had spent his American leisure time in Nashville instead of [[Spillville, Iowa]], his ''New World'' Symphony might have sounded like this.\"<ref>{{Cite news|title=MUSIC REVIEW; Vivaldi and a Touch of Twang From Some Flexible Fiddlers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/19/movies/music-review-vivaldi-and-a-touch-of-twang-from-some-flexible-fiddlers.html |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 October 2001 |access-date=March 6, 2017|last1=Kozinn |first1=Allan }}</ref> Both \"Strings & Threads\" Suite and \"American Seasons\" were recorded for the album [[The American Seasons]], released in 2001 on the label OMAC Records.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Mark O'Connor {{!}} Orchestral {{!}} D'Addario |url=https://www.daddario.com/artists/orchestral/mark_oconnor/ |access-date=2024-06-15 |website=www.daddario.com}}</ref> In 2008 O'Connor paired up with violinist [[Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg]] to record his \"Double Violin Concerto\" with [[Marin Alsop]] and the [[Colorado Symphony Orchestra]] for OMAC Records.\n\nOver a period of five years, O'Connor teamed up with jazz musicians [[Frank Vignola]] and [[Jon Burr]] for a trilogy of \"Hot Swing Trio\" albums dedicated to his mentor [[Stephane Grappelli]]. O'Connor recorded ''Thirty-Year Retrospective'' in 2003 with the mandolinist [[Chris Thile]], guitarist [[Bryan Sutton]], and bassist Byron House.<ref>\"Thirty Year Retrospective\" liner notes</ref> It celebrates his thirty years as a recording artist on his own OMAC label. He also provided the soundtrack to a 30-minute animated film on the story of [[Johnny Appleseed]] (and released the music on his 1992 album ''Johnny Appleseed''), narrated by [[Garrison Keillor]]. He contributed four tracks to a 1993 album on the theme of ''[[A Visit from St. Nicholas|The Night Before Christmas]]'', narrated by [[Meryl Streep]].\n\nHis composition, Appalachia Waltz (appearing on the album of the same title), has been adopted by Yo-Yo Ma as part of his live performance repertoire.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Yo-Yo Ma |url=https://www.sonyclassical.com/artists/artist-details/yo-yo-ma-2 |access-date=2024-06-15 |website=www.sonyclassical.com |language=en}}</ref> One of his chamber music efforts is his piano trio entitled Poets and Prophets which is inspired by his boyhood hero [[Johnny Cash]]. O'Connor and [[Rosanne Cash]] united in double bill concerts for premiering their collaboration. The piece was recorded by the [[Eroica Trio]].\n\nOn April 28, 2009, O'Connor teamed with chamber musicians [[Ida Kavafian]], [[Paul Neubauer]] and [[Matt Haimovitz]] to present his second and third string quartets, amalgamating bluegrass with classical styles, at Merkin Concert Hall in New York.<ref>{{Cite web|last=O'Connor, Kavafian, Neubauer, Haimovitz|first=Mark, Ida, Paul Matt|title=Mark O'Connor's String Quartet No. 3 (2nd Mvmt) w. Kavafian/Neubauer/Haimovitz|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DCM8Z3s2J3g&list=PL7D4C78D6C024C1D7&index=79 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/DCM8Z3s2J3g |archive-date=2021-12-22 |url-status=live|work=String Quartet No. 3|publisher=YouTube|access-date=September 24, 2012}}{{cbignore}}</ref> O'Connor released the recording for both string quartets under the label OMAC in May 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark O'Connor String Quartets No. 2 & 3|url=https://www.amazon.com/Mark-OConnor-String-Quartets-Nos/dp/B0021R519K|publisher=Amazon|access-date=March 6, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 2010, O'Connor released his \"Americana Symphony\" recorded by the [[Baltimore Symphony]] as well as his \"Concerto No. 6 (Old Brass) and released on OMAC Records. In 2011, he released his unique \"The Improvised Violin Concerto\" on CD and DVD with the [[Boston Youth Symphony Orchestras]]. Partnering with his wife Maggie (who he married on November 8, 2014), his son Forrest, and his daughter-in-law, they recorded two band albums \"Coming Home\" for [[Rounder Records]] and \"A Musical Legacy\" for OMAC Records. He also recorded a duets album with Maggie featuring music from the O'Connor Method. Some of O'Connor's albums are or contain tributes to his musical mentors and inspirations, including [[Niccol\u00f2 Paganini]], [[Benny Thomasson]], and [[St\u00e9phane Grappelli|Grappelli]]. He has recorded solo albums for OMAC Records,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://omacrecords.com/home|title=OMAC Records|website=omacrecords.com}}</ref> [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/rounder-to-reissue-mark-oconnor-albums/|title=Rounder reissues classic Mark O'Connor albums|date=September 13, 2016}}</ref> and [[Sony|SONY Classical Records]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/mark-oconnor-mn0000293391/discography|title=Mark O'Connor &#124; Album Discography|website=AllMusic}}</ref>\n\n==The O'Connor Method==\n{{BLP sources section|date=March 2017}}\nO'Connor has developed a string instrument technique for music teachers and students, ''The O'Connor Method&nbsp;\u2014 A New American School of String Playing''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=O'Connor Violin Method |url=http://markoconnor.com/index.php?page=about&family=method |publisher=Mark O'Connor Musik International |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714040226/http://markoconnor.com/index.php?page=about&family=method |archive-date=July 14, 2011}}</ref> The method places an emphasis on music and playing techniques from North America, in addition to focusing on rhythmic development, ear training, and improvisation.\n\nThe method is published as a series of books that also contains short essays about famous Americans who played fiddle, such as [[Johnny Gimble]], [[Ray Nance]], [[Byron Berline]], [[Pinchas Zukerman]], [[Eddie South]], [[Kenny Baker (fiddler)|Kenny Baker]], [[Benny Thomasson]], [[Scott Joplin]], [[Thomas Jefferson]] and [[Davy Crockett]], and the history of a wide variety of music including [[jazz]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Romani music|Romani]], [[western swing]], [[Cajun music|cajun]], [[blues]], [[African-American music|African American Spirituals]], [[ragtime]] and [[Mariachi]]. Teacher training sessions based on the Method take place around the United States and in other countries including at O'Connor Method String Camps. The physical edition which includes violin, viola, cello and orchestra method books was released in 2010. In 2020, the books were released as a digital edition for download.\n\n==Awards and honors==\nO'Connor won a [[Grammy Award]] three times: in 1991 for Best Country Instrumental Performance, ''The New Nashville Cats''; in 2000 for Best Classical Crossover Album, ''[[Appalachian Journey]]'' with [[Yo-Yo Ma]] and [[Edgar Meyer]]; and in 2016 for Best Bluegrass Album, ''Coming Home'' by the O'Connor Band With Mark O'Connor.\n<ref name=\"Past Winners: Grammys\">{{Cite web|title = Past Winners: Grammys |date = 30 April 2017|url=https://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=%22mark+o%27connor%22&field_nominee_work_value=&year=All&genre=All&=Search|publisher=Grammy Awards website|access-date=July 9, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"npr\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/12/514877528/grammy-awards-2017-the-full-list-of-winners|website=npr.org|title=NPR Choice page|date=12 February 2017 |access-date=November 10, 2018|last1=Flanagan |first1=Andrew }}</ref><ref name=\"hollywoodreporter\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/grammys-2017-winners-list-966483/item/grammy-nominations-best-r-b-performance-952821|title=Grammys 2017 Winners Full List|website=Hollywood Reporter|date=12 February 2017|access-date=November 10, 2018}}</ref>\n\nHe was named Musician of the Year by the [[Country Music Association]] six years in a row (from 1991\u201396).<ref name=\"Country Music\">{{Cite web|title=CMA Musician of the Year Past Winners|url=http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blprevcmamus.htm|publisher=Country Music|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018193917/http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blprevcmamus.htm |archive-date=October 18, 2015}}</ref> His collaborative single \"Restless\" (with Vince Gill, Ricky Skaggs and Steve Wariner) won the 1991 CMA Vocal Event of the Year award. O'Connor is 4-time National Old-Time Fiddler Champion,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Mark O\u2019Connor - My History at Weiser |url=https://www.idahobluegrassassociation.org/mark-orsquoconnor---my-history-at-weiser.html |access-date=2024-06-15 |website=Idaho Bluegrass Association |language=en}}</ref> 3-time Grand Master Fiddler Champion,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Grand Master Fiddler Championship - Past Winners |url=https://www.grandmasterfiddler.com/past-winners/ |access-date=2024-06-15 |website=www.grandmasterfiddler.com |language=en}}</ref> 2-time national guitar flatpick champion,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2014-10-17 |title=National Flat Pick Guitar Championship |url=https://www.pickersparadise.org/contests/flatpick |access-date=2024-06-15 |website=Walnut Valley Festival |language=en}}</ref> and world mandolin champion, all achieved in his teens.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Can A Mandolin Kick Any More _____? |url=https://www.mandolincafe.com/forum/threads/122646-Can-A-Mandolin-Kick-Any-More-_____?p=1480766&viewfull=1 |access-date=2024-06-15 |website=www.mandolincafe.com}}</ref> He was inducted into The National Fiddler Hall of Fame in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalfiddlerhalloffame.org/HallOfFame/marko%27connorbio.html |title=Mark O'Connor at the National Fiddler Hall of Fame |publisher=nationalfiddlerhalloffame.org |access-date=5 May 2022 }}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"7\"| Peak United States Chart Positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Label\n|-\n! style=\"width:65px;\"| <small>[[Billboard charts#Top Classical Crossover Albums|Classical Crossover]]</small>\n! style=\"width:65px;\"| <small>[[Billboard charts#Top Classical Albums|Classical]]</small><br /><ref>{{Cite magazine \"Johnny Has Gone for a Soldier\" <small>(with [[James Taylor]])</small>\n| \n|}\n\n== See also ==\n{{Portal|Biography}}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links Band members]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lloyd_Maines","to":"Lloyd Maines"}],"pages":{"523148":{"pageid":523148,"ns":0,"title":"Lloyd Maines","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{BLP refimprove|date=March 2020}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name                = Lloyd Maines\n|image               = Lloyd_Maines_-_Acoustical_Cafe_-_Ron_Baker_2019.jpg\n|caption             = Lloyd Maines at Acoustical Cafe in Austin, TX (2019).\n|image_size          = 250px\n|background          = non_vocal_instrumentalist\n|birth_name          = Lloyd Wayne Maines\n|alias               = \n|birth_date          = {{Birth date and age|1951|06|28}}<br>[[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], [[Texas]], U.S.\n|death_date          = \n|instrument          = [[Pedal steel guitar]], [[dobro]], guitar, [[mandolin]], [[banjo]]\n|genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[folk music|folk]], [[alt-country]]\n|occupation          = Musician, producer, songwriter\n|years_active        = 1976-present\n|label               = \n|associated_acts     = [[The Maines Brothers Band]], [[Natalie Maines]], [[Terri Hendrix]], [[The Chicks]] (formerly known as the [[Dixie Chicks]]), [[Court Yard Hounds]], [[Wilco]]\n|website             = \n}}\n\n'''Lloyd Wayne Maines''' (born June 28, 1951) is an American [[country music]] record producer, musician and songwriter. He was inducted into the Austin City Limits Hall of Fame as one of the first three members, the other two being [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]]. He is the father of [[Natalie Maines]] who is best known as the lead singer of [[The Chicks]].\n\n==Life and career==\nMaines was born and raised in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], [[Texas]], and is now based in [[Bulverde, Texas|Austin, Texas]].\n\nArguably best known as a [[pedal steel guitar|pedal steel]] player, Maines is a multi-instrumentalist who has also performed and/or recorded playing [[dobro]], electric and acoustic guitar, [[mandolin]], [[lap steel guitar]], [[banjo]] and [[bell tree]]. He toured and recorded as a member of the [[Joe Ely]] Band and has also played with [[Jerry Jeff Walker]], [[Guy Clark]], [[Butch Hancock]], [[Terry Allen (country singer)|Terry Allen]], [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]], [[Golden Bear (band)|Golden Bear]],<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r846134/credits|pure_url=yes}} Golden Bear album credits], [[AllMusic]]</ref> and other Texas musicians.  Maines was a member of [[The Maines Brothers Band]] in the late 1970s and early 1980s and has contributed to [[alt-country]] releases, including [[Uncle Tupelo]]'s ''[[Anodyne (album)|Anodyne]]'' and [[Wilco]]'s debut, ''[[A.M. (Wilco album)|AM]]''.\n\nMaines began producing some of his own music, branching out beginning with other country artists, early on starting with [[Terry Allen (artist)|Terry Allen]]'s seminal 1979 album, ''[[Lubbock (On Everything)]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lloyd Maines: A Driving Force In Texas Music |author=Harrington, AnnMarie |date=April 2002 |publisher=Take Country Back |url=http://www.takecountryback.com/features/lloydmaines.htm |access-date=September 3, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811203441/http://www.takecountryback.com/features/lloydmaines.htm |archive-date=August 11, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref> He has produced and worked on recording projects with numerous artists, including the [[Bad Livers]], [[Richard Buckner (musician)|Richard Buckner]], [[Roger Creager]], [[Anna Fermin]]'s Trigger Gospel, [[Pat Green]], [[Butch Hancock]], [[Wayne Hancock]], [[Terri Hendrix]],<ref name=TerriHendrix_WebsiteHome>{{cite web| publisher=Terri Hendrix| title=Live from Wilory Farm Tonight!| url=https://www.terrihendrix.com/| date=April 29, 2020| accessdate=2020-04-29}}</ref> [[Rita Hosking]], [[Ray Wylie Hubbard]], [[Intocable]], [[Robert Earl Keen]], the [[Lost Gonzo Band]], [[Bob Livingston (musician)|Bob Livingston]], [[Charlie Robison]], [[Owen Temple]], [[Two Tons of Steel]], [[Jerry Jeff Walker]], [[The Waybacks]], [[Dale Watson (singer)|Dale Watson]] and [[Martin Zellar]]. He frequently tours with Terri Hendrix throughout the United States, and is a major part of her band and production as an artist.\n\nMaines won a [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album]] in 2003 as producer of the album ''[[Home (The Chicks album)|Home]]'' by [[The Chicks]]' (formerly known as the [[Dixie Chicks]]). As the father of [[Natalie Maines]], lead singer of The Chicks, he was instrumental in bringing the current lineup of bandmates together in 1995, which jump-started their sudden popularity and change in sound. [[Susan Gibson]]'s \"[[Wide Open Spaces (song)|Wide Open Spaces]]\", which had been sent to Maines, proved to be a hit from their debut album, and has remained their [[signature song]].\n\nAs of 2020, Lloyd Maines, on guitars, has accompanied singer/songwriter [[Terri Hendrix]] live and in recordings since 1997 and her second album.<ref name=TerriHendrix_WebsiteHome/>{{Better source needed|reason=This source is a video that might no longer be on Hendrix's website|date=October 2021}}\n\nMaines has twice been inducted into the [[West Texas Walk of Fame]] \u2014 in 1993 as a member of the Maines Brothers Band and in 2012 in his own name.\n\n[[File:Lloyd_Maines_-_Terri_Hendrix_-_Cactus_Cafe_2_-_Ron_Baker_2013.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Lloyd Maines with Terri Hendrix at Cactus Cafe in Austin, TX (2013).]]\n[[File:Lloyd Maines by Ron Baker.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Lloyd Maines at Austin City Limits Music Festival (2006).]]\n\n==See also==\n*[[Music of Austin]]\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.lloydmaines.com Official website]\n*[http://www.virtualubbock.com/intLloydMaines.html Interview with Lloyd Maines]\n*[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p101055/credits|pure_url=yes}} Complete Lloyd Maines discography]\n\n===Archival Materials===\n\n* [http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/ttuav/00026/tav-00026.html Steve Maines papers, 1964-2015, at Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University]\n\n{{Dixie Chicks}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Maines, Lloyd}}\n[[Category:1951 Skaggs"}],"pages":{"12374524":{"pageid":12374524,"ns":0,"title":"Ricky Skaggs","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician, producer, and composer}}\n{{Multiple issues|\n{{BLP sources|date=February 2013}}\n{{More footnotes needed|date=January 2016}}}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Ricky Skaggs\n| image           = Ricky skaggs performing.jpg\n| caption         = Skaggs during the Festival of Faiths in 2007\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = Rickie Lee Skaggs<ref name=\"KT\">{{Cite book |title=Kentucky Traveler: My Life in Music |last=Skaggs |first=Ricky |date=2013}}</ref><ref name=\"Excerpt from KT\" />\n| alias           = \n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1954|7|18}}\n| birth_place     = [[Cordell, Kentucky|Cordell]], Kentucky, U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals, [[mandolin]], guitar, [[banjo]], [[fiddle]]\n| genre           = {{Hlist|[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailypress.com/news/dp-fea-ricky-skaggs-0409-story.html|title=Ricky Skaggs stays true to his country and bluegrass roots|author=Holtzclaw, Mike|newspaper=Daily Press|date=April 9, 2019|access-date=July 21, 2019}}</ref>|[[neotraditionalist country]]<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/how-ricky-skaggs-redefined-bluegrass-and-brought-it-to-the-mainstream-253332/|title=How Ricky Skaggs Redefined Bluegrass and Brought It to the Mainstream|author=Freeman, Jon|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 11, 2017|access-date=July 21, 2019}} [\"Skaggs had his first country Number One, at age 27, in April 1982 with the weepy ballad \u201cCrying My Heart Out Over You.\" It kicked off an incredible run of 12 chart-topping hits, placing him in the first wave of country's celebrated neotraditional movement along with George Strait, John Anderson and Randy Travis.\"]</ref>|[[gospel music|gospel]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1569152/ricky-skaggs-whites-record-gospel-cd/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816203908/http://www.cmt.com/news/1569152/ricky-skaggs-whites-record-gospel-cd/|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 16, 2017|title=Ricky Skaggs, Whites Record Gospel CD|publisher=CMT.com|date=September 7, 2007|access-date=July 21, 2019}}</ref>|[[folk music|folk]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, [[session musician]], bandleader, producer, arranger\n| years_active    = 1961\u2013present\n| label           = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]], [[Epic Records|Epic]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], DCC, [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], Camden, [[Rebel Records|Rebel]], [[Hollywood Records|Hollywood]], [[Legacy Records|Legacy]], Skaggs Family\n| current_member_of = [[Kentucky Thunder]]\n| spouse = {{marriage|Sharon White|1981}}\n| website         = {{URL|www.rickyskaggs.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Rickie Lee Skaggs'''<ref name=\"KT\" /><ref name=\"Excerpt from KT\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1712490/read-from-ricky-skaggs-memoir-kentucky-traveler/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150422020630/http://www.cmt.com/news/1712490/read-from-ricky-skaggs-memoir-kentucky-traveler/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 22, 2015 |title=Read From Ricky Skaggs' Memoir, Kentucky Traveler |last=Skaggs |first=Ricky |date=August 16, 2013 |website=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]}}</ref> (born July 18, 1954),<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2019/07/18/Famous-birthdays-for-July-18-Vin-Diesel-Kristen-Bell/8771563155558/|title=Famous birthdays for July 18: Vin Diesel, Kristen Bell|work=[[United Press International]]|date=July 18, 2019|access-date=August 7, 2019|archive-date=July 19, 2019|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190719181941/https://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2019/07/18/Famous-birthdays-for-July-18-Vin-Diesel-Kristen-Bell/8771563155558/|url-status=live|quote=Country singer Ricky Skaggs in 1954 (age 65)}}</ref> known professionally as '''Ricky Skaggs''', is an American [[neotraditional country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer, musician, producer, and [[composer]]. He primarily plays [[mandolin]]; however, he also plays [[fiddle]], guitar, [[mandocaster]], and [[banjo]].<ref name = zane>{{cite web | url = https://www.zanesvilletimesrecorder.com/story/news/local/2018/11/28/ricky-skaggs-headlining-christmas-shows/2125007002/ | publisher = Zanesville Recorder | title = Ricky Skaggs headlining Christmas shows| access-date = 2 March 2021}}</ref>\n\nSkaggs was inducted into the [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2016 and both the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame]] and the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1792529/country-music-hall-of-fame-elects-ricky-skaggs-dottie-west-johnny-gimble/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327223726/http://www.cmt.com/news/1792529/country-music-hall-of-fame-elects-ricky-skaggs-dottie-west-johnny-gimble/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 27, 2018|title=Country Music Hall of Fame Elects Ricky Skaggs, Dottie West, Johnny Gimble|access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref> On January 13, 2021, it was announced Skaggs had been awarded the [[National Medal of Arts]] by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]], alongside fellow country musician [[Toby Keith]].\n\n==Biography==\n===Early career===\nSkaggs was born in [[Cordell, Kentucky]].<ref name=\"Inc.\">{{cite book|title=American Cowboy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--oCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32|date=May\u2013June 2000|publisher=Active Interest Media, Inc.|page=32|issn=1079-3690}}</ref> He started playing music at age 5 after he was given a [[mandolin]] by his father, Hobert Skaggs. At age 6, he played mandolin and sang on stage with [[Bill Monroe]]. At age 7, he appeared on television's [[Martha White]] country music variety show, playing with [[Lester Flatt]] and [[Earl Scruggs]]. He also wanted to audition for the [[Grand Ole Opry]] at that time, but was told he was too young.\n\nIn his mid-teens, Skaggs met a fellow teen guitarist, [[Keith Whitley]], and the two started playing together with Whitley's banjo playing brother, Dwight, on radio shows. By 1970, they had earned a spot opening for [[Ralph Stanley]], and Skaggs and Keith Whitley were thereafter invited to join Stanley's band, the [[Ralph Stanley#Clinch Mountain Boys|Clinch Mountain Boys]].<ref name = pbs>{{cite web | url = https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/ricky-skaggs-biography/ | publisher = PBS | title = Ricky Skaggs Biography| access-date = 2 March 2021}}</ref>\n\nSkaggs later joined [[The Country Gentlemen]] in Washington, DC, [[J. D. Crowe]]'s [[New South (band)|New South]]. In 1976, Skaggs formed progressive bluegrass band Boone Creek, including members [[Vince Gill]] and [[Jerry Douglas]]. For a few years, Skaggs was a member of [[Emmylou Harris]]'s Hot Band. He wrote the arrangements for Harris's 1980 bluegrass-roots album, ''[[Roses in the Snow]]''. In addition to arranging for Harris, Skaggs sang harmony and played mandolin and fiddle in the Hot Band.\n\n==Country career==\nSkaggs launched his own career in 1980, achieving 12 No. 1 hits, 8 CMA awards, and 8 ACM awards. In 1982, he became a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]], the youngest musician ever to be inducted at that time. Guitarist and producer [[Chet Atkins]] credited Skaggs with \"single-handedly\" saving country music.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rickyskaggs.com/bio |title=The Story |publisher=Ricky Skaggs |date=July 1, 1954 |access-date=January 1, 2016 |archive-date=August 19, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819020842/http://www.rickyskaggs.com/bio |url-status=dead }}</ref> Skaggs is considered one of the pioneers of the [[Neotraditional country]] sub-genre.\n\nIn 1981, he debuted on [[Epic Records]] with the album ''Waitin for the Sun to Shine'', which brought him to both the country and pop charts and produced two No. 1 hits.\n\nIn 1982, he released ''[[Highways & Heartaches (Ricky Skaggs album)|Highways & Heartaches]]'', his only platinum album, featuring the instrumental heavy \"[[Highway 40 Blues]]\".\n\nKeeping with his instrumental heavy themes, he released \"[[Country Boy (Ricky Skaggs song)|Country Boy]]\" on the album of the same name. He also had [[Bill Monroe]] as a guest on this album.\n\nExploring a role as producer, Skaggs produced [[Dolly Parton]]'s album ''[[White Limozeen]]'', which started her comeback in country music.\n\nSkaggs also guested on other albums. In 1995, he sang with [[Vince Gill]] on \"[[Go Rest High on That Mountain]]\", which later won CMA's Song of the Year and was determined by [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] to be the Most-Performed Song in 1997.\n\n==Later career==\n\nIn 1996, Skaggs went back to his [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] roots, and also experimented with new sounds. With his band, [[Kentucky Thunder]], he is a perennial winner of Grammy Awards and International Bluegrass Music Association for best bluegrass album.\n[[File:Ricky Skaggs in May 2016 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Ricky Skaggs in May 2016]]\n\nIn 2000, he shared the stage with Vermont-based [[jam band]], [[Phish]].<ref>{{cite web|title=June 22, 2000 Setlist :: Phish|url=http://phish.net/setlists/?d=2000-06-22|publisher=The Mockingbird Foundation, Inc.|access-date=September 6, 2012}}</ref> On March 20, 2007, Skaggs released an album with rock musician [[Bruce Hornsby]].\n\nIn 2008, Skaggs released an album he recorded with [[The Whites]] on his Skaggs Family Records label.\n\nIn 2008, Skaggs recorded a bluegrass version of \"Old Enough\" by the [[Raconteurs]] with [[Ashley Monroe]] and the [[Raconteurs]]. He played the [[mandolin]] on the track as well as sharing vocals with [[Jack White (musician)|Jack White]], [[Brendan Benson]], and [[Ashley Monroe]].\n\nIn 2011, Skaggs, along with other musicians including the Irish band [[The Brock McGuire Band]], released their album 'Green Grass Blue Grass\", an exploration of the connection between [[Folk music of Ireland|Irish Traditional Music]] and American [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]] and [[Appalachian music]].\n\n[[File:Ricky Skaggs and Sharon White 19Aug2015.jpg|thumb|Ricky Skaggs and Sharon White, McGlohon Theater, Charlotte, NC, August 19, 2015]]\n\nAlso in 2011, Skaggs contributed to ''[[Moody Bluegrass]] TWO...Much Love'', a bluegrass [[tribute album]] to the British [[Progressive Rock]] band [[the Moody Blues]]. Skaggs sang lead vocal on the song \"[[You and Me (Moody Blues song)|You And Me]]\".<ref>\n{{cite web|title=Moody Bluegrass TWO...Much Love|url=http://www.twomuchlove.com/two-much-love-story-2/|publisher=Moody Bluegrass project website|access-date=September 6, 2015|url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706091533/http://www.twomuchlove.com/two-much-love-story-2/|archive-date=July 6, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, Skaggs collaborated with [[Barry Gibb]] on the song, \"Soldier's Son\" which was released on ''Music to My Ears''.\n\nIn 2015, Skaggs toured with [[Ry Cooder]], Sharon White and other members of [[The Whites]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Cozy Up To Warm Sounds for Fall with 'Cooder White Skaggs' Tour |url=http://www.rickyskaggs.com/news/09-09-15/cozy-warm-sounds-fall-cooder-white-skaggs-tour/|publisher=Ricky Skaggs website|access-date=September 9, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 2016, he produced the Grammy-winning album [[Love Remains (Hillary Scott album)|Love Remains]] for [[Lady Antebellum]] member [[Hillary Scott]].\n\nIn 2019, he collaborated with [[Steven Curtis Chapman]] for Chapman's album ''Deeper Roots: Where the Bluegrass Grows''\n\nIn 2019, Skaggs performed at the 6th [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] Concert and Induction Ceremony.\n\nAs of recent years, Skaggs continues performing at the historic Grand Ole Opry house in Nashville, Tennessee.\n\nIn 2021 Skaggs was nominated for the SOTE award which was delayed by the Covid pandemic.\n\n==Personal life==\nRicky Skaggs was previously married to Brenda Stanley and has two children, Andrew and Mandy, from that marriage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Skaggs|first1=Ricky|title=Kentucky Traveler: My Life in Music|date=2014|publisher=Dey Street Books|isbn=978-0061917349}}</ref> Skaggs has been married to Sharon White of [[The Whites]] since August 1981.<ref name=\"wrightforyou.com\">{{cite web |url=http://www.wrightforyou.com/offstage2.html |title=Offstage |website=Wrightforyou.com |access-date=January 1, 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306020610/http://www.wrightforyou.com/offstage2.html |archive-date=March 6, 2016 }}</ref> They have two children; a daughter, Molly, and a son, Lucas.<ref name=\"wrightforyou.com\"/> Molly Skaggs is a Christian/Gospel singer.<ref name=\"Hallels\">{{cite web |url= http://www.hallels.com/articles/20572/20190103/listen-to-bethel-musics-new-rootsy-aint-no-grave-here.htm |title= Listen to Bethel Music's New Rootsy \"Ain't No Grave\" Here : News : Hallels |last= Yap |first= Timothy |date= January 3, 2019 |website= Hallels |access-date= December 16, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Molly Skaggs |url=https://www.cagelessbirds.com/artist-molly-skaggs |access-date=2023-08-29 |website=CAGELESS BIRDS |language=en-US}}</ref> Lucas is a multi-instrumentalist and session musician.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Luke Skaggs |url=https://www.cagelessbirds.com/artist-luke-skaggs |access-date=2023-08-29 |website=CAGELESS BIRDS |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2020, Skaggs underwent quadruple [[coronary artery bypass graft|bypass surgery]] in Nashville.\n\nSkaggs in 2021 was awarded the National Medal of the Arts by President [[Donald Trump]].\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Ricky Skaggs discography}}\n\n==Awards==\n\n===Grammy Awards===\n* 1983 Best Country Instrumental Performance: New South ([[J.D. Crowe]], [[Jerry Douglas]], [[Todd Phillips (musician)|Todd Phillips]], [[Tony Rice]], Ricky Skaggs) for ''Fireball''\n* 1984 Best Country Instrumental Performance: Ricky Skaggs for ''Wheel Hoss''\n* 1986 Best Country Instrumental Performance (Orchestra, Group or Soloist): Ricky Skaggs for ''Raisin' The Dickins''\n* 1991 Best Country Vocal Collaboration: Ricky Skaggs, [[Steve Wariner]] & [[Vince Gill]] for ''[[Restless (Carl Perkins song)|Restless]]''\n* 1998 Best Bluegrass Album: Ricky Skaggs and [[Kentucky Thunder]] for ''Bluegrass Rules!''\n* 1998 Best Country Collaboration with Vocals: [[Clint Black]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Merle Haggard]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Patty Loveless]], [[Earl Scruggs]], Ricky Skaggs, [[Marty Stuart]], [[Pam Tillis]], [[Randy Travis]], [[Travis Tritt]] & [[Dwight Yoakam]] for ''Same Old Train''\n* 1999 Best Bluegrass Album: Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder for ''Ancient Tones''\n* 2000 Best Southern, Country, or Bluegrass Gospel Album: Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder for ''Soldier Of The Cross''\n* 2003 Best Country Performance By A Duo or Group With Vocal: Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder for ''A Simple Life''\n* 2004 Best Bluegrass Album: Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder for ''Brand New Strings''\n* 2005 Best Musical Album For Children, \"Songs From The Neighborhood, The Music Of Mr. Rogers\"\n* 2006 Best Bluegrass Album: Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder for ''Instrumentals''\n* 2008 Best Southern, Country, or Bluegrass Gospel Album: Ricky Skaggs and [[The Whites]] for ''[[Salt of the Earth (Ricky Skaggs & The Whites album)|Salt of the Earth]]''\n* 2009 Best Bluegrass Album ''Honoring The Fathers Of Bluegrass 1946 & 47''\n* 2016 Best Contemporary Christian Music Album (as producer for ''Love Remains'' by [[Hillary Scott]] & The Scott Family )\n\n===CMA (Country Music Association) Awards===\n* 1982 Male Vocalist of the Year: Ricky Skaggs\n* 1982 Horizon Award: Ricky Skaggs\n* 1983 Instrumental Group of the Year: Ricky Skaggs Band\n* 1984 Instrumental Group of the Year: Ricky Skaggs Band\n* 1985 Entertainer of the Year: Ricky Skaggs\n* 1985 Instrumental Group of the Year: Ricky Skaggs Band\n* 1987 Vocal Duo of the Year: Ricky Skaggs & [[The Whites|Sharon White]]\n* 1991 Vocal Event of the Year (with Mark O'Connor & New Nashville Cats)<ref name=\"rickyskaggs.com\">{{cite web |url=http://www.rickyskaggs.com/index.htm?id=14090&sid=14078 |title=Ricky Skaggs |publisher=Ricky Skaggs |access-date=January 1, 2016 |archive-date=November 28, 2010 Ricky Skaggs Band\n* 1984 Specialty Instrument: Ricky Skaggs (Mandolin)\n* 1985 Band of the Year \u2013 Touring: Ricky Skaggs Band\n* 1986 Band of the Year \u2013 Touring: Ricky Skaggs Band\n* 1987 Specialty Instrument: Ricky Skaggs\n<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acmcountry.com/winners |title=ACM Winners &#124; Academy of Country Music |website=Acmcountry.com |access-date=January 1, 2016}}</ref>\n\n===IBMA (International Bluegrass Music Association) Awards===\n* 1998 Instrumental Group of the Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 1998 Album Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder for ''Bluegrass Rules!''\n* 1999 Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2000 Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2000 Instrumental Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2003 Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2004 Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2005 Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2006 Instrumental Group Of The Year: Ricky Skaggs & Kentucky Thunder\n* 2008 Recorded Event of the Year: Everett Lilly & Everybody and Their Brother; Featuring Everett Lilly, Bea Lilly, Charles Lilly, Daniel Lilly, Mark Lilly, Marty Stuart, Rhonda Vincent, Billy Walker, Ronnie McCoury, Rob McCoury, David Ball, Charlie Cushman, Larry Stephenson, Joe Spivey, Eddie Stubbs, Jason Carter, Dickey Lee, Freddy Weller, Mike Bub, Rad Lewis, Andy May, Darrin Vincent, Marcia Campbell, Clay Rigdon, Eric Blankenship and Bill Wolfenbarger (artists); Charles Lilly & Bill Wolfenbarger (producers); Swift River Music\n* 2012 Gospel Recorded Performance of the Year: \"Singing as We Rise\", [[Gibson Brothers (bluegrass)|Gibson Brothers]] with Ricky Skaggs\n* 2017 Gospel Recorded Performance of the Year for song \"Sacred Memories\", Joe Mullins & the Radio Ramblers with Ricky Skaggs and Sharon White Skaggs  \n* 2018 [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame]] inductee\n\n===TNN/Music City News Country Awards===\n* 1982 Bluegrass Act of the Year\n* 1983 Bluegrass Act of the Year \n* 1983 Star of Tomorrow\n* 1984 Bluegrass Act of the Year\n* 1988 Instrumentalist of the Year\n* 1989 Instrumentalist of the Year\n* 1990 Instrumentalist of the Year\n* 1996 Vocal Collaboration of the Year (with Vince Gill & Patty Loveless)<ref name=\"rickyskaggs.com\"/>\n\n===Other awards and accomplishments===\n* [[National Medal of Arts]], awarded by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] in 2021\n* Inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame on March 27, 2018, in the Modern Era category\n* [[Kentucky Music Hall of Fame]], Class of 2004\n* R&R Best New Artist{{citation needed|date=January 2021}}\n* [[Billboard magazine]]'s Artist of the Year\n* Musician Magazine- Voted One of the Top 100 Guitarists of the Century\n* Artist of the Decade- Listeners' Poll Award [[BBC]] Radio 2\n* [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s [[40 Greatest Men of Country Music]] rank No.&nbsp;37 in 2003.\n* Judge for the 2nd annual Independent Music Awards\n* ACM's Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award, 2012\n* [[Gospel Music Hall of Fame]] inductee, 2012\n* Bluegrass Star Award, presented by the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation of Dallas, Texas (2017).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://bluegrassheritage.org/bluegrass-star-award/ |title=Bluegrass Star Award, by the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation |website=Bluegrass Heritage Foundation |language=en-US |access-date=October 31, 2017}}</ref>\n* Honorary Doctorate of Humanities from [[Eastern Kentucky University]] \u2013 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://honorarydegrees.eku.edu/honorary-degree-recipients|title=Honorary Degree Recipients \u2013 Honorary Degrees \u2013 Eastern Kentucky University|website=honorarydegrees.eku.edu|access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref> \n* Honorary Doctorate of Music from [[Berklee College of Music]] \u2013 received in March 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/2008-03-15-3399074100_x.htm|title=Ricky Skaggs getting honorary doctorate - USATODAY.com|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com|access-date=July 23, 2018}}</ref>\n* Plaque on Nashville's [[StarWalk]], 1987<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.apnews.com/6fdce423ff3e624e016d874602627495 |title=Country Music Stars Initiate Sidewalk Memorial |date=August 5, 1987 |website=[[Associated Press|APNews.com]] |access-date=February 17, 2019 }}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lester_Flatt","to":"Lester Flatt"}],"pages":{"60626":{"pageid":60626,"ns":0,"title":"Lester Flatt","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1914\u20131979)}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name            = Lester Flatt\n|image           = Publicity_Photo_of_Lester_Flatt.jpg\n|image_size      = \n|caption         = Publicity Photo of Lester Flatt\n|background      = solo_singer \n|birth_name      = Lester Raymond Flatt\n|birth_date      = {{birth date|1914|6|19}}\n|birth_place     = [[Overton County, Tennessee]], U.S.\n|death_date      = {{death date and age|1979|5|11|1914|6|19}}\n|death_place     = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n|instrument      = Guitar, vocals, [[mandolin]]\n|genre           = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[country music|country]]\n|occupation      = Musician, songwriter\n|years_active    = 1940\u20131979\n|label           = \n|past_member_of  = [[Flatt and Scruggs]], [[Nashville Grass]]\n}}\n\n'''Lester Raymond Flatt''' (June 19, 1914 \u2013 May 11, 1979)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Lester-Flatt|title=Lester Flatt &#124; American musician|website=[[Encyclopedia Britannica]]|access-date=August 28, 2021}}</ref> was an American [[bluegrass (music)|bluegrass]] guitarist and mandolinist, best known for his collaboration with banjo picker [[Earl Scruggs]] in the duo [[Flatt and Scruggs]].\n\nFlatt's career spanned multiple decades, breaking out as a member of [[Bill Monroe]]'s band during the 1940s and including multiple solo and collaboration works exclusive of Scruggs. He first reached a mainstream audience through his performance on \"[[The Ballad of Jed Clampett]]\", the theme for the network television series ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]'', in the early 1960s.\n\n==Biography==\n[[File:Earl Scruggs and Lester Flatt.jpg|thumb|left|Lester Flatt (right) with [[Earl Scruggs]] (left) as part of [[Flatt and Scruggs]] in 1949]]\nFlatt was born in Duncan's Chapel, [[Overton County, Tennessee]], United States,<ref name=browne>{{cite book |editor1-last=Browne |editor1-first=Ray B. |editor2-last=Browne |editor2-first=Pat |url={{Google books|U3rJxPYT32MC|page=284|plainurl=yes}} |chapter=Flatt and Scruggs |title=The Guide to United States Popular Culture |publisher=[[Popular Press]] |year=2001 |page=284 |isbn=978-0879728212}}</ref> to Nannie Mae Haney and Isaac Columbus Flatt. In 1943, he played [[mandolin]] and sang [[tenor]] in The Kentucky Pardners, the band of [[Bill Monroe]]'s older brother [[Charlie Monroe|Charlie]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flatt-and-scruggs.com/lesterbio.html |title=Biography: Lester Flatt |website=Flatt-and-scruggs.com |access-date=June 6, 2020}}</ref> He first came to prominence as a member of [[Bill Monroe]]'s Blue Grass Boys in 1945 and played a thumb-and-index guitar style that was in part derived from the playing of Charlie Monroe and Clyde Moody. In 1948, he started a band with fellow Monroe alumnus [[Earl Scruggs]], and for the next 20 years, [[Flatt and Scruggs]] and the Foggy Mountain Boys were one of the most successful bands in bluegrass.<ref name=ecm>{{cite book |last=Rosenberg |first=Neil V. |year=1998 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PT504 |chapter=Flatt & Scruggs and the Foggy Mountain Boys |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=173\u20134 |isbn=978-0195395631}}</ref> When they parted ways in 1969, Flatt formed a new group, the [[Nashville Grass]], hiring many of the Foggy Mountain Boys. He continued to record and perform with that group until his death in 1979.<ref name=ecm2>{{cite book |last=Samuelson |first=Dave |year=1998 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PT504 |chapter=Lester Flatt & the Nashville Grass |title= The Encyclopedia of Country Music |editor-first=Paul |editor-last=Kingsbury |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=173 |isbn=978-0195395631}}</ref> His role as rhythm guitarist and vocalist in each of these seminal ensembles helped define the sound of traditional bluegrass music. His solid guitar playing and rich lead voice are unmistakable in hundreds of bluegrass standards. He is also remembered for his library of compositions.\n\n==Death and legacy==\nFlatt died of heart failure in Nashville, Tennessee, at the age of 64.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/05/12/archives/lester-flatt-singer-and-guitarist-in-duo-with-earl-scruggs-dies.html |title=Lester Flatt, Singer and Guitarist in Duo With Earl Scruggs, Dies |first=John |last=Rockwell |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=26 |date=May 12, 1979}}</ref>\n\nHe was posthumously inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1985 along with Scruggs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/flatt-and-scruggs |title=Flatt and Scruggs |website=[[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]] |access-date=August 15, 2016}}</ref> Flatt was also posthumously inducted as an inaugural member of the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Honor]] in 1991.\n\nLester's hometown of [[Sparta, Tennessee]], held a bluegrass festival in his honor for a number of years, before being discontinued a few years prior to the death of the traditional host, resident Everette Paul England; Lester Flatt Memorial Bluegrass Day remains part of the annual Liberty Square Celebration held in Sparta.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eastpublicrelations.com/lester_flatt_memorial_bluegrass.htm |title=Lester Flatt Memorial Bluegrass Day |website=East Public Relations |date=September 29, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071205192520/http://www.eastpublicrelations.com/lester_flatt_memorial_bluegrass.htm |archive-date=December 5, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>\n\nFlatt and Scruggs were ranked No. 24 on [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s 40 Greatest Men of Country Music in 2003.\n\n==Discography==\n[[File:Lester-flatt-sparta-tn-memorial2.jpg|right|thumb|Lester Flatt memorial in Sparta, Tennessee]]\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Irene_Kelley","to":"Irene Kelley"}],"pages":{"49881749":{"pageid":49881749,"ns":0,"title":"Irene Kelley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country and bluegrass musician}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Irene Kelley\n| image           =\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      =\n| birth_place     = [[Latrobe, Pennsylvania]]<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|page=89|year=2008|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      =\n| years_active    = 1980s\u2013present\n| label           = [[MCA Records|MCA]], Madacy, Irk, Patio, [[Mountain Fever Records|Mountain Fever]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|www.irenekelley.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Irene Kelley''' is an American [[Country music|country]] and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] musician. As a songwriter, she has written for [[Ricky Skaggs]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Loretta Lynn]], and [[the Osborne Brothers]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lawless|first1=John|title=Carolina Wind- new single from Irene Kelley|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/carolina-wind-new-single-from-irene-kelley/|accessdate=2 July 2016|publisher=Bluegrass Today|date=16 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Recker|first1=Scott|title=Pennsylvania Coal|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/178322-irene-kelley-pennsylvania-coal/|accessdate=5 July 2016|publisher=PopMatters|date=12 February 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nKelley is originally from Pennsylvania and in high school sang in a Led Zeppelin cover band.<ref name=\"ColumbusLedZepplin\">{{cite news|last1=Clementi|first1=Tyler|title=How Led Zeppelin led to Bluegrass for Irene Kelley|url=http://www.columbusunderground.com/how-led-zeppelin-led-to-bluegrass-for-irene-kelley-dd1|accessdate=4 July 2016|publisher=Columbus Underground|date=8 February 2015}}</ref> She was asked to leave the group after suggesting the band cover songs from Dolly Parton.<ref name=\"ColumbusLedZepplin\"/>\n\n==Career==\nKelley moved to Nashville, Tennessee in the early 1980s. This was after visiting on her honeymoon in 1983 and discovering the first gathering of the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Randy|title=Irene Kelley's roots run deep through Pennsylvania Coal|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/irene-kelleys-roots-run-deep-through-pennsylvania-coal/Content?oid=4059487|accessdate=2 July 2016|publisher=Nashville Scene|date=13 February 2014|ref=NashScene}}</ref> Kelley co-wrote the [[Ricky Skaggs]] and [[The Whites|Sharon White]] song \"[[Love Can't Ever Get Better Than This]]\" with Nancy Montgomery. The song peaked at number ten on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles]] chart in 1987 and was awarded Duet of the Year at the [[Country Music Association Awards]] that same year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Peter|title=Ricky Skaggs and Sharon White find harmony|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/peter-cooper/2014/10/03/ricky-skaggs-sharon-white-find-harmony/16586533/|accessdate=2 July 2016|publisher=The Tennessean|date=3 October 2014}}</ref> Kelley signed to [[MCA Records]] in the late 1980s.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]<br><ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n|-\n| 1989\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love Is a Hard Road\"\n| 67\n|-\n| 1991\n! scope=\"row\"| \"A Rock and a Rolling Stone\"<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1991/BB-1991-01-05.pdf|title=Single Reviews|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=January 5, 1991}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Something About a Train Sound\"\n|\u2014\n|- colspan=\"3\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tony_Furtado","to":"Tony Furtado"}],"pages":{"1655061":{"pageid":1655061,"ns":0,"title":"Tony Furtado","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Tony Furtado\n| image           = Tony Furtado Fox Theatre Boulder CO February 2008.jpg\n| image_size    = \n| landscape      = \n| caption          = Fox Theater, Boulder, Colorado, February 8, 2008\n| background    = solo_singer\n| birth_name    = \n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|mf=y|1967|10|18}}\n| birth_place     = [[Pleasanton, California]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]], [[country music|country]], [[rock music|rock]]\n| occupation     = Musician\n| instrument     =  [[banjo]], [[slide guitar]], [[electric guitar]]\n| years_active  =\n| label             = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], Yousay Furtado Records\n| associated_acts =\n| website      = {{URL|www.tonyfurtado.com}}\n}}\n'''Tony Furtado''' (born October 18, 1967) is an American singer-songwriter, banjoist, and guitarist.\n\n== History ==\n[[Image:Tony Furtado 2.jpg|left|thumb|Fox Theater, Boulder, Colorado, February 8, 2008]]\nFurtado was born in [[Pleasanton, California]]. He took up the banjo at age 12, inspired by the [[The Beverly Hillbillies|Beverly Hillbillies]] television show and a sixth-grade music report. He studied music and art at [[California State University, East Bay|California State, Hayward]]. He first attracted national attention in 1987, when he won the National Bluegrass Banjo Championship in Winfield, Kansas. Then he toured with bluegrass musician [[Laurie Lewis]]. [[Rounder Records]] released his debut album, ''Swamped'', in 1990.<ref>[http://www.modernguitars.com/archives/002779.html \"Tony Furtado Interview\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501142050/http://www.modernguitars.com/archives/002779.html |date=2007-05-01 }} by Tom Watson, January 18, 2007 ''Modern Guitars''.</ref>\n\nIn 1990, Tony signed a recording deal with [[Rounder Records]], one of the country's preeminent independent record companies. Beginning with Swamped in 1990, he recorded six critically acclaimed albums for the label, collaborating with such master musicians as [[Alison Krauss]], [[Jerry Douglas]], [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], [[Stuart Duncan]], [[Kelly Joe Phelps]] and [[Mike Marshall (musician)|Mike Marshall]]. During this period, Tony also performed and recorded with the band SugarBeat and the Rounder Banjo Extravaganza with [[Tony Trischka]] and Tom Adams.\n\nBeginning in the late 1990s \u2013 influenced by such musicians as [[Ry Cooder]], [[David Lindley (musician)|David Lindley]] and [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]] \u2013 Tony added slide guitar, singing and songwriting to his musical toolbox and began leading his own band.\n\nFurtado is an accomplished sculptor.\n\n== Performance ==\nFurtado is a tireless road musician who performs in a variety of formats: solo, in a duo, or trio or with his full five-person band. He has toured with such legendary musicians as [[Gregg Allman]] and with such esteemed slide guitarists as David Lindley, Derek Trucks, and [[Sonny Landreth]].\n\nHe has performed throughout the world at top venues and appeared at such prestigious music festivals as the [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]], High Sierra Music Festival, Jazz Aspen, Kerrville Folk Festival, Strawberry Music Festival, Winnipeg Folk Festival, Sisters Folk Festival, San Jose Jazz Festival and countless others. . His second album, ''Within Reach'' (1992), featured bluegrass veterans [[Alison Krauss]] and [[Jerry Douglas]].\n\nHe recorded a duet album with [[Dirk Powell]].<ref name=\"Wilson\">{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=MacKenzie|title=Tony Furtado {{!}} Biography & History {{!}} AllMusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/tony-furtado-mn0000000589/biography|website=AllMusic|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>\n\n== Band ==\nHis band Sugarbeat also featured Ben Demerath (vocals, guitar), [[Matt Flinner]] (mandolin), and Sally Truitt (bass).<ref name=\"TF-deseret-1994\">{{cite news|last1=Bonham|first1=Nicole A.|title=Sugarbeat Reels In Audience with Songs about Fish, Future|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/337882/SUGARBEAT-REELS-IN-AUDIENCE-WITH-SONGS-ABOUT-FISH-FUTURE.html?pg=all|accessdate=August 6, 2017|work=Deseret News|date=February 21, 1994}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and honors ==\n* Won [[National Bluegrass Banjo Championship]], [[Winfield, Kansas]], 1987 and 1991\n\n==Musical style==\nTony is an evocative and soulful singer, a wide-ranging songwriter and a virtuoso multi-instrumental-ist adept on banjo, cello-banjo, slide guitar and baritone ukulele who mixes and matches sounds and styles with the flair of a master chef.  Comparisons to [[Ry Cooder]] were rooted in Furtado's combination of jazz, Celtic, and old-time music. On his third album, ''Full Circle'' (1994) he concentrated on acoustic blues and [[slide guitar]], with Cooder as an influence.\n\n\"Furtado mixes Americana, folk, indie-rock, blues, and jazz styles.\"<ref>[http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=1001 \"Tony Furtado goes for a lucky 'Thirteen'\"] by Jason MacNeil, January 2007, ''Country Standard Time''</ref>\n\n\"As a banjo virtuoso, Furtado is well known for his envelope-pushing, progressive bluegrass stylings. His picking is rapid-fire quick, sharp and clear, and puts him in the school of B\u00e9la Fleck and [[David Grisman]].\"<ref>[http://www.telluridegateway.com/articles/2007/03/09/the_pulse/pulse03.txt \"Furtado brings eclectic bag of tricks to Opera House\"] by Katie Klingsporn, March 8, 2007, ''Telluride Daily Planet''.</ref>\n\n\"He mixes bluegrass roots with a mainstream pop streak, easily holding the spotlight, thanks to his restrained virtuosity on acoustic and slide guitar and a warmly engaging voice reminiscent of T Bone Burnett, sans preachiness. \u2013 ''Paste'' magazine\n\n== Discography ==\n* ''Swamped'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]], 1990)\n* ''Within Reach'' (Rounder, 1992)\n* ''Full Circle'' (Rounder, 1994)\n* ''Roll My Blues Away'' (Rounder, 1997)\n* ''Tony Furtado & Dirk Powell'' (Rounder, 1999)\n* ''Tony Furtado Band'' (Rounder, 2000)\n* ''American Gypsy'' (What Are, 2002)\n* ''Live Gypsy'' (Dualtone, 2003)\n* ''These Chains'' (Funzalo, 2004)\n* ''Bare Bones'' (Funzalo, 2005)\n* ''Thirteen'' (Funzalo, 2007)\n* ''Deepwater'' (Funzalo, 2008)\n* ''Golden'' (Funzalo, 2010)\n* ''Live at Mississippi Studios'' (Funzalo, 2012)\n* ''The Bell'' (Yousay Furtado Records, 2015)\n* ''Cider House Sessions'' (Yousay Furtado Records, 2017)\n* \"Decembering\" (Yousay Furtado Records, 2021)\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External
