Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bradley_Walker_(singer)","to":"Bradley Walker (singer)"}],"pages":{"52268342":{"pageid":52268342,"ns":0,"title":"Bradley Walker (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country vocalist}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Bradley Walker\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = 1978\n| birth_place     = [[Athens, Alabama]]\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| origin          =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]\n| years_active    = 1998\u2013present\n| label           = [[Gaither Music Group]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|bradleywalker.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Bradley Walker''' is an American [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[country music]] singer and songwriter.\n\n==Early life==\nBradley Walker is a native of [[Athens, Alabama]]. He was born with [[muscular dystrophy]], and has been in a wheelchair all his life. He was a student at [[Limestone County School District|East Limestone High School]] where he played percussion in the school band.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archive.decaturdaily.com/decaturdaily/news/060721/walker.shtml |title=Riding on a 'Highway of Dreams' |first= Holly|last= Hollman |work=The Decatur Daily |date=July 21, 2006 }}</ref>\n\nWalker started singing when he was two or three years old, and began performing in public when he was four.<ref name=\"waff\">{{cite news |url=http://www.waff.com/story/13305350/overcoming-the-odds-country-singer-lives-out-his-dreams |title=Overcoming the Odds: Country singer lives out his dreams |first=Kimberly|last= Essex |work=WAFF48 }}</ref>  When he was ten, he was invited on stage to perform with [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], and when he was eleven, he sang with The Oak Ridge Boys on [[The Nashville Network]]'s [[Nashville Now]] as well as on the [[The Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon|Jerry Lewis MDA Telethon]].<ref name=\"profile\">{{cite web |url=http://americanprofile.com/articles/singer-bradley-walker/ |title=Singer Thrives Despite Disease |first= Michael|last= McCall |date=January 20, 2008 |work=American Profile }}</ref>\n\nHe works at the [[Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Plant]] as a Material Inventory Coordinator while pursuing a music career.<ref name=\"waff\"/>\n\n==Music career==\nIn 1998,  Walker formed a band, The Trinity Mountain Boys, and began to perform at bluegrass festivals.<ref name=\"profile\" /> In 2001, he joined the Georgia-based group Lost Horizon.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/297056/bradley-walker/biography |title=Bradley Walker > Biography |magazine=Billboard |access-date=2016-11-13 |archive-date=2016-11-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129220949/http://www.billboard.com/artist/297056/bradley-walker/biography |url-status=dead }}</ref>  He was signed to [[Rounder Records]], and released his debut album, ''Highway of Dreams'', in 2006. The album was produced by [[Carl Jackson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6955339 |title='Highway of Dreams' for Singer Bradley Walker|date=January 23, 2007 |work=NPR}}</ref>  For his performance on the album, he won the Male Vocalist of the Year Award from the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]].<ref name=\"rolling stone\"/>\n\n===2016:  ''Call Me Old-Fashioned''===\nWalker's second album, ''Call Me Old-Fashioned'', was produced by [[Rory Feek]] and recorded at the [[Joey + Rory]] studio out on their farm.  Walker had known Joey and Rory Feek since 2007, and he was asked by Rory Feek to sing the hymn \"[[Leave It There]]\" at the funeral of [[Joey Feek]] in accordance with her wishes.<ref name=\"rolling stone\">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/features/bradley-walker-on-joey-feeks-influence-behind-new-album-w445844 |title=Bradley Walker on Joey Feek's Influence Behind New Album |magazine= Rolling Stone |first=Deborah |last=Evans Price|date=October 20, 2016 }}</ref> [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]] of the [[Gaither Music Group]], who was also at the funeral service, heard Walker's performance and signed Walker to his label.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gospelherald.com/articles/67436/20161021/christian-artist-born-with-muscular-dystrophy-discusses-faith-influence-of-rory-and-joey-feek-album-call-me-old-fashioned.htm |title=Christian Artist Born with Muscular Dystrophy Discusses Faith, Influence of Rory and Joey Feek, Album 'Call Me Old-Fashioned' |first=Leah Marianne |last=Klett|date= October 21, 2016|work=Gospel Herald }}</ref> The album includes a posthumous duet with Joey Feek, \"In The Time That You Gave Me\",  using vocals she recorded before her death.<ref name=\"rolling stone\"/> The album was released on September 23, 2016,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/call-me-old-fashioned-mw0002974140 |title=Call Me Old-Fashioned |first=Mark |last=Deming |work=AllMusic }}</ref> and debuted at No. 9 on the Top Country Albums chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7550131/bradley-walker-call-me-old-fashioned-album-joey-rory-show|title=Bradley Walker Reflects on His Surprise Top 10 Country Album & Singing at Joey Feek's Funeral |date=October 25, 2016 |first= Chuck |last=Dauphin |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>\n\n===2017\u201319: ''Blessed: Hymns & Songs of Faith'' ===\nOn October 6, 2017, Walker released ''Blessed: Hymns & Songs of Faith''. The album, produced by Ben Isaacs, features collaborations with [[Vince Gill]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Jimmy Fortune]], [[The Oak Ridge Boys]], [[The Isaacs]] and [[Ricky Skaggs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Blessed-Hymns-and-Songs-of-Faith-by-Bradley-Walker-ft-Alison-Krauss-More-Out-Now-20171006 |title='Blessed: Hymns and Songs of Faith' by Bradley Walker ft, Alison Krauss & More Out Now|date=October 6, 2017 |work = Music World.com }}</ref>  The album received a [[GMA Dove Award]] for the Bluegrass/Country/Roots Album of the Year in 2018.<ref name=\"whnt\" />\n\nHe also performed a song \"Leave It There\" in the Homecoming CD/DVD release ''Give the World A Smile'' in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.gastongazette.com/entertainment/20170406/bill-and-gloria-gaither-share-2-new-homecoming-albums|title=Bill and Gloria Gaither share 2 new 'Homecoming' albums |work=Gaston Gazette |first=Wade |last=Allen |date= April 6, 2017}}</ref>\n\nWalker appeared at the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival 2019]] alongside Vince Gill.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/eric-clapton-2019-crossroads-festival-live-album-1065415/ Eric Clapton\u2019s 2019 Crossroads Fest Set for Live LP/Concert Film Release ] ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', September 23, 2020. Retrieved 11 October 2021</ref>\n\n===2020&ndash;present: Brothers of the Heart===\n\nIn 2020, Walker collaborated with [[Jimmy Fortune]], Ben Isaacs, and Mike Rogers to release an album ''Brotherly Love'' and a concert DVD/TV special filmed at Rory Feek's barn/studio near Columbia, TN.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/jimmy-fortune-isaacs-rogers-walker-elizabeth-premiere/ |title=Jimmy Fortune, Ben Isaacs, Mike Rogers and Bradley Walker Deliver New Take on Statlers' Classic 'Elizabeth' |first= Deborah |last= Evans Price|date= September 18, 2020|work=Sounds Like Nashville }}</ref> The album was released digitally on May 29, 2020, and the DVD and CD released on September 4, 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/new-music/8383-jimmy-fortune-bradley-walker-mike-rogers-ben-isaacs-release-gaither-music-group-cd-dvd-tv-special |title=Jimmy Fortune, Bradley Walker, Mike Rogers & Ben Isaacs Release Gaither Music Group CD, DVD & TV Special |date= September 3, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs|work=The Christian Beat }}</ref> The concert film aired on the [[Circle (TV network)|Circle]] network on October 20, 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thechristianbeat.org/index.php/news/8725-gaither-music-group-s-brotherly-love-premieres-on-circle-network |title=Gaither Music Group's 'Brotherly Love' Premieres On Circle Network |date= October 20, 2020 |first= Herb |last=Longs |work=The Christian Beat}}</ref> The collaboration was successful and they decided to continue with another project, and while they were recording their second album they named their group Brothers of the Heart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ccmmagazine.com/ccm-cafe/a-conversation-with-brothers-of-the-heart-fortune-walker-rogers-isaacs/ |title=A Conversation with Brothers of the Heart (Fortune, Walker, Rogers, Isaacs) |first= Brandon |last=Woolum |date= February 10, 2023 |work=CCM Magazine}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2023, Brothers of the Heart released the second album, ''Listen To The Music''.  The album reached No. 5 on the Top Christian Albums chart, and No. 32 on Top Album Sales.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://todayschristianent.com/music-news-brothers-of-the-heart-to-perform-on-the-opry-feb-7-listen-to-the-music-hits-1-on-billboard-christian-album-chart/ |title=\nMusic News: Brothers of the Heart to perform on The Opry Feb. 7; 'Listen To The Music' hits #1 on Billboard Christian album chart |work=Today Christian Entertainment }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Alabama]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:1978 births]]\n[[Category:People with muscular dystrophy]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Devil_Makes_Three_(band)","to":"The Devil Makes Three (band)"}],"pages":{"7850608":{"pageid":7850608,"ns":0,"title":"The Devil Makes Three (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American bluegrass trio from Santa Cruz, California}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = The Devil Makes Three\n| background       = group_or_band\n| image            = The Devil Makes Three 2016.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| caption          = The Devil Makes Three in 2016\n| alias            = \n| origin           = [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]], [[California]]\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]]\n*[[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n*[[Folk music|folk]]\n*[[folk blues]]\n*[[old-time music|old-time]]\n*[[Country music|country]]\n}}\n| years_active     = 2002\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Milan Records|Milan]]\n*[[New West Records|New West]]\n*[[Monkeywrench Records|Monkeywrench]]\n*Khan\n}}\n| associated_acts  = \n| website          = {{URL|http://thedevilmakesthree.com}}\n| current_members  = Pete Bernhard<br />Lucia Turino<br />Cooper McBean\n| past_members     = \n}}\n'''The Devil Makes Three''' is an [[Americana (music)|Americana]] band from [[Santa Cruz, California]], United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://amusicblogyea.com/2015/03/17/gimme-your-answers-an-interview-w-the-devil-makes-three/|title=Gimme Your Answers: An Interview w/ The Devil Makes Three|last=Fox|first=Iain|date=17 March 2015|website=Amusicblogyea.com|access-date=22 September 2016}}</ref> The group blends [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[old time music|old time]], [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]], [[blues music|blues]], [[jazz music|jazz]], and [[ragtime music|ragtime]] music.<ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedevilmakesthree.com/biography.php|title=Biography - The Devil Makes Three|publisher=Milan Records|accessdate=14 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090820183835/http://thedevilmakesthree.com/biography.php|archive-date=20 August 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref> The group's members are [[guitarist]] Pete Bernhard, [[Double bass|upright bassist]] Lucia Turino, and [[guitarist]] and [[banjo|tenor banjo]] player Cooper McBean.\n\n==Career==\nThe band has released six full-length albums.  They independently released a self-titled album in 2002.  Another independent release followed in 2004, ''Longjohns, Boots, And A Belt''.  The band recorded two shows in April 2006 in [[Felton, California|Felton]], [[California]] with guest [[fiddle]]r Chojo Jacques.  The recordings were later released as a live album, ''A Little Bit Faster And A Little Bit Worse''.\n\nAfter the release of their live album, the band signed with independent label [[Milan Records]], which specializes in [[film scores]] and [[soundtrack]]s.  Their first album on Milan was a re-release of their debut album, ''The Devil Makes Three''.  In 2009, they followed with an all-new album, ''Do Wrong Right''.\n\nBand member Bernhard independently released a solo album, ''Things I Left Behind'' (2006).  In September 2009 Bernhard released his next solo album, ''Straight Line'', on Milan Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antimusic.com/news/09/june/30The_Devil_Makes_Three_Frontman_Goes_Solo_Again.shtml|title=The Devil Makes Three Frontman Goes Solo Again|date=30 June 2009|website=Antimusic.com|accessdate=17 July 2009}}</ref>\n\nMcBean and Bernhard are originally from near Brattleboro, Vermont, where they played music together as childhood friends and when they were in high school.  They were also acquainted with Turino (from New Hampshire but raised in Vermont), but didn't know her well.  After graduating from high school, all three moved to California separately, Bernhard by way of Nashville.  Bernhard and McBean re-connected in Olympia.  Later in Santa Cruz they also became reacquainted with Turino, forming the band soon after in 2001.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web|last1=Linn|first1=Sarah|title=The Devil Makes Three ready to rock at SLO concert|url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article39510666.html|website=The Tribune (San Luis Obispo)|accessdate=14 January 2018|date=28 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jasper|first1=David|title=Hillbilly punk: The Devil Makes Three has unplugged and gone country|url=http://www.bendbulletin.com/slideshows/1506523-151/hillbilly-punk|website=The Bulletin|accessdate=14 January 2018|date=14 April 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fun Has Just Begun: The Devil Makes Three comes home thirsty and ready to rock|url=http://goodtimes.sc/uncategorized/fun-has-just-begun/|website=Goodtimes.sc|accessdate=14 January 2018|date=27 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ellis|first1=Lauren|title=Doing Wrong Right: The Devil Makes Three|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2011/10/the-devil-makes-three-stomp-and-smash/|website=Mother Jones|accessdate=14 January 2018|date=31 October 2011}}</ref><ref name=\"auto1\">{{cite web|last1=Peterson|first1=Kate|title=Devil's in the Details|url=http://inweekly.net/wordpress/?p=9993|website=In Weekly |accessdate=14 January 2018|date=16 May 2012}}</ref>  Before forming The Devil Makes Three with Turino, both Bernhard and McBean played in punk bands and later toured as a duo.<ref name=\"charleston\">{{cite web |last1=Lawrence |first1=Stratton |title=Moshing with folk-punk act the Devil Makes Three |url=https://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/moshing-with-folk-punk-act-the-devil-makes-three/Content?oid=3654375 |website=Charleston City Paper |accessdate=4 September 2018 |date=3 December 2011}}</ref>\n\nAround 2010, Bernhard and Turino moved back to Brattleboro. McBean remained in California and later moved to Austin.<ref name=\"auto\"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Diamond|first1=Austen|title=The Devil Makes Three Tonight at the State Room: Americana band The Devil Makes Three farms for forbidden fruit.|url=https://www.cityweekly.net/utah/the-devil-makes-three/Content?oid=2149729|website=Salt Lake City Weekly|accessdate=14 January 2018|date=10 October 2010}}</ref><ref name=\"auto1\"/> Despite no longer living in the same town, the band continues to tour and write.\n\nIn August 2010, the band performed at [[Outside Lands Music and Arts Festival]]. They have also performed several times at the annual [[Hardly Strictly Bluegrass]] Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfstation.com/2013/10/01/devil-makes-three-hardly-strictly-bluegrass/|title=Devil Makes Three Returns With New Music to Hardly Strictly Bluegrass|website=Sfstation.com|accessdate=22 August 2018}}</ref>\n\nOn June 4, 2018, The Devil Makes Three announced their new studio album, ''[[Chains Are Broken]]'', which was produced by [[Ted Hutt]] and released on August 24, 2018, via [[New West Records]]. Along with the album announcement, they released \"Paint My Face\" as a streaming single and released another album track, \"Bad Idea\", on July 13, 2018.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"5\"| Peak chart positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Bluegrass Albums|US Grass]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the devil makes three|chart=Bluegrass Albums}}|title=The Devil Makes Three \u2013 Chart history \u2013 Bluegrass Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=9 December 2020}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the devil makes three|chart=Billboard 200}}|title=The Devil Makes Three \u2013 Chart history \u2013 Billboard 200|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=9 December 2020}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the devil makes three|chart=Heatseekers Albums}}|title=The Devil Makes Three \u2013 Chart history \u2013 Heatseekers Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=9 December 2020}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Independent Albums|US Indie]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the devil makes three|chart=Independent Albums}}|title=The Devil Makes Three \u2013 Chart history \u2013 Independent Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=9 December 2020}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Folk Albums|US Folk]]<br /><ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the devil makes three|chart=FLK}}|title=The Devil Makes Three \u2013 Chart history \u2013 Americana/Folk Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=9 December 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Devil Makes Three''\n| \n* Release date: November 1, 2002\n* Label: [[Monkeywrench Records|Monkeywrench]]\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Longjohns, Boots, and a Belt''\n| \n* Release date: November 18, 2003\n* Label: The Devil Makes Three\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n!
